PETITION.TITLE: Australian Coastline
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned, wish to lodge our protest, in the strongest possible terms, at the Federal Government's inaction to take legislative measures to protect our coast.

We the surfriders and TRACKS readers of Australia have watched our coastal treasures, the ecology, biodiversity and beauty of the Australian coast marred by urban development, poor planning and pollution, especially over the last 25 years.
The ALP has been in government for half that time and we've lost double our resources.
We (not so humbly) demand that you urge the Federal Government to act now to establish a national coastal agency with national powers to stop the destruction of our Australian coastline.
We also demand that the Federal Government recognise and include surfriders in the major decision making forums and call on you to contribute resources toward those who protect our surfing coast.
Finally, we demand that the environment be recognised in the Australian Constitution.
We are tired of waiting! You must act now. Please write to me and inform me of what you are going to do to save our surf.

PETITION.TITLE: French Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia respectfully showeth that:
We register our strongest protest at the decision by the French Government to resume nuclear testing in the South Pacific.
The decision to resume testing is without regard to strident opposition from not only the people and nations of the South Pacific, but also many other countries around the world.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Election Campaign
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain residents of the State of Queensland draws to the attention of the Senate the recent election to the House of Representatives of Members who during their election campaign, openly manipulated racist sentiments against and about the Aboriginal Peoples of Australia as a means to gain office in the national Parliament.

Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate to publicly condemn the use of racial attacks by candidates or political parties in federal elections, and to call upon all parliamentarians to represent all of their constituents without racial discrimination, fear or favour, and to establish and enforce a code of race ethics to be observed by parliamentarians as national representatives of the citizens of Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Election Campaign
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned shows: That the printing and distribution of `How to Vote' Cards on Polling Day in State and Commonwealth Elections is extremely wasteful as the distribution of approximately 40 million pieces of paper during the last Federal Election indicates.

Your Petitioners request that the Senate should: Enact legislation to stop the use of `How to Vote Cards' at Commonwealth elections and that it should prevail on all State Governments in Australia to pass similar legislation for State elections.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned shows:
"That same sex defacto relationships are not recognised under superannuation schemes, funds and associated legislation across Australia."
Your Petitioners request that the senate should:

In view of the current Federal Government's Superannuation Guarantee Charge seek recognition of same sex defacto relationships under Superannuation Schemes, funds and associated legislation across Australia, so that all Australians are ensured of equality of access to all superannuation benefits.

PETITION.TITLE: Religion and Democracy in Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned requests:
(i) that those of religious conviction who have contributed to the development of Australia should be recognised in the study of Australian history to ensure that a balanced history is taught;
(ii) that any syllabus prepared on the teaching of Civics and Citizenship should include the contribution of people of religious conviction highlighting their religious motivation;
(iii) that funds be allocated to ensure that teachers are given in‐service training on their role of religious influences in the development of Australian democracy; and
(iv) that materials are produced to support the above for use in the classroom.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Margetts moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely, a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 19.
This debate is urgent today. We have seen there are advantages in using an existing structure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, so as not to waste time I point out that we are not objecting to the suspension of standing orders.
—That is not a point of order but it is information. Did you hear that, Senator Margetts?

—With the agreement of the Senate, I am happy to proceed to the substantive debate. I wish that general business notice of motion No. 19 be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business—
—Senator, we are still on the suspension motion you moved earlier. We will have to deal with that first and foremost.
—The move to suspend standing orders to reappoint the Select Committee on the Dangers of Radioactive Waste and to extend it terms of reference—

—I was given to understand that you wanted to move the suspension immediately so I was going to speak briefly to that, but if you are going to speak to it I have lost my ability to speak.

Clearly, any senator in this chamber, up to a limit of six if all use the available time limit—in fact, without sessional orders applying perhaps there are different procedures in place—has a capacity to address this motion to suspend standing orders, including Senator Margetts, Senator Parer, Senator Panizza or anyone else. While it is interesting to know how various parties and senators in this chamber are going to vote, it is merely no more than an indication of your views for any likely division or likely vote in this chamber.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: I submit to you that Senator Faulkner in this instance is quite correct. Senator Panizza has indicated, for the benefit of Senator Margetts, that the coalition—the government—will support the suspension. Nevertheless, if she still wants to put her case for the suspension, she is quite entitled to do so. We will respond, through Senator Parer, and tell the reasons why we will agree to the suspension.

—Thank you, Senator Hill, for your assistance in determining the point of order. I do uphold the point of order that Senator Faulkner took. I probably should express gratitude to Senator Panizza for putting the chamber into a state of some confusion. Rather than ruling, I will give some advice to Senator Margetts. You have moved for the suspension of standing orders; you have a right to speak to that motion for suspension of standing orders. With Senator Panizza's intervention, you sought, as I understand it, to bring that decision forward. Some confusion was further caused when Senator Parer stood to his feet. I give you the opportunity now to speak to your motion to suspend standing orders if you so choose to exercise your right to do so.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President, and I thank the Senate. I will not speak long. This is a moment of opportunity for us as a Senate to put forward a proposal to advance the cause of public information in relation to the uranium debate. There is an opportunity at the moment, in the existing committee structure, to use the Select Committee on the Dangers of Radioactive Waste, although it has officially dissolved. There is an expertise within that committee and an expertise within its secretariat which I believe are useful. We also have the opportunity to use that.

SPEECH.PARA: The new government has already made an announcement about its decision to open up uranium mining. Therefore, the time is right to bring information together for the public interest and for public debate. There are limitations on public input via the environmental impact statements. They relate to what is and what is not available to be mentioned on an environmental impact statement. What is not available to be used is the history of the last 20 years within the industry. It is therefore well overdue.

The Fox inquiry, which was not a parliamentary inquiry, was held nearly 20 years ago. It may have been excellent for the time but it was limited. We now have 20 years of experience to match up the expectations of the time with the realities. I therefore seek the support of the Senate for both the suspension of standing orders and for the substantive motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the select committee known as the Select Committee on the Dangers of Radioactive Waste, appointed by resolution of the Senate on 9 March 1995, be reappointed, with the same functions and powers, except as otherwise provided in this resolution.
(2) That the committee be known as the Select Committee on Uranium Mining and Milling.

(3) That the committee inquire into and report on the environmental impact, health and safety and other implications and effectiveness of security agreements in relation to the mining, milling and export of Australian uranium.
(4) That in considering these terms of reference the committee is to take into account, and where necessary report on, the following issues:

PARA.TAB: (a) the environmental impact of uranium mining and milling in Australia and the effectiveness of environmental protection and monitoring in relation to existing and previous Australian uranium mining operations;
(b) the role of the Office of the Supervising Scientist in monitoring Australian uranium mining and milling activities;
(c) the health and safety implications of uranium mining and milling for workers at mining and milling sites and workers involved in the transport and handling of uranium and uranium waste;

(d) the health, safety and other effects of uranium mining and milling on communities adjacent to mine and mill sites and communities on existing or planned transport routes for uranium ore and uranium waste;

(e) the effectiveness of Australia's bilateral agreements with countries importing Australian uranium, in ensuring that Australian‐sourced uranium is not used in military nuclear technology or nuclear weapons testing activities; and

(f) the volume and location of Australian‐obligated plutonium currently in existence in the international nuclear fuel cycle (produced as a result of the use of Australian uranium), in what form it exists (for example, separated or in spent nuclear fuel), and its intended end use.

SPEECH.PARA: (5) That the committee have the power to consider and use for its purposes the minutes of evidence and records of the Select Committee on the Dangers of Radioactive Waste appointed in the previous Parliament.
(6) That the committee consist of seven senators:

PARA.TAB: (a) three nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b) two nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate;
(c) one nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats; and
(d) one nominated by the Greens (WA) or Independent Senators.

SPEECH.PARA: (7) That the chair of the committee be elected by the members of the committee.

(8) That the quorum of the committee be three members with one representing the Government, one representing the Opposition and one representing either the Australian Democrats, the Greens (WA) or Independent Senators.
(9) That the chair is authorised to make statements to the media on behalf of the committee concerning its activities, without disclosing confidential proceedings of the committee.
(10) That each statement to the committee by a person in relation to the inquiry be published only after a resolution to that effect by the committee.
(11) That the committee report to the Senate on or before the last day of sitting of 1996.

Whilst I mentioned that there was an excellent inquiry around 20 years ago, namely the Fox inquiry, and that there is to be an environmental impact statement on the first cab off the rank in relation to uranium mining—the Kakadu mining proposal—there is a limitation in both the process used and breadth of the coverage of such inquiries. The Fox inquiry originally looked at the Alligator Rivers region. Two reports resulted. They looked carefully at the implications of uranium mining as they were seen at that time.

It is worth mentioning that the proposals for the Office of the Supervising Scientist were, contrary to many people's belief, never set up to protect the environment from radioactive waste. The Office of the Supervising Scientist, from reading about that inquiry, was there to monitor the dispersal of radioactive waste from uranium mining at a regulated pace. That is, it was always assumed that there would be radio toxins leaking into the environment. The assumption that radio toxins in the environment were safe was the basis of that decision.

Therefore, whilst some people would argue, and have argued in the past, that the very position of the Office of the Supervising Scientist is a safeguard of the health of, and the environment for, workers and the community, it is very clear right from the very beginning that it was never set up to be a safeguard for the community from the radio toxins in air and water.

Let us face it: in Western Australia there is a list of over 14 proposed or prospective uranium mines and I believe in other states there would be a considerable list to add to that. The breadth of an environmental impact statement for any new proposal, whether it is Kakadu or any other proposed uranium mine in Australia—which, of course, is a useful thing to do—has limitations because each environmental impact statement can only look at the proposal as put forward by the proponent. So if the proponent says, `We will maintain the highest levels of environmental safety and standards,' then it is a bit like a court. You cannot necessarily then go back and say, `Well, in the past people have said similar things and they just have not been able to come up to scratch,' or, `This is the way it has worked over history, these are the licensed conditions under which other mines have operated and this has been the outcome.'

There are many other issues involved in relation to uranium mining, of course. We know the concern within the Australian community in relation to French nuclear testing. We know that there were statements made by the French government at the time that Australia was being naive to hide behind assurances in relation to the security arrangements for the nuclear non‐proliferation treaty in relation to the use of Australian uranium. That is, they admitted to us publicly—as have Australian government officials in inquiries—that there is no way of guaranteeing that Australian uranium is not used in the nuclear weapon cycle.

BREAK.PARA: There are security implications not just for our present uranium exports but for any increase that may be based on the current increase in price in uranium oxide ore. The reason is that if people are seeking markets there is an extra problem in that, in areas where in the past we might have been very circumspect in arranging sales and exports, there may well be the temptation to get into markets that we would never have touched for security reasons before. The more uranium mines that open in Australia, if we find that a number of those uranium mines are marginal—depending on what happens to the price and depending on how much uranium there is on the market—then there is the temptation to maintain that structure. Once the status quo has been established, the temptation is to get into markets or to promote markets that normally you would not touch with a barge pole.

We are especially concerned about regional security implications. We pointed a finger at China. Everybody was concerned about Chinese nuclear testing and the fact that the Chinese government has not yet promised to suspend their nuclear weapons testing program, but it is rather hypocritical of Australia and the Australian parliament to point the finger at China and say, `You must not continue your nuclear testing,' if we are prepared to export uranium to South Korea, Japan and to other countries in the region which might create concern for countries like China.

China joined with the countries of the world in assisting to defuse the dangerous situation that was developing with worldwide pressure on North Korea. It always seems strange to me that the pressure was on North Korea in relation to the build‐up of nuclear materials and not on Japan. However, that is what the western world community decided to do: they would concentrate on North Korea. It was a very tricky situation and China joined with the world community.

PARA.BREAK: China, if you like, was the most important factor there. They joined with the world community to convince North Korea to accept the compromise positions and to accept funding to change their nuclear power pro gram to a different method which does not produce the same enriched materials. But if we are expecting China to participate in that kind of strategy now and in the future, then it is hardly the right thing for Australia to do to be negotiating prospective contracts for uranium sales to South Korea.

TALK.START.PARA: —We already do it for power generation.
—Certainly we are already doing it, but we are heading into a situation where there is—
—You are not apologising for China's weapons testing, are you?

—Absolutely not. Senator Cook asks whether I am apologising for China's weapons testing. Absolutely not. What I am pointing out is the sheer hypocrisy of any parliament pointing the finger at China and at the same time being prepared to supply nuclear materials to South Korea. As I said, even France admitted that they had no way of guaranteeing that Australian uranium was not going into their weapons program because you cannot determine what is an Australian uranium atom compared with what is a uranium atom supplied by another country which has not signed the nuclear non‐proliferation treaty.

BREAK.PARA: Therefore, if Australia provides uranium to countries which have or are developing a nuclear weapons program and if other countries are also supplying uranium to the same country, then all it means is that there is an increased pool of uranium. There is no way that you can guarantee where the Australian atom is going. All there is is an accounting procedure which says that a certain amount of uranium comes in, a certain amount of uranium goes out. Therefore, the assurances are nonsense.

The broader implications of uranium mining on local communities have been of great concern. It is not just the implications on local communities' environmental health and safety and the issues of the control of land and land use. That is extremely important and obviously extremely important for indigenous communities in Australia.

It is not just about the situation of local communities in and around uranium mining and milling. It is about communities on transport routes. It is about communities living around ports. I am sure that, if the Yeelirie mine were to go ahead, the people of Esperance in Western Australia would be appalled at the prospect of being a port for the export of uranium. I am not sure that the people of Port Hedland in Western Australia would be terribly thrilled about the prospect of being a uranium export port for the Kintyre deposit. As I mentioned before, there are around 14 prospective uranium mines in Western Australia and some that do not even have a name yet.

The committee that I mentioned—that is, the Senate Select Committee on Radioactive Waste—has already looked at some aspects of the effectiveness of waste management. But, so far, that committee has not had the chance to look at the impacts of radioactive waste management from uranium mining because, by the choice of this chamber, that was excluded from the terms of reference. That always was an anomaly of the original inquiry and that is why it is important that we now address the problems, if they exist, in relation to the handling and storage of radioactive waste from uranium mining.

There are social impacts of uranium mining—and this has been mentioned by the coalition. In many instances, they have emphasised the economic benefits for communities. If people want to argue for the economic benefits, perhaps this is the opportunity when they can put those ideas forward and others can talk about the counter argument. If there are economic benefits, there may well be social and environmental costs, and even economic costs if one activity precludes others. It is the time to put those ideas on the record. It is also the time, with a secretive industry, to ask the questions which for so long have been denied.

There is the ongoing argument about mining in national parks. Contrary to Senator Parer's assumptions earlier, the Greens have always talked about the values in mining. The Greens do not have a no‐mining policy. The Greens have a policy in relation to the social and environmental impacts of mining. That has been the approach we have always taken. Therefore, if you are going to look at the environmental values—whether they are World Heritage values, national park values or the impact of environmental pollution—this is the time to bring that information together. That information should be not just from one mine, but from all the experiences that are occurring. Either the mines that have operated in Australia or examples from the various proposed mines in Australia should enable that information about the possible impacts of mining national parks to be brought forward.

I will not speak for long because many of these kinds of issues have been canvassed in the public arena. I strongly urge the Senate to support this inquiry. It certainly is timely for it to take place. I believe the community expects that any new decisions in relation to such an important issue are looked at carefully, and are seen to be looked at carefully, in a process that involves people. The environmental impact process is one where people can have an input; they can put in a submission. But, often, it is a case of a lot of people putting in a submission and the decision, as originally stated, still going ahead. There might be some variations, but it does not give people the chance to have a two‐way process with the parliamentary system.

This is the important thing that we are asking for now: firstly, that there is the opportunity to bring that information together; to be able to ask those questions of the bodies who have been involved with uranium mining for so many years and to have those questions put on the public record; and then for the chance to test all of those assumptions and statements that have been made in the past about uranium mining. It is important to have those questions put on the public record, and it is important that those statements have a chance to be aired. I therefore strongly urge support of this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated earlier, there were two notices of motion put before the Senate. One was from Senator Margetts which, as I indicated, was to some degree understandable. The other one was put by the government. I must say I could not help but be amused—
—You're the government now!
—By the opposition—thank you. Senator Faulkner, who moved the second notice of motion—
—I know it's hard to believe.

—I might tell you that mistake has been made on both sides in the past couple of days. But Senator Faulkner seems to be struck with what I would call a bad case of selective amnesia. He would be aware that many of his ALP colleagues have different positions in respect of uranium mining. It just shows the longstanding hypocrisy of the Labor Party on the issue of uranium.

SPEECH.PARA: We had this incredible situation where the Labor Party had a so‐called three‐mine policy. In other words, some uranium was good uranium, whereas uranium from other areas was bad uranium. Then we had the position where one of the mines closed, so we did not have a three‐mine policy at all; we had a two‐mine policy. Nabarlek extracted ore for about five or six months, processed ore for about nine or 10 years and currently has been rehabilitated.

Then the Labor Party bent its own so‐called rules and allowed the development of Olympic Dam, because politically it suited them with the then Labor Party government in South Australia. I thought it might be worth quoting from the ALP policy on uranium mining. What it says is—

TALK.START.PARA: —What's your policy? You're the government.
—You know our policy; we have made it very clear. The ALP policy says:

SPEECH.PARA: The alternate sources of supply of uranium are available to the world's nuclear power industry, including some which are subject to less stringent nuclear safeguard conditions—
That means less stringent than from Australia. It goes on to say:

For the time being at least, Australia's ability to contribute to the reduction of those risks and hazards will be enhanced if Australia continues to participate as a uranium exporter in the nuclear cycle, but only on the terms and conditions set out below.

This was all to do with nuclear safeguards and the absolutely ludicrous three‐mine policy. Of interest, too, were the remarks made by Senator Collins, who was the minister. In July 1994, less than two years ago, the Age reported :
Senator Collins, an advocate of changing the `three mines' policy said, `My position is that we should either be in the uranium business or not be in it.'

I know the Greens' view is that we should not be in it at all. That is clear. It is their view on most mining operations, but they have a particular passion about uranium. But the Labor Party's view is total and utter hypocrisy. Senator Collins also went on to say:

. . . Bob Collins, a NT Senator, has the backing of Aboriginal custodians of the Kakadu region who want the Koongarra uranium deposit to be mined, to create jobs for their people. Despite uranium's low price—
at that time—
Senator Collins also wants the 180,000‐tonne Jabiluka prospect, 18 km north of Ranger, developed because of its potential to generate $6.3 billion in sales . . .

That is, to address our current account deficit and our foreign debt. Of course, who created that foreign debt? The Labor Party. In their 13 years in government, they did not address it. You come in here and have a `me too' policy with the Greens, whose policy we understand, but yours is utter and total hypocrisy. On 30 September 1994, Senator Collins said:
"I have to be honest—
That is a change—not for Senator Collins, but for the Labor Party—

. . . as the Minister responsible I had a real good push at getting the industry expanded and I lost," Senator Collins said last night. "I am disappointed in the result and I am feeling a little bruised and battered from it." He said the Conference decision to send the issue back to the ALP uranium policy review committee was "like returning to the past."
What about Senator Faulkner's notice of motion? He is returning to the past. There is a whole range of other quotes from Senator Collins on this particular matter.

BREAK.PARA: Let us talk about the Premier of Western Australia at the time, Miss Carmen Lawrence.

TALK.START.PARA: —`Doctor' actually.

—Dr Carmen Lawrence. Thank you, Senator Faulkner. She needs something. This is where we had this marvellous contradiction within the Labor Party. Reported in the Sunday Times on 7 April 1991, Dr Lawrence gave her resolve that there would be no uranium mining in Western Australia while she was premier. That is good, clear, direct stuff. But guess what? In the Western Australian Hansard of 18 August 1993, when she was still Premier, her government excised the Kintyre deposit from the national park reserve.
—Why would they do that?

—Good question. Here we have them saying one thing publicly and then excising an area. I have no particular problem with that because I happen to believe that you can, in certain cases, have mining operations in national parks, provided it is done sensibly and is environmentally safe. But that shows the utter hypocrisy of that particular government.

BREAK.PARA: I would like to address some of the terms of reference. The reason that we really are not very keen on having this done is not because we are afraid of it. All the information is on the table. I heard Senator Margetts say, `We want this to be publicly exposed.' I do not know what information you will get from this committee that is not already on the table. You missed out, Senator Collins; I was quoting you.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I didn't, Senator Parer; I was hanging off every word on the monitor.

—Let me just go on further with some of the terms of reference. Uranium mining and milling has been conducted for 16 years in the Alligator River regions in the Northern Territory and for eight years in the Olympic Dam area in South Australia with no significant effects on the environment. Senator Margetts said the office of the—
—Who said that?

—I will come to that. Senator Margetts said that the Office of the Supervising Scientist was there really not to care for the environment. That is patently not true. If you go to Ranger, and you should go to Ranger, you will find you have a total work force in Ranger of about 200 people. Of that 200 who work for that particular company, 30 people are involved specifically in environmental matters. In addition, there are 55 people from the Office of the Supervising Scientist measuring just about every effect of mining and milling that you could imagine, whether it be radon in the air or whatever you want to think about.

BREAK.PARA: The mine itself has won awards for its successful environmental management and for landcare research, and I do not think you would disagree with that. It is one of the best‐run mines in the world. I am not specifically supporting a particular mine; I am just giving you the facts as they occur in a mine that has been in operation for 16 years.

The Office of the Supervising Scientist has reported over the period, quite publicly—you can read the reports any time you like—on 46 incidents. If you read the report of the Office of the Supervising Scientist, you will find that in not one case, either individually or cumulatively, did those incidents have any effect on the environment. The sorts of things that occurred are the sorts of things that happen really in any industrial situation. I noticed in some of the discussions we had with some of the environmental groups that one of the things they talked about was a spillage of water. A spillage of water did occur. It was held within the bund wall, if you know what a bund wall is, and I am sure Senator Sherry knows what a bund wall is. But do you know how much water was actually released that caused the great furore? It was about half the size of a normal backyard swimming pool. That is the sort of thing you are talking about. This experience shows that uranium mining can be undertaken safely.

TALK.START.PARA: —Radioactive water!

—What an emotive statement from Senator Margetts—`radioactive water'. It had no effect on the environment whatsoever. Experience shows that mining can be undertaken safely, as with any mining operation. Any sort of operation, whether it be mining or industrial, has its particular hazards. In mines that have similar plant requirements, you need to manage mine and mill waste. We do not disagree with that. It has to be done in a proper way.

BREAK.PARA: Radiation hazards, of course, are relatively minor and not unique to the uranium industry. Another example, of course, is mineral sands, where you do have some radioactive content. The government has clearly stated that all proposals for new uranium mines will be subject to stringent and comprehensive environmental impact assessment processes. We have not budged one inch from that.

The government has also ensured that where projects are approved there are adequate measures in place for monitoring and reporting for the duration of the mine's operations. Clearly, we have the technology to conduct mining of uranium responsibly. I think that is shown by 16 years experience of very little impact.

Reference (b) of the terms of reference would examine the role of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. Senator Margetts, I do not know if you are aware just how many people from the Office of the Supervising Scientist are on the Ranger site. I mentioned there are 30 people within the work force of ERA concentrating entirely on environmental matters and another 55 people from the Office of the Supervising Scientist. They measure everything, as I indicated, even things like nuclides that are used for the filtration process through dam walls. Every single thing you can possibly imagine is being done by the Office of the Supervising Scientist.

The next terms of reference that Senator Margetts is proposing is again, I believe, a waste of resources. The health and safety implications of mining and milling uranium and transporting it are well understood. There is no need for a Senate select committee or anyone else to inquire further into these matters.

To give some perspective to the idea that people working and living near uranium mines will be exposed to radiation, all human beings are exposed to low levels of ionising radiation in Australia. AGSO actually surveys the whole of Australia with regard to its radiation levels. The whole country, to some degree, is radioactive. The exposure comes from traces of radioactive elements in rocks, soil, the roads you drive on and building materials.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bricks.

—Bricks—you are quite right, Senator—and cosmic rays and minute amounts of radioactive elements which are naturally present in our bodies. I am not saying you should not be stringent in everything you do, but there has to be a sense of balance in this.

BREAK.PARA: The typical dosage from this background radiation is two millisieverts per annum. Nevertheless, it is important to minimise the additional radiation received by the community and by people working in the industry. No disagreement there. The standards that apply to protect workers in Australia are based on internationally agreed approaches which have proven effective in protecting community health. As I mentioned earlier, uranium mining is really no more hazardous than any other mining.

I know this is an emotive issue. I do not disagree. It is emotive because people have abused what, I believe, is a gift to use something for the generation of power, but they have abused it by making bombs. We were most stringent in our opposition to the nuclear testing by the French in the Pacific. That is an abuse by humankind, if you prefer non-sexist language, of what is used in many parts of the world to help people improve their standards of living.

It should be pointed out that the Ranger uranium mine is the only mine in Australia with a five‐star safety rating from the National Safety Council. That is pretty impressive. You cannot walk away from that. Hazards are not unique to uranium and are effectively managed in all types of mining where radioactive materials are present in the ore body, and in certain industrial and medical operations. People often neglect the benefits because they talk about bombs a lot. They do not talk about the radioactive isotopes used within the medical profession which contribute to human health.

Health and safety requirements apply to all these activities and are based on internationally accepted codes of practice. For example, public and occupational radiation dose limits were recommended by the International Commission on Radiological Protection and published in 1991—that is, ICRP 60. These new lower dose limits were reduced from five to one millisieverts per annum and from 50 to 20 millisieverts over 50 years. The background figure, as I gave you before, is two. The new limits were jointly adopted as the voluntary Australian standard by the Australian National Health and Medical Research Council and the National Occupational Health and Safety Council in June 1995. Relevant state and territory regulations have been or are being updated to reflect those new standards. The Ranger and Olympic Dam mines are operating well within these limits and any new mines will also be required to operate within those limits.

Let me say more about the important issue of the health of uranium workers. While this is a matter that falls more within the health portfolio, I have sought advice on the current position in the context of my responsibilities for uranium mining. A national radiation dose registry is being established by the Australian Radiation Laboratory, ARL, as a national database of personal radiation dose records of all Australians occupationally exposed to external ionising radiation. This covers people working in the radiography fields across the board. This will provide from a single source a complete history of individual radiation exposure throughout the working life of individual workers.

Routine collection of data commenced in February 1996 and the system is due to be operational by July 1996. I understand that some privacy concerns have been raised and that these will be addressed in legislation being drawn up for the establishment of an Australian institute for radiation protection. So far as internal radiation exposure is concerned—that is, through inhalation—dose records are held by state authorities and employees. The ARL has requested dose records from state authorities and where these are not available for privacy reasons it will be necessary to negotiate with employers and employee organisations. I would like to emphasise that the current health and safety requirements relating to radiation exposure are based on internationally accepted codes of practice.

As regards the transport of nuclear materials, again, safe practices are well understood and recognised internationally. There is no need for concern for the health or safety of workers involved in such transport or for people who live near the routes along which the material will move. As an aside, for Senator Margetts's interest, in the first 10 years of my working life I worked with X-rays and radioactive isotopes in the industrial field. We were very conscious of the health effects but nothing like we are today. That was over 20 years ago. I believe people were very aware of the fact that one had to take very careful safety precautions.

As regards bilateral safeguard agreements—the opposition cannot disagree with this because it was instrumental in putting some of these into place—why inquire into their effectiveness? They are on the table and everyone knows about them. They are clear for everyone to see. There is not a shred of evidence to suggest that any Australian nuclear material and material derived from it covered by such an agreement has ever been diverted away from peaceful non‐explosive purposes. I have heard the opposition say that over and over again. If my memory is correct, I think it was repeated ad nauseam by former Senator Gareth Evans when he was in this place.

Our safeguard agreements are the most stringent in the world. No other country has as exacting a set of requirements. Hence the ALP's policy. As we have such stringent agreements, we should encourage the export of uranium because we know what it is being used for. Australia has 14 such agreements covering AONM in 24 countries. Each is a treaty level document with the recipient country giving guarantees about AONM within its borders and in transit.

The starting point for our safeguard agreements is careful selection of countries with which we trade uranium. Countries which are not nuclear weapon states must be members of the nuclear non‐proliferation treaty and subject to NPT full‐scope safeguards. That is, IAEA safeguards apply to all existing and future activities. Nuclear weapon states with which we trade uranium, that is the United States, France and the United Kingdom, must give a treaty level assurance that AONM will be used only for peaceful purposes and must have arrangements in place for AONM to be covered by IAEA safeguards.

Our bilateral safeguard agreements contain the following main conditions. The AONM can be used only for peaceful purposes and IAEA safeguards will apply. None of the following can occur without Australia's prior consent: transfer to AONM third parties; enrichment to 20 per cent or more in the uranium 235 isotope; or reprocessing. Adequate physical security will be applied to AONM in the country concerned and detailed arrangements will be established setting out the procedures that will apply in both countries to account for AONM.

I will provide just a little detail on these accounting arrangements administered by Australia by the safeguards office. In each customer country, ASO's counterpart organisations ensure that detailed records are maintained, that there are regular reports to ASO and that transfer and receipt documentation for AONM is provided. The ASO's accounting is based on those reports and documentation plus calculations of process losses and nuclear consumption.

Senator Margetts suggests that the committee inquire into the volume and location of Australian obligated plutonium currently in existence. `What form is it in?', asks Senator Margetts. She makes it sound as if there is some sort of big secret—that it is hidden, that the Australian government does not know about or must be hiding this information about plutonium. When she gives that implication it is not just about this government but about the past government. That is absolute paranoia. It is just not true. If you want your question about plutonium answered, all you have to do is read the annual report of the director of safeguards. It is all there, tabled in this place and publicly available. I do not understand the whole point of the exercise. The information you claim to be seeking is already publicly available.

Let me tell you what the last report says about our obligated plutonium. It tells how much is irradiated plutonium—that is, spent fuel—and how much is separated. It tells what countries the material is in. We know what its end use will be: it can be used only for peaceful purposes—for power generation—because that is what Australia's safeguard agreements and the IAEA safeguards system guarantee. So all Senator Margett's questions about plutonium are answered every year by the director of safeguards. I do not think anyone questions the integrity of the director of safeguards.
Let me just make the following points in conclusion. I know what Senator Margetts is doing. She is playing to a little constituency out there.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's what we all do, Warwick.

—I think, Senator Collins, that with the passage of time you will learn that this government is made up of statesmen. I know it will be hard to come to grips with. What you are doing is pursuing something in an emotional way, and not in a balanced way, which I believe is to the disadvantage of this country. Senator Collins has just left now. I think he agrees with me, in view of his past remarks.
—He should speak.
—I was hoping he would come in and speak.
—You've got me.

—It would be fascinating to hear what Senator Faulkner has to say in view of all that he has done in the past. Senator Margetts has an ideological hang‐up that lacks balance. These mines generate wealth in a safe way. It is essential that we care for the environment and meet social needs.

BREAK.PARA: For example, in the last 10 years something like $115 million went to the Aboriginal people from the Ranger mine alone. When I was up there I spoke to a number of the traditional owners and they were very supportive of these mines. One of the reasons they were supportive is that the mines provide infrastructure that would not normally be provided. Out of that infrastructure, they get roads and they develop their own tourism industry. If you go up to Jabiru you will see a magnificent motel owned by the Aboriginal groups which, as they told me, would not be there if it was not for the Ranger mine.

I also make the point that these mines have a relatively short life and they cover a very tiny area. I know the pickies on television may not show that, but, if you look at the amount of material moved in one year by the Ranger mine, it is about 100,000 tonnes. Compare that with one of the open‐cut coalmines in the Bowen basin. One of those mines moves that amount of material in two days. That gives you an idea of the size. The mines are relatively small. They do not cover a big area.

Let me just conclude by saying this. I think this is where we need a sense of realism in the whole picture. As I indicated, we have no problems with extending the inquiry because most of the information is already known anyway. The inquiry will just reinforce what I have been saying. Uranium is a source of power, and a very important source, especially if you have a power station in a country where you do not have indigenous reserves of other energy materials. To give you an idea of volumes, 2,000 tonnes of uranium is equal to 32 million tonnes of coal.

There are already over 450 nuclear power stations around the world, with more being constructed, notwithstanding the fact that people say they are not. Those nuclear power stations supply 17 per cent of the world's power. Nuclear power, by its very nature, requires stringent safeguards. No-one disagrees with that. The benefit of nuclear power is that there are no greenhouse gas emissions, no CO2. That is why the French—who we criticise for letting off bombs in the Pacific and who generate 80 per cent of electricity by nuclear power—are in a position to take a very high moral ground in regard to greenhouse gas emissions. They sell their nuclear power into adjoining countries who will not put in nuclear power stations. There is some irony in that.

Australia has around 30 per cent of the world's economically recoverable reserves. We do not have the lot, but we do have 30 per cent and we supply about 10 per cent of the market. Canada, by comparison, has 10 per cent of the reserves and supplies 30 per cent of the market. This has occurred because of this ludicrous ALP three mines policy. I know that the Greens say, `Let's supply zero.' That would not affect one iota the number of nuclear power stations generating electricity around the world or the growth of that. There are lots of other sources. That in itself is not just a reason for going ahead, but I think I have made the point that it is no different to any other mining. They are relatively small mines and it can be done safely.

There is a window of opportunity to increase our sales under stringent safeguards from around $250 million a year to $1.2 billion by the year 2002. This came out from an Access Economics report printed last year. That is not insignificant in addressing our current account deficit and foreign debt.

The coalition has not varied its position in respect of uranium mining. We have taken the view that we would abandon the ludicrous ALP policy. We have already announced that. Our policy has not changed, but we have changed the previous government's policy. It will be done under stringent safeguards. Proper EISs will be carried out and the uranium itself will only be used to generate electricity for peaceful purposes. We understand that the government does not have the numbers in regard to this particular motion so, inevitably, we also understand that the select committee will continue its work with the enlarged terms of reference suggested by Senator Margetts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The continuing policy of the Labor Party is that no new uranium mines should be allowed to open. There is a very clear difference between ourselves and the government on this particular issue, one that was the subject of considerable debate during the recent election campaign. This policy that the former Labor government had meant that a significant number of new uranium mines in this country were prevented from opening. That included potential uranium mines in the Kakadu National Park, a World Heritage area. The government's position—very eloquently put by Senator Parer, at extraordinary length but, as he said, what do you expect from a statesman—is simply open slather uranium mining in this country. It is a position that we do not and will not accept.

SPEECH.PARA: I join with other senators in the chamber who have expressed very great concern about the health hazards of uranium. Uranium ore has a low level of radioactivity. Although contaminants are always present, the dangers to workers in this particular industry come mainly from dust and radon gas and can be accumulated in the lungs. Radioactive materials escaping from mines, tailings dumps, spills or wastes can certainly accumulate markedly through the food chain and endanger both wildlife and humans.

The position that the opposition has taken in relation to this particular inquiry is that we believe it ought to be targeted to that area which is being very closely examined right now by the new government to open uranium mines, particularly in the Kakadu World Heritage area. The new government is committed to moving helter‐skelter to open uranium mines in the environs of Kakadu National Park. That is a very great concern not only to the opposition but also to many people in the Australian community. Let us put it clearly on the record again: the opposition absolutely totally opposes any plans to open any uranium mines and we are particularly concerned about mines in the environs of Kakadu.

We had a very fine record in government in terms of our commitment to protecting the values of World Heritage areas in this country. This proposal to open mines near Kakadu completely violates the principle of World Heritage protection. As far as the new government is concerned, it is a very clear indicator of their lack of commitment to the protection of the environment in this country.

The comparison between the previous Labor administration and the new coalition government on this issue is very obvious. We went to great lengths to protect World Heritage areas. We opposed the opening of any new uranium mines in this country and we are happy to work with others in the community to ensure that no uranium mines are opened in this country.

I know that Australian environment groups have called for a full public inquiry under section 11 of the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act in relation to uranium mining in Kakadu. Senator Hill has rejected that on behalf of the government but Kakadu deserves the highest level of protection and warrants the closest possible scrutiny in relation to the Jabiluka and Koongarra proposals.

That particular focus is an important one for the Senate to reflect upon as it determines to establish this particular select committee. For that reason, I move the following amendment to Senator Margetts's motion:
At the end of paragraph (3) add the following words "with particular emphasis on the impacts of uranium mining in and around the Kakadu World Heritage area".

I believe that the preferred option put forward by the opposition—a tightly focused, targeted Senate inquiry—could get to the heart of the key issue, the issue that is right up there in the public mind and right at the top of the government's agenda, which is to expand the Ranger uranium mine. That would be the most sensible thing that the Senate could do. The Senate would need to consider seriously the alternative proposition to a more targeted and focused inquiry because it would have much more bearing and influence on the approval process for that mine at Jabiluka. That would have been the most effective approach for the Senate to take.

PARA.BREAK: We have a situation where the Liberal government is clearly indicating that it will take less account of and be less concerned with an adequate level of environmental scrutiny for proposals than the previous Labor government. That adds weight to the argu ment that a focused Senate inquiry is the way to go.

SPEECH.PARA: A very broad‐ranging inquiry dealing with all the issues that Senator Margetts has addressed in her motion and in her contribution in this chamber would be a very useful addition to the debate on these issues in this country. But I would not want to see that mean that we could not concentrate on the real agenda of the new government. We genuinely believe that a broad‐ranging Senate inquiry is a risk because on the line at the moment is uranium mining and its impact in and around the Kakadu World Heritage area. That is top of the pops with the government. That is what the government wants to do.

I do not want to be part of any process, be it a Senate process or otherwise, that will in any way assist the government in the clear objective that it has been very willing and happy to state time and time again and has made clear again today. I suggest to senators in the chamber that the amendment I have moved is a sensible and constructive one and is likely to have a very positive impact. It certainly embraces the approach that the opposition has taken because of our concern with the way the government is tripping over itself to open up these uranium mines near Kakadu. I think the amendment is worthy of support.

As I have indicated many times in this chamber, the Labor Party does not fall over itself to support either new committee references or the establishment of new select committees. Obviously, we need to be able to look at proposed terms of reference and to ensure that the Senate's resources and energies are best directed to those key issues of public policy that senators have a responsibility to address.

We see the urgency in relation to Jabiluka. I accept many of the arguments that have been put forward by my colleague Senator Margetts in relation to her concerns with that proposed uranium mine. I commend this amendment to the chamber. I understand that the substantive motion will be agreed by the Senate. It is not the opposition's intention to oppose this committee reference but we are keen to ensure that the work of the Senate is well directed, well focused, well targeted and most effective in derailing the outrageous plans of the new Liberal government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to spend a lot of time looking at the issues which I believe the Select Committee on the Impacts of Uranium Mining and Milling in Kakadu National Park will be inquiring into, but I do want to pick up on a couple of points that the minister has raised. I would like to begin with a comment about the committee itself, the committee that is just about to lapse and which we are trying, before it is too late, to see continue. This committee has not had any opportunity to look at this issue before. As my colleague Senator Bell has said time and time again, it really did need this additional reference. It was deliberately omitted, apparently. But it is a natural derivative to now move on and have what is really the rest of the inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: Another issue Senator Parer raised was in regard to the traditional owners being supportive. A couple of weeks ago I also spent some time in Kakadu meeting with some traditional owners and with a range of different people. I know there are a few traditional owners who are still supportive, but I was not able to meet any of those particular people. The people I spoke to raised a wide range of concerns about what is now happening at Ranger.

Yes, they are obviously benefiting. The Aboriginal people are seeing a small amount—a very small amount—of the profits flowing in their direction. But, unfortunately, that money is going into services that the rest of us take for granted. For example, that money is going into providing a health service, a health service which really should have been provided by the former Commonwealth government; it is also going into providing services—the infrastructure—which one would have expected the Northern Territory government should have put in place.

So, rather than really enjoying what are the fruits of their land, they are in many cases forced to spend this money in areas that will at least guarantee them some housing, although not adequate housing by any standards. Indeed, some of them are living in appalling conditions, and the public housing possibilities in the Northern Territory are so limited that that is where some of the money is going.

Yes, it has gone into tourist ventures but, as they have explained to me, that is also to get profits to spend on basic infrastructure and services that most people in Australia are able to tap into through either federal or state programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —And jobs, too.

—The jobs issue is an absolute furphy. I am pleased Senator Parer noted that there are some 200 people employed at Ranger. Only about 10 of those are Aboriginal people and only two or three of them are local Aboriginal people. As for the jobs that are available in the two major tourist ventures that they operate, again, there are a few jobs, but unfortunately they are very low paid intensive jobs—for instance, in the laundry. Indeed, one of the key traditional owners, a senior member of the local people, who will be making one of the major decisions on Jabiluka, works in the laundry. I believe those jobs could be far better allocated or open to Aboriginal people than they are at the moment. Of course, they are pleased for any jobs that they are able to access, but it is still—
—But they own it.
—They own the motel.

—The motel is actually partly managed by Aboriginal people; they own the motel. But, unfortunately, the job opportunities have not flowed to the extent that many of the local people had hoped they would. So, to say that the Aboriginal people are benefiting in some additional way from the extra royalties that are flowing, beyond the standard of living the rest of us enjoy, is not correct.

SPEECH.PARA: To move on to a couple of other issues, I make a general comment on the fact that the government would like to push this aside as being a not terribly important environment issue. I am sure the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) would recognise that, for the environment movement, this is one of the key issues. For him to say, `Don't you worry about that; we will have an inquiry; everything will be fine' and simply to push ahead, basically already agreeing that North Ranger will go ahead, leaves many questions unanswered.

I am pleased to hear that the government is in fact going to support this motion. The minister had been assuring us that all was well, but he really did run out of excuses for not supporting this. We have to have an open, thorough and public look at what is actually happening now.

This brings me to one of the concerns that I will raise today and that is the release of contaminated water—whether it is accidental or intentional. I do not believe it is reasonable to push this aside as being something that does not matter terribly much. In particular, I do not believe it is reasonable to suggest that the long‐term effects are negligible when we simply do not know. The Office of the Supervising Scientist, for all the work that it is doing, is doing virtually nothing to look at the health of the local people and the impact of their exposure in this area.

In particular, I refer to what has been happening as far as the mobilisation of water off the Ranger site is concerned. As we know, that is a high rainfall area, as is the area where Nabarlek was, as is the area where Jabiluka and Koongarra are. That presents us with a whole range of very specific problems. The tailings from uranium extraction contain more than 70 per cent of the radioactivity of the original ore. We simply cannot suggest that a small leakage is basically nothing when we may be talking about very highly concentrated leakages of water, as happened at Nabarlek where some five kilos of tailings slurry sprayed well outside the restricted release zone. We simply cannot push it aside and say, `Sorry, we are not really going to worry about that.'

During 1995 there was a very heavy wet season. This was one of the first issues that was raised with me when I was talking to the traditional owners and to other people up there. The Aboriginal people had always believed, when they agreed to Ranger, that they would be involved in the processes of making decisions that were going to affect the environment. But they were not consulted. Ranger applied to release the water from retention pond No. 2 and it would have gone out into the Magela Creek system.

The traditional owners had to fight this all the way. They eventually ended up in the Northern Territory Supreme Court, which heard the matter on 16 March. Unfortunately, there again, they lost. The wet season ended rather suddenly and the flow in Magela Creek reduced very rapidly. Eventually the Office of the Supervising Scientist said, `Alright, it is really getting too late in the season. There is not enough water; we won't release it.' That is the only thing that saved the Aboriginal people from having to put up with a substantial release of water, although I would argue any release of water would have been bad enough. It would have been a substantial release of water out into that wetland area.

This is one of the concerns that the traditional people raised with me when I was there. They are having no say in decisions that affect their environment. They were promised a say. They were supposed to be involved. They do not even have any regular contact with the Office of the Supervising Scientist. The occasional meeting and the occasional briefing are all too few and far between. So for the minister to suggest that traditional owners are in favour of this is simply not correct. They have many, many concerns about what is now happening at Ranger. To then suggest that they are going to agree with the new mine is a bit premature. The meetings are still going on. I believe it is going to take at least a month or so before any final decision is reached. Surely we at least owe them a thorough look at what is happening now and a look at all the plans for Jabiluka and particularly for Koongarra where most of the deposit is not only inside the national park outside the current lease area, but is also in the world heritage area. That presents a whole new range of problems.

I do not know whether the minister visited that particular art site while he was there. The site just near Koongarra is the only site that is accessible all year round. To have people visiting a world heritage area to look at traditional Aboriginal artwork within hearing of mining activities—Koongarra would be going ahead only a kilometre or two away, just over the nearby hill—will put at risk the tourism industry in the Northern Territory. As I say, it is the only all‐weather accessible art gallery. All the bus tour companies insist, when they come to the point of making travel arrangements, that their tourists visit that particular site. For most of the year, if you want to visit Aboriginal art you have to go there. While you talk about jobs in the mine, you may be looking at a loss of jobs and a loss of tourism opportunities in Kakadu. That is what the Aboriginal people are very concerned about.

This brings me to the opposition's amendment. I really do not think it is needed. If the opposition is very enthusiastic about just looking at Kakadu, they are quite able to encourage submissions on that issue from those people who are also concerned, including traditional owners. We could look at some of the findings of the Office of the Supervising Scientist and some of the concerns they have raised just as a start. If we begin to narrow down the reference to referring just to that particular area of the Northern Territory, we lose the opportunity to look in depth at issues in my home state and also in Western Australia.

Therefore, the Democrats will not be supporting the Opposition amendment, largely for the reasons that we did not support the Labor Party's motion in the first place. That was because we believe we need a far broader inquiry. We should not quarantine it. This amendment begins to bring it back into a fairly narrow area of just looking at the specific problems that we have at Ranger. Rather than go through what I could spend most of the day talking about—specific problems and some of the comments from the Office of the Supervising Scientist—I will finish here. I hope that we will see all parties in this chamber agreeing to this motion.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —The hypocrisy of the Australian Labor Party knows no bounds. What we hear from them today is astonishing.
—Even Senator Sherry is looking embarrassed about it.

—The Greens and the Australian Democrats have been consistent. They have consistently opposed uranium mining per se and they continue to do so. But the Labor Party, with its the policies of opportunism—
—I am looking at the superannuation committee report.

—Senator Sherry is embarrassed. He is hiding his face behind his papers, and so he should. For 13 years of government those opposite supported uranium mining in this country. For 13 years they supported the Ranger mine in the vicinity of Kakadu park. The Australian Labor Party supported it. They have had within their province the Office of the Supervising Scientist and all the environmental mechanisms to ensure that that mine would be operated safely and environmentally sensibly. Now, within a few days of being out of office, there is suddenly a revision of thought. It is time for the Senate to review the whole issue of uranium mining—the mining, the production, the export. `Let's consider it all again' says the ALP. It was embarrassing enough for the Labor Party when in government to have that nonsense three‐mine policy. What is it? Three mines—

—It turned out to be a two‐mine policy. I must say, for the benefit of the Labor Party, that they should visit the rehabilitation of the Narbalek site because it does seem to be proceeding extremely well. It goes on. Three big mines are worse than six small mines, or vice versa. It was a nonsense policy. Everyone knew it was. It was just political opportunism. Now it has been beaten by their new reflection upon coming to opposition that the whole issue of uranium should now be revisited. It is just astonishing that Senator Faulkner can stand in this place and put that argument today.
—He was blushing.

—I am not surprised. My colleague says that he was blushing. I am not surprised that he has left before the conclusion of the debate, because they have no credibility at all on this issue. Is an inquiry of this type necessary? We actually do not think it is.
—Why are you voting for it?

—Because in the 13 years that you were in government, you claimed that uranium mines can be operated safely and that exports can be controlled through the international mechanism and bilateral agreements. You said it to us for 13 years. Our position has been put very well by Senator Parer.
—You just contradicted him.

—Listen to my speech. There is an enormous amount on the public record now that can give us confidence that uranium mining can proceed safely and in an environmentally sound way. That has been the experience in this country. That has been the experience overseas. We have had the particular value of the Office of Supervising Scientist for so long now specifically monitoring the Ranger mine and also broadening our scientific knowledge generally in this area.

BREAK.PARA: That is why we start from the position today, which I have stated before outside this chamber, that we do not actually think that a new Fox‐type inquiry into the whole issue of uranium mining is really warranted. Nevertheless, we are also cognisant of the numbers in this place. We are not a majority. The majority in this place, with the Labor Party, now decides that it is time for a uranium mining inquiry. They have decided this is how they wish to spend Senate committee funds. I presume after this they will decide there is insufficient funding for an inquiry into the Victorian casino as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, we won't.

—You can't have them all. You have to make some choices and apparently you are choosing this as the priority. This is the first one, Senator Carr, that you have put on the Notice Paper . This is your first priority. But, as I said, the majority in this place clearly believes that this inquiry is worth while. We, as always, respect the view of the majority.

BREAK.PARA: Our policy is well known. It was taken to the people at the last election; it is clear and unambiguous. We believe in uranium mining as a legitimate activity to create wealth for the benefit of all Australians. But any uranium mining must go through a very strict and transparent set of tests before it will be approved.

Certainly, as I have said publicly—and I will repeat it here—those tests that I will apply as environment minister will include all my obligations under the environmental impact act and, in the cases where it is relevant, under the World Heritage Act, the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act, in fact, all pieces of Commonwealth legislation. If and when any particular application for a new uranium mine reaches my desk, those laws will be applied with all proper vigour. That is a responsibility that we obviously accept as a government because we are committed not only to further development in this country, particularly the creation of jobs that can come from further economic development, but also to environmentally responsible policies.

It was a major plank at the last election. We took it up-front. In fact, we have committed ourselves to establishing a $1 billion natural heritage trust for the benefit of the Australian environment. We will apply the environmental principles, as I said, with vigour. Notwithstanding the deliberations of the Senate and any outcomes that might come from this inquiry, the Australian people can also have the confidence that, in relation to any application that might reach us for a new uranium mine in this country, it will only be approved if it can be conducted in an environmentally safe way.

The question I want to ask is: why choose this particular committee and why choose this motion over the newly converted Labor Party's? It seems to us that this committee does have a track record. As was said by Senator Margetts, its secretariat is in place and it can be seen as an extension of its previous inquiry. That seems to us, therefore, to be the better of the two options that have been presented to us. Whilst we start from the position of believing that it is unnecessary, that there is sufficient material on the public record already for the Australian people to make judgments and to feel secure in these matters, nevertheless we accept the numbers in this place. We will give whatever support is necessary to ensure that the committee can carry out its functions in order to produce the best possible report for the benefit of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak briefly to the amendment moved by the opposition. The government will not support the opposition's amendment. I think it is an example of the utter hypocrisy of the Labor opposition in the Senate. As Senator Hill pointed out, for the past 13 years Ranger has operated under Labor governments. It has been defended, over the years, by people such as former senator, now member of the House of Representatives, Gareth Evans, in response to various questions raised by the Greens. I may be wrong. They had the opportunity over the past 13 years to do exactly what they are proposing today. One has to ask why they did not do it then. It is hypocrisy in the extreme.

SPEECH.PARA: In his response, Senator Faulkner talked about how good their policy was and how they were limiting it to three mines; in fact there are two mines. He did not say that recently, in the last year, they extended the operations at Olympic Dam. Again, I have no particular problem with that; in fact, I would support it. But, as Senator Hill said, they are saying it is all right to have two big mines but not three or four little mines. For that particular reason, and I simply base it on the hypocrisy of the Labor Party's position, we will not support this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I will briefly conclude this debate today. I would like to thank all of the senators who have contributed to the debate. There is obviously a great deal of community interest in the inquiry that will be set up as a result of today's vote. I am very pleased to see that there is now support from all parties in relation to this inquiry. It is extremely important that the inquiry takes place.

SPEECH.PARA: It is perfectly reasonable that the committee be able to set its agenda. If in the first instance there is a wealth of concern in relation to Kakadu, I am sure the committee will go to Kakadu and listen to those concerns. If necessary, and if there is a particular urgency, it can make a brief report to the Senate in relation to that urgency. That is always in there.

Whilst I thank the opposition for their proposed amendment, I believe that it would not be helpful in this debate. If we are talking about international security arrangements, we are not just talking about international security arrangements in relation to Kakadu. Therefore, the particular emphasis is redundant.

Kakadu is extremely important and I can guarantee that the Greens will fight tooth and nail in relation to that particular consideration. That does not mean to say that limiting the inquiry to specialise in Kakadu will be of major assistance in this regard. I believe that the general arguments ought to be put. Kakadu obviously will receive a great deal of attention by the community because of its symbolic nature. It is extremely important to the people of Australia.

I have to agree with Senator Parer that the decision to continue mining in that area has been with the previous government for so long. It is very nice to see that they have rediscovered this concern. However, creating a smokescreen on the general issue—that is, continuing or expanding uranium mining opportunities—is not helpful. There is nothing at all in the terms of reference which preclude the committee responding to the community's particular concerns. Therefore, whilst I thank the opposition for their support now for the general terms of reference, the WA Greens are unable to support their amendment.

I believe this is a very important day for the Australian environment movement, for the communities living in and around uranium mines, for the peace movement and for the general community of Australia because now we have the opportunity to have the first general inquiry into uranium mining and put that information together. I am very pleased to be here to see this motion adopted.
Amendment negatived.
Original motion agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the order of the Senate of 29 November 1994, relating to the consideration of legislation, not apply to the following bills:
Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1996
Health Legislation (Powers of Investigation) Amendment Bill 1996
Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill 1996.

This motion is so we can get on with the legislative program of the new government, and in particular have the opportunity to debate the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1996, the Health Legislation (Powers of Investigation) Amendment Bill 1996 and the Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill 1996.

As you would be aware, Mr Deputy President, in what I might describe as an inadvertent consequence, the effect of an order of the Senate of 29 November 1994 is that the new government does not have the opportunity to have legislation debated in this place unless the Senate is prepared to agree that that particular order should not apply. That order was put in place to encourage an orderly process of legislation in this place and we accept, as I said yesterday, the principle behind it.

However, it does create an impossible situation for a new government that is anxious to get on with the legislative program, to get on with the chance of implementing the policies that it took to the community at the last election. It is, therefore, our argument that it certainly should not apply to all bills that are introduced within the first two‐thirds of this first sitting session, but that is a debate we still have to conclude. Certainly, in relation to the three bills before us today, it should not apply.

BREAK.PARA: The hazardous waste bill was before the Senate under the authority of the last government. It is very familiar to senators. In fact both the Labor Party and the coalition had indicated their support for it on the last occasion. It would have been carried on the last day of the sitting but the Western Australian Greens indicated that there would be an extensive debate and there simply was not time.

You will remember, Mr Deputy President, that the then Labor government had got itself into an awful mess with the program. As I recall, some 40 packages of legislation were sitting there on that last day. In some ways, what we are seeking to do is to clean up the mess, for which no doubt the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) will express gratitude.

In this instance, the hazardous waste bill had been through an extensive public consultation process. An exposure draft was put to interested parties. Furthermore, a reference group of interested parties was set up to assist the then government in the drafting and finalisation of the bill. What I am saying is that the bill is very familiar to senators; therefore, any argument that senators have not had sufficient notice will obviously not have merit. I argue, therefore, that the order of November 1994 not apply to this bill.
