It will have the power to look at, consult and take evidence, but in the end the power to ratify a treaty—to accede to a treaty—still remains with the federal government unless the parliament takes action to direct it otherwise, as it does have the power to direct the federal government at any time if you can get legislation through both houses of parliament. We do not object to the committee, but we accept what it always should have had—the power to advise and the power to express an opinion, but not the power to veto.

Despite six years of humbug in this Senate from the then opposition, in the end after two months in government they have done nothing else but dress it up. The existing position of the former government continues as it should. We congratulate the minister for climbing down and accepting reality. We condemn him for going around before the election and conducting a fear campaign that did not have any substance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we have one of the most significant reforms in relation to the Commonwealth's power under section 51(xxix) of the constitution. Over the years there has been much concern expressed by community groups, business groups and state governments as to how this government entered into international treaties. I am pleased to see that the government has accepted 10 out of 11 recommendations made by the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee, which I chaired during this inquiry. I take this opportunity to thank those members of the committee for their hard work and their contribution. I also wish to thank the secretariat who served us so well at that time, in particular, Ms Anne Twomey, who has now gone on to lecture at Sydney University.

SPEECH.PARA: This report was one of the most significant reports made by a Senate committee in the last parliament. The government has recognised the concerns which were expressed to the committee and has sensibly accepted its recommendations. I point out to the Senate that recently in the House of Lords this Senate committee report was referred to favourably in the course of a debate on a bill introduced by Lord Lester which involved parliamentary scrutiny in that country. We have the so-called mother of all parliaments in the United Kingdom looking to Australia for leadership in this area of reform in the process of entering into treaties. I think that is significant and completely overshadows the remarks made by Senator Schacht.

Let us look at some of the responses made by the government. The first is that treaties be tabled in parliament at least 15 sitting days before the government takes binding action. Previously, treaties were tabled twice a year. I recall an instance in October last year when no less than 100 international instruments, comprising treaties and amendments to treaties, were tabled with senators having no time at all to scrutinise them. This response is a great leap forward.

And so is the national interest analysis—basically a treaty impact statement—which was recommended by the committee. No such statement has existed before. It will enable people looking at treaties and impact statements to have a better understanding of what they entail. Through that process alone the community will be better informed about what we are letting ourselves in for.

The Parliamentary Joint Standing Committee on Treaties is something else new. It will allow the parliament—the House of Representatives and the Senate—to inquire into and report on any treaties under consideration. This can only be looked upon as an innovative step forward.

In relation to the Treaties Council, I remind Senator Schacht that the standing committee on treaties is really a body made up of officials. The Treaties Council will be made up of elected representatives from the states and chief ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not in the statement.
—It is in the report. The Senate report outlined how the standing committee worked. Obviously, Senator Schacht, you do not have that understanding.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the council, I refer you to recommendation 7. The government's response says that the composition and role of the council are matters to be agreed with between the Commonwealth, states and territories—properly so. But the government has accepted the recommendation made by the committee that the council should be made up of elected representatives rather than officials. That is a step forward.

The committee also recommended that the council would issue reports from time to time and that those reports be made public. That is in stark contrast with the existing situation—another point that Senator Schacht has overlooked.

I turn now to the treaties information database, which will be designed to make it easy for all persons and groups in the community with an interest in this area to obtain information on treaties free of charge. The committee heard that the current situation was unsatisfactory, that information was not available to the community at large. This database will be another great leap forward in increasing the transparency of the treaty process.

Up until now there has been a democratic deficit in the way this country has entered into treaties. That concerned many people who gave evidence to the Senate committee inquiring into this matter. At the last election the community raised the question of what a future government might do in this regard. That is why the coalition saw fit to put out its policy on the matter.

The coalition did not say at any stage that it would bring in a system whereby the parliament would disallow treaties. The government has sensibly said that it will review in two years time how these reforms work. It will also review whether further consideration should be given to parliament having the ability to disallow treaties. That is a very sensible approach to reviewing how these reforms operate. I can tell Senator Schacht that a great deal of concern in this regard was expressed to the Senate committee.

I concede that there were divergent views. That was because this is such a complex and difficult area that no‐one has the experience to draw on to form a definitive view. I suggest that in two years time, once we have seen the operation of these reforms, we will have the experience and hindsight to make an informed decision. This, fellow senators, is a great step forward in the way this federation operates. It means that the people of Australia will have greater input into how we enter into treaties. Community groups, business groups, state and territory governments will all have input.

To date there has been no formal procedure for the government to follow before entering into treaties. We had no notice of what was to be signed or ratified. We now have a situation where treaties will be tabled 15 sitting days prior to signing or ratification, which could mean having as long as three calendar months. That will give an opportunity for a joint parliamentary committee to review and inquire into these treaties and to report to the people on what the country is letting itself in for.

Most importantly, with recommendation 1, the government has accepted the need for an audit or listing of treaties that we have entered into. It was discovered during the course of our inquiry that no‐one was certain about how many treaties we had signed. I take on board the department's difficulty with the fact that some of the countries we have signed treaties with have since disappeared. Nonetheless, there must be an ongoing audit of how many treaties we have signed and what they are. That information should be available to all Australians.

We have here a comprehensive response to a unanimous report from a Senate committee comprised of members from the Labor Party, the Australian Democrats, the National Party and the Liberal Party. The committee reached complete consensus on what was needed and the government has adopted 10 of the 11 recommendations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats welcome today's ministerial statement by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill) on reform of the treaty‐making process. As everyone in this chamber knows, we have been calling for reform of treaty‐making processes for several years. In fact, I have introduced two private senator's bills, both for a Parliamentary Approval of Treaties Act. The second of these, introduced last year, would ensure that no treaty could come into force in Australia unless the parliament gave its approval.

SPEECH.PARA: We have long held the view that parliament's role should not be usurped by the executive when it comes to making commitments and entering into international obligations on behalf of the entire country—on behalf of every single one of us. There has clearly been an undermining of some very basic democratic principles in this area recently and the Democrats were critical of the previous government's failure to take action in that regard.

I congratulate the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) and the coalition on their decision to make changes to the area of treaty making as one of their first actions in government. The government's changes are in line with much of what the Democrats have proposed. However, there is one great disappointment. That is, the coalition government has followed the course of its Labor predecessors and backed off making the final commitment to the democratic process: to allow both houses of the federal parliament to decide whether or not Australia should be a party to a treaty.

The coalition gets to that hurdle—and it makes some positive changes and commitments along the way. But it cannot quite bring itself to jump over that final obstacle and recognise the supremacy of the parliament over the executive. That failure to take the final step does weaken the impact and the strength of today's statement.

The government has agreed to table treaties in parliament at least 15 sitting days before the government takes binding action. That is a step forward. As we have frequently heard before, in the past the parliament has put up with having a swag of treaties and international agreements tabled once or twice a year in one big lump, with time—if we are lucky—for half an hour's worth of debate on the lot of them. Tabling usually comes after ratification—quite often, a long time after ratification—and impending legislation accompanying treaties has been very rare.

So the government's decision to table treaties 15 days before ratification is welcomed by the Democrats. As Senator Hill said, 15 sitting days does often extend into a month or more in calendar days, and I accept that this move will not only improve parliamentary scrutiny of treaties but also open them up for public debate and comment. That level of openness in scrutiny is very much overdue.

We support the decision to table treaties accompanied by a national interest analysis. That sort of impact statement is something which will certainly facilitate public debate about the possible flow‐on effect of treaties and it makes the tabling process a more meaningful exercise than it otherwise might have been. We will also support—though with reservations—the decision to establish a joint parliamentary committee on treaties, although I again make the point that scrutiny is not the same as approval.

The Democrats are already on the record as saying that we are not keen to set up a special committee to examine treaties. I have called for an expanded role for the Selection of Bills Committee to enable it to make referrals on treaties to whatever Senate committee—or, indeed, joint committee—is best equipped to deal with the content of the particular treaty. The Democrats still believe that is the better course of action, but we will not stand in the way of the government's proposal.

I also make the observation that the committee will need adequate resources if it is do its job properly and play a genuine and effective role in leading public debate on treaties. That is something the government needs to seriously consider if it is about to cut resources to the parliamentary committee process. I trust the government will ensure that that joint committee has sufficient resources to do its job.

The Democrats also support the creation of a treaties council under the auspices of the Council of Australian Governments. That should ensure a greater level of Commonwealth‐state cooperation on treaties—I certainly hope it does—and it should also raise the level of debate and understanding about the impact of treaties. We also support the government's decision to fund the establishment of a treaties database and I commend the government for its stated commitment to ensuring a greater level of public access to information about treaties.

I cannot finish a speech on treaty making without mention of the Australian‐Indonesian bilateral security treaty which was put in place, almost single‐handedly, by the previous Prime Minister, Mr Keating, in December of last year. That treaty must rank as the prime example of how not to carry out the process of writing and ratifying a treaty. The terms of the treaty were agreed on in absolute secrecy—and the last Prime Minister was immensely proud of that fact.

I heard the former Prime Minister say on television that the reason he kept it absolutely secret was that if it had been public it would not have happened. How is that for democracy! If I, as an Australian citizen, am going to be bound by an international treaty to closely cooperate with a defence force, one section of which—Kopassus—has one of the worst human rights records in the world, I want to know about it. As a citizen of a democratic country, I have a right to know about it. And I want to have the democratically elected members of the federal parliament decide by a vote whether or not I will be bound by that treaty.

It is quite interesting to note that, before that treaty went ahead, there was a lot of debate—including in the committee that Senator Cooney, Senator Ellison and others are members of—about what the rules and regulations should be for treaty making. But it was all a bit academic at the time, because most of the treaties that Australia had put in place over the previous 20 years or so, over several different governments, had been fairly public. We had had debates on them in parliament—the more contentious ones, at any rate—and they usually led to some sort of a vote in parliament.

But the treaty with Indonesia was the most outrageous abuse of democratic process I have seen in a very long time. It was outrageous because we did not have a say on what went into that treaty; we did not have a say on whether we should be a part of that treaty; and it was, I am sure, deliberately timed to be put to the Australian people just after the parliament had risen, just before Christmas, so there would be very little public debate—and no debate whatsoever in parliament. It is just an absolute outrage.

The bottom line, though, is really this: the democratic deficit will remain in existence until such time as the government of the day is prevented from entering into treaties, conventions or protocols without the approval of both houses of parliament. During the election, the coalition, in its foreign affairs policy, pointed out with great clarity the current problems in the treaty‐making process. I agreed with them. Their policy talked of the increasing impact of internationalisation on domestic laws. It talked of the inadequacy of Australia's treaty‐making processes to manage the growing task of international law making.

Perhaps most significantly, the policy said that there was already `compelling evidence' of the direct and undesirable impact on domestic laws and the division of powers as a result of those inadequate processes. We have to think of the Teoh legislation here. We have to remind ourselves that if we have agreed to a piece of legislation, through both houses of this parliament, that piece of legislation is something that Australia has to be bound by.

In the same way, if we have signed a treaty and said, `We believe this is our international obligation', it should also be our domestic obligation. We cannot say, `We have agreed that everybody else should do this—but, by the way, we won't.' That is a really outrageous thing to say. We have to keep that in mind when we look at the treaty making process. We have to keep that in mind when we look at the treaties that we have already signed.

The coalition says all these things but it still cannot bring itself to solve those problems through the relatively simple mechanism of giving the parliament the right to approve treaties. It would have been better to go down that path. It is a great pity and a great loss of opportunity that we did not. But I think we are going down a path which is far better and far more clearly spelt out than the one we have gone down before.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allocated for debate on this matter has expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted for the time of debate to be extended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —Today is a historic day in the constitutional development of this country. It is a historic day because, for the first time ever, a government has come to the parliament and said, `We wish to put controls over the power of the executive government to enter into and ratify treaties.' That is why today is significant. It is significant because this government, in the first week of sitting, has said that the process which had been in train for the last 50 years—by which the power of the states and the Commonwealth parliament to legislate and the sanctity of the constitution had been eroded by continual transgressions by governments of all political persuasions—has been arrested.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the first time that a government has said, `We believe that the practice of government should adhere more strictly to the intention of the constitution.' As my colleague Senator Ellison so eloquently said earlier, section 51 of our constitution lays down certain restrictions upon the right of the federal government to legislate. Yet what we have seen, most particularly since the Franklin dam case in 1983, has been the efforts of the previous Labor government to ignore section 51 and to use spurious treaties as the basis of oppressive legislation overriding the rights of the states and overriding the interests of the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would have dammed the Franklin—typical National Party!

—That is why today is an historic day and that is why Senator Schacht is so bitter and twisted on the other side of the chamber. This government shows that it is concerned with the true basis of democracy in this country, which is that the executive government must be held accountable to the parliament. That is the basis of the reforms which have been outlined today by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I go on any further, it is appropriate to pay tribute to a number of honourable senators present in the chamber today. They include my colleagues from both sides of the chamber who served on the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee and also the current Manager of Government Business in the Senate, Senator Kemp. When he sat on the other side of the chamber, he was one of the people who had the courage and the fortitude to say, `We believe that the powers which the federal government currently exercises in relation to treaties should be examined and should be subject to some sort of oversight by the parliament.'

Let me move to some of the great reforms that are introduced in this ministerial statement. I wish to concentrate on two of those reforms. The first of those reforms is a commitment to a treaties council which will truly involve the states as well as the federal government in the process of considering treaties before they are entered into. Senator Schacht in his contribution said, `There are a number of treaties and we consulted with industry.' But, as Senator Bourne quite rightly said, there have been more treaties which the government has entered into in secret. Most notably, the recent treaty entered into with Indonesia on security matters was negotiated and signed in secret and only wheeled out before the parliament and the people of this country after the ink was dry on the paper. That we believe is wrong. That we believe is an abuse of executive power. That is why this coalition government has taken the unprecedented step of saying, `We believe that wherever possible these matters should be subject to scrutiny.'

The role of the treaties council will be to allow the states input into whether treaties should be signed, whether there should be reservations—that is, restrictions—upon Australia's obligations under those treaties and what scope a treaty should have in the process of negotiation when it is being drawn up. That is something that no government of either political persuasion has been willing to entertain to date. It is a sign of the commitment of this coalition government to return the parliament to its paramount position in the Australian democracy and to involve the states in a process of true federalism—not sham federalism and not centralism, but a process of true federalism which recognises the fact that state parliaments and state governments have as much of a stake in these treaties as does the federal parliament and the federal government. For that, I believe the government deserves to be congratulated.

More importantly, I believe the government is deserving of congratulations in respect of the recommendation it accepted for a joint parliamentary committee on treaties. The wording of the recommendation is quite important. The committee recommended that the joint parliamentary committee on treaties have the power to inquire into: proposals to enter into treaties; whether there should be any reservations; whether there should be any changes or removal of reservations we already have; the obligations Australia already has under treaties; the function of scrutinising treaty statement impacts; the right to hold public hearings and hearings in camera and to call for documents and witnesses; and the power to commence an inquiry into a treaty at any time, regardless of whether or not it relates to a document which has been tabled in parliament. The government has accepted this recommendation for the establishment of this committee.

PARA.BREAK: Therefore, for the first time ever in Australian constitutional history, not only will there be parliamentary oversight by virtue of this joint committee but, because the committee will have the power to call witnesses and to hold hearings into treaties, the people of Australia will have a say about Australia's treaty obligations. You would well be aware, Mr Acting Deputy President Childs, that there are many people in Australia today who are horrified at the way in which the previous government abused the treaty making power. This will give the ordinary Australian the chance to present his or her view to the parliament of this country, for all to see. They can give their view as to the impact of a treaty, as to whether we should make reservation to a treaty or as to whether the treaty should be entered into or not. That is a bold step by this government, but a step which says, `We trust the people of Australia and we trust the good sense of the people of Australia when it comes to these matters.' More importantly, we trust them to make recommenda tions which we can consider and, if appropriate, implement.

SPEECH.PARA: Senators from both sides of the chamber who sat on the committee should be happy to see that so many of these recommendations have been accepted by the government. I and others may have differing views as to whether treaties ultimately should be subject to parliamentary disallowance or whether they should be subject to parliamentary approval processes and so on. That is an appropriate debate for us to have. The government does not walk away from that. The government, in the ministerial statement, is committed to a further examination, in two year's time, of the workings of the processes we commence here. I believe that we have started a process which will ultimately lead to parliamentary ratification or parliamentary disallowance of treaties. It may take two years; it may take 22 years.

The most important thing to say today is this: hitherto treaties were formal affairs of state that were discussed, agreed and signed in secret. Under this government we have taken the historic and, hopefully, irreversible step of involving the parliament and the people in the treaty making process, which can only befit a great democracy such as this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —(12.34 p.m.)—We are debating a most important document which arises out of a very important report. Much has been said about that so far and I agree with most of what has been said. Senator Schacht is, of course, right when he says that, in the end, it is still government that makes, signs and ratifies the treaties. That is understandable because historically that is the position: the government, as distinct from parliament, was the institution that made treaties, in the sense of agreeing to them, and that signed them and ultimately ratified them.

SPEECH.PARA: The position over the last few decades or so has been that treaties have impacted more and more directly on the lives of citizens of countries around the world than was the position prior to that. States went to war usually on the declaration of war by their executive. That had a horrific impact. But putting that aside, most treaties did not touch the lives of people in the way that they do today.

BREAK.PARA: The treaty which gave rise to the saving of the Franklin Dam has already been mentioned and I use that illustration again. Another illustration is the one that concerned your state, Mr Acting Deputy President Childs—the matter that arose from the Toonen case. You would be very well aware of that.

That is an illustration of how treaties more and more come into the forefront of our lives. That is particularly the case with treaties that deal with civil rights, arising from such conventions as the International Convention on Civil and Political Rights; treaties that deal with the way and conditions under which we work, the International Labour Organisation treaties, which are very significant indeed; and environmental treaties. It is those three categories of treaties—dealing with work, civil and economic rights, and the environment—which impact upon people in an everyday sense. It is for that reason that people and citizens of other countries generally have become more and more interested in what their particular governments have to say to each other about what will be the norm, what will be the agreement as to how things will function around the world.

When the constitution, which has been mentioned, came into operation in 1901, our foreign policy was very much dictated by Westminster, by the British parliament. It was only later with statutes like the Statute of Westminster that the separate foreign policy of the former colonies became more and more their own possession. So this particular committee report and government response must be seen as now coming within that great sweep of change, if you like, from 1901 to the present time and into the future.

The importance of this report, amongst other things, is that it anticipated that change. It has, as it were, seen the growing appetite of people in this country to have a greater say in what is agreed between us and other countries because the fact of the matter is it affects their lives. So if we are going to have laws, for example, about the way sexual practises are conducted, about the way our land is to be used and about the way the workplace is to be regulated, they will need to be looked at by the public and by the public's representatives, which is this parliament. They will then be passed into law if they are appropriate.

People are starting to understand more and more that the laws that ultimately fill our statute books in many instances have their origin, their birth, in the agreements that are made in the United Nations and, to a lesser extent, between nations on a bilateral basis. The United Nations is the engine of much change around the world. The European Community has its own dynamics but as far as Australia goes, as we are a separate country, down here in the Southern Hemisphere it is the United Nations which gives most force to the changes that arise from international agreements, international treaties.

So when this parliament passes statutes to outlaw racism, to promote the equality of gender, to give people with disabilities—people who are injured in mind and body—an equal place in society with those of us who are whole, it should be understood, which is happening more and more, that those sorts of laws come from international agreements which may have been reached many years before and are, therefore, appropriate to be looked at by the people of Australia prior to their actually being ratified at least.

Senator Bourne, who has done much work in this area, says, as I understand her, that before treaties are signed this parliament should give agreement to them. We looked at that issue, as Senator Ellison, Senator McKiernan, who is about to speak, and Senator O'Chee would agree, but clearly the United Nations, where most of this change comes from, is an organisation of executive governments not parliaments. As you know, Mr Acting Deputy President, the parliaments meet on occasions in such forums as the IPU, at which you have represented Australia with great distinction.

It is a difficulty which will need to be discussed further but it would be premature to have a situation where this parliament must agree to a treaty being signed before it is so signed. The practicalities are very much against that being a viable matter. Also, the way we deal with treaties has to be seen as being in continuing development, as an organic sort of thing. This is a major step along the way. It is for that reason I join with Senator Ellison, as deputy chair of the committee, in thanking the committee and in thanking the secretariat. Over the years the secretariats of this committee have served this country well. I join, finally, with Senator Ellison in thanking Anne Twomey. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a big day when a government, after three or four days of sittings, meets one of its electoral promises so soon. While Senator Schacht was very churlish in his response to the proposition that was put down—
—Senator Cooney's been much more magnanimous.
—Senator Cooney is a big man in this parliament. We all recognise that.
—You are right. You have changed nothing in substance, and I applaud the government for changing nothing in substance.

—The fact is that this government has gone as far as is practical. It has gone as far as it could go. In contrast to that, Senator Schacht, on 30 November 1994, 36 bilateral and multilateral treaties were tabled, of which 16 had been ratified by your government and a further seven had come into force. You must concede that the document laid down today goes a long way to improve that position. Even the most ungenerous person would concede that a lot of advancement has been made since your position of dumping 36 treaties on the table and saying, `Here they are. Whether you want them or not, they are ratified.'

SPEECH.PARA: This proposition may not go as far as the Australian Democrats want to go. It may not go as far as you want it to go. But at least it is going somewhere. I believe it is really answering something which concerns the constituency of Queensland. People have recognised over the last 13 years, with the government's continued use of international treaties to override their vote, that they have been losing their democratic right to have an influence on governments, both federal and state.

The new arrangements do meet the concerns of the public. They meet, as far as is practical, the concerns of the state and territory governments. The members of the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee should be congratulated on recognising these and on coming up with a deliberate way of satisfying some of the concerns that have been raised.

The treaties will have to be tabled for 15 sitting days before any decisions can be made. That will allow scrutiny. It will allow debate. It will allow people to become involved in issues that they are concerned with. An exceptional circumstances provision is there for when parliament is not sitting. I think that we all recognise the need for that. The national interest and people's concerns will be met through analysis, which will accompany the tabling of the treaty. No treaty will be ratified without an analysis of the impact a treaty will have on Australia and the states.

A joint parliamentary committee on treaties will be set up to scrutinise treaties before they come into parliament. The proposed treaties council will include representations from states and territories and will be part of the COAG agreement. There will be a database for information on treaties, and that will be able to be accessed by all Australians.

It is a red‐letter day for Australia. It is a day that should be recognised. A newly formed government has tried to grapple, and has grappled successfully, with an issue that has been raised on numerous occasions in Australia. I would say that it is of concern to rural Australia, and it is of even more concern to the people of the cities because they have seen democratic rights being eroded through treaties laid down on the Franklin Dam, on the wilderness areas in the north of Queensland, and on the timber industry where rights were completely eroded under an international treaty. Jobs were lost and industries were destroyed. People then started to take note of treaties being forced down their throats. But they had no practical way of voting against those treaties or of using the democratic process to stop those treaties going ahead and affecting their lives.

So, in contrast to the Labor Party's gung‐ho approach of dumping 36 treaties on the table—seven of which have come into force and 16 of which have been ratified—that process will never be allowed to happen again while this government is in power. I believe that that will be for a very long time.

What you are seeing now—it may not be obvious to Senator Schacht or senators opposite—is one of the first processes of a new government taking the concerns that have been expressed to the National and Liberal parties by the people through their branches and through other processes. These concerns have been recognised by the two parties, and action has been taken at the earliest possible opportunity.

I once again congratulate the people who were responsible for the report: the members of the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee. They have done a good job, as has the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) in responding in such a quick fashion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarrette, Sen Christabel

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, on behalf of the Greens (WA), welcome the statement delivered by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill) concerning the reform of Australia's treaty making processes. In particular, the Greens welcome the decision to table in parliament all treaties for at least 15 sitting days prior to any binding action. This is a crucial democratic step. We also welcome the creation of a treaties council to involve all states and territories, and the establishment of a treaties information database, which will enable the general public to be better informed about the whole international treaty process and what those treaties oblige Australia to do.

SPEECH.PARA: However, all this is made somewhat irrelevant when one puts it alongside the move by the former government, with the support of the then opposition, to bring before this parliament the Administrative Decisions (Effect of International Instruments) Bill 1995. That bill would have negated the effect of many of the treaties Australia has signed by removing any administrative necessity to fulfil our interna tional obligations unless expressly legislated by the parliament. The passage of such legislation would have severely damaged Australia's international reputation.
As Justice Elizabeth Evatt said in her oral submission to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee's inquiry into that bill:
It—
the anti‐Teoh legislation, as abbreviated—
gives the message that we have no reasonable expectation that our government will comply with obligations that it has undertaken. I would be ashamed to have to say that at an international forum.

Many others have spoken out against the gutting of Australia's international obligations through the so‐called anti‐Teoh bill. I would hope that, by instigating an orderly process of implementing treaty commitments, this will remove the need for this new government to proceed to reintroduce the Administrative Decisions (Effect of International Instruments) Bill 1995 or any other legislation that looks remotely like it.

There has been a void in Australia's international treaty procedures. We have not had an effective and comprehensive mechanism for consultation, scrutiny and implementation of international instruments. So I could not agree more heartily with Senator Bourne, who expressed her grave concerns about the Australian‐Indonesian security treaty that was negotiated in such a secretive way and with such disdain for democratic principles. I do agree with and endorse the comments previously made in relation to concerns that that way of entering into treaty making is utterly unacceptable and undemocratic. I believe the new government has made a strong stand. By that, I hope it will distance itself from any such similar behaviour.

I must disagree, however, with Senator Bourne and the Democrats, who assert that parliament should dictate to and veto the executive in the area of international treaties. Treaties are essentially aspirational. International treaties ensure that standards are set which have a wider perspective than that brought by any one country. Treaties provide a measure of intent which, hopefully, will be greater than that allowed by the political exigencies of any one country. Treaties allow the international community to focus on what should be, rather than on what we can get put in place back home. Because treaties are aspirational, even the negotiation process can compromise ideals and in some sense already international treaties are the result of the lowest common denominator approach. However, this would be exacerbated much further if that were the result of the domestic parliament constraining the executive.

These particular reforms that we have in place and see introduced today are historic. They will keep the executive accountable without allowing the executive to be rendered impotent in relation to its very responsible role in international fora. The Commonwealth government has the right to participate in international fora and the responsibility to exercise its national role in the global community. That right and responsibility does not give it licence to make treaties without open and clear processes of consultation with the Australian community and with the parliament. These measures today guarantee that that licence not be allowed in this country.

Neither should that right and responsibility of treaty making give any government the licence to enter into treaties and make treaties without any intention of honouring them in its administrative decision making. That is why I have referred to the High Court decision on Teoh, which affirmed the common law position of 1969, that there should be a legitimate expectation that decision makers will take provisions of international conventions into consideration. Therefore the Greens (WA) welcome the government's reforms in relation to treaty making and believe it will go far in addressing the community's concerns about the role of treaties in the past and in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —I am going to take a somewhat different position from some of the earlier speakers in this debate. I differ from my colleague, Senator Schacht, and actually welcome the response by the minister to the report of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee. I think it is admirable and it sets a standard, which I hope will be repeated through the life of the parliament, that committee reports will be responded to with the speed with which this one has been responded to.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been mentioned that the government has only had two months in which to respond to the report. That is absolutely correct because the election was only held two months ago today, and here we are discussing the response. That perhaps overlooks the fact that the report has actually been in the parliament and in the public eye now for six months. A considerable amount of work has been done on the report and the preparation of the response by officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. In commending the government for the speed in which the response has been brought into the parliament, one must also commend the individuals who are part of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade for the efforts that they have put into the preparation of the response that we are debating in the Senate this afternoon.

I do agree with my colleague Senator Schacht, though, on the content of the response. I would urge people, particularly those who spoke earlier, not to get too carried away with the response that is before us. I have not had the opportunity of having an early copy of the report, but I do not believe that it does all the things that has been said of it in this place. Hopefully, in the few minutes remaining to me here, I will be able to deal with that.

It seems to me that the minister, in delivering his response here this afternoon, dwelt more on the contents of the government's reforms—as foreshadowed in its foreign affairs and law and justice policy statements enunciated before the election—than on the recommendations in the report of the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee. The minister said that the changes would provide proper and effective procedures to enable parliament to scrutinise intended treaty action. It is commendable if they do that, but it would have been more honest if the minister had said that the changes would provide proper and effective procedures to enable parliament to scrutinise some policy actions as they relate to treaties, because that is what the committee was about.

We recognised when we were taking evidence and when we were deliberating on and preparing the report that there would be some treaties that this country would enter into that would not be the subject of the scrutiny of the parliament. Indeed, I believe, and I can be corrected, that one of the treaties mentioned here today by Senator Bourne—the one relating to Indonesia which was publicised late last year—was supported by the then opposition and that it will not repudiate the content of the treaty now that it is in government. So it might have been more honest if the minister had enunciated that it is only some things that will change. I welcome the changes that are going to be made.

I want to deal in part—and very briefly because of the time limitations here today—with the contents and the detail of the response. Essentially, what we have before us, and I welcome it, is a holding report; it is a holding response. The real response hopefully will come in two years when, as the minister said, the government will review the new tabling arrangements. They consider that then, two years hence, will be the most appropriate time to consider the need for legislation and any suggestion that there might be a further examination of a parliamentary approval system. This response does not automatically give that parliamentary approval system now.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not go near.

—It does not go near, as my colleague Senator Bolkus has said. Recommendation 2 of the report recommends legislation provide that the government report to parliament annually. The response to this recommendation says:

SPEECH.PARA: The government agrees to table annually a list of Commonwealth legislation specifically implementing Australia's treaty obligations.

There is a very distinct difference in the words, and a more distinct difference in the meaning of the words. The committee asked for legislation: the government said that it will agree to table a list.

Recommendation 3 was agreed to. Recommendation 5 was not accepted and there are reasons given in the response as to why it was not accepted. Recommendation 6 called for the government to increase its efforts to identify and consult. The response is that that recommendation is accepted. The comment actually does not take the response all that much further than what has become, in recent years, the current practice—the practice that has evolved in consulting with representative groups, with individuals and with non‐government organisations. I hasten to add that the comment that goes with the response is that it has been accepted by the government. Recommendation 7 stated:
That the existing Commonwealth‐State Standing Committee on Treaties be abolished and replaced with a Treaties Council that is preferably established by legislation . . .
The response was:
The government accepts the need to establish a treaties council.
There is a very great difference between accepting the need to establish a treaties council and going out there and legislating, or even giving a commitment to legislate, to establish one.

The committee recommended, yet again, a legislative means to progress what we had determined would arise out of the committee's inquiry. We called for legislation to be enacted which would require the tabling of treaties in both houses of the Commonwealth parliament within 15 sitting days. We recognised, as a committee, that it would not always be possible to do that within 15 sitting days. I welcome the fact that some of the earlier speakers recognised that in some instances it could be up to three months before the parliament would have an opportunity to table the treaties.

Equally important in the process was the fact that the committee lent itself to the legislative path. However, from the response it seems that there is no wish to move to legislative means at all. I think that is a bit sad but I also welcome the fact that the matter will be looked at within a two‐year period.

With respect to recommendation 9, the committee again took the legislative path by recommending the establishment of a joint parliamentary committee on treaties. That has not been accepted by the government. They say that a better way of progressing this would be by resolutions of both houses of parliament. I understand that sometime today—perhaps the manager of government business might nod in approval—we will be told what the joint committees of the parliament are going to be.

TALK.START.PARA: —You want a job, do you?
—I do want a job, yes. I would prefer a job in government than one in opposition but that is not to be.
—You are applying for chairman, are you? I will put in a good word for you.

—No, I am not applying for chairman. Recommendation 10 also called for the legislative path but, again, the government has sought not to undertake that path. I wonder why the government has not given a greater commitment to going down the path of legislation in this very important area, especially when there is an increased interest within the community about it.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that the people who beat up the issues that led to the inquiry, and kept the matter going during the inquiry, will in turn do the proper thing and let everyone who made submissions know what the response is. I hope those people, many of whom were very genuine in their beliefs—some of the beliefs were misguided, I believe—will not be too disappointed in the report. To conclude, you have set a pattern of responses within six months of delivery of committee reports. Let us hope you stick to that in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a few comments on the government response to the report by the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee entitled Trick or Treaty? Commonwealth power to make and implement treaties . I welcome the government's response and put on record again my thanks to all my fellow committee members and the secretariat of the references committee.

SPEECH.PARA: It would be fair to say that the question of treaties and the implementation of them within the body politic of Australia has been somewhat controversial over the last decade or so. I think it is a credit to the committee as a whole that we were able to bring down a unanimous report. Such a controversial topic required serious consideration and I believe the Senate committee did give it that.

When people such as Senator McKiernan, Senator Spindler, Senator O'Chee, Senator Ellison and me all sign off on the one document, I think it is a credit to the workings of this chamber and to the Senate committee system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under the chair of the committee!

—That was my very next point, Senator McKiernan. I also pay tribute to the chairmanship of my colleague, Senator Chris Ellison. Some of us are somewhat concerned as to who is going to chair the next legal references committee, Senator McKiernan, but we live in hope and trust that you will live up to the great precedent set by Senator Ellison.

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberal Party and the National Party went to the last election on the promise of reforming the processes of parliament. I welcome the government's response to this report because if there has been one criticism of the treaty‐making process in the past, it has been of its lack of transparency and of the lack of community involvement. Literally, members of this parliament could wake up one morning finding that we had entered into international obligations without any consultation with the parliament of Australia and without any consultation with the people of Australia.

As we now know, as a result of certain High Court decisions in recent times, these international treaties can affect our domestic laws in ways in which the Australian Labor Party used to say they would not be affected. There were people on this side of the chamber, such as the capable Manager of Government Business in the Senate, Senator Kemp, and others who made comments to the effect that these international treaties would be of importance in determining our domestic law. The High Court has now, I say regrettably, confirmed that view. It is absolutely important that the system of international treaty making be made transparent and be made subject to the Australian parliament and through that to the people of Australia.

Some two years ago, in my first speech in this place, I expressed my concerns at the way in which the international treaty‐making process was subverting our federal system of government. Basically the federal government could simply sign any international treaty and thereby get a head of power to legislate in areas which had usually been the preserve of the states. That provided a great degree of uncertainty in constitutional law. If there is one thing that any country needs it is certainty in the law. Unfortunately, the treaty‐making processes adopted, especially under the past Labor government, were such that the certainty of law was undermined.

The government's response has been a considered and appropriate one. Furthermore, I am delighted that the government has taken the initiative to respond so quickly. Indeed, I believe it is the government's first response to a Senate committee report. It is a great credit to Mr Downer—I listened to his comments in the House of Representatives—and to others in the new Howard‐Costello government that they have brought down this report so quickly and yet so thoughtfully.

I thought the 11 recommendations that the committee made were good ones. At the time that the report was brought down, I indicated that I had limited some of my thoughts and views to ensure that we could get a unanimous report. It is disappointing when a unanimous report is not fully accepted by the government. But this new government has been left with a fiscal hole of $8 billion—the legacy of the Labor government—and, as a result, some of the initiatives in this report cannot be implemented, simply because that would just add to the financial dilemma that this country finds itself in.

I am hopeful that once we have got the economic imperatives back in order the government may be able to revisit its considered response to this report and ascertain whether, after some of the Labor legacy debt has been paid off, funds could possibly be made available to implement some of the programs suggested by our committee. This would ensure that the people of Australia have a say in international treaty making.

I was delighted that during the campaign the then shadow Attorney‐General, Senator Amanda Vanstone, was able to announce the Liberal Party's policy in relation to international treaty making. That policy was to look through an international treaty and ascertain what domestic obligations might flow from that treaty if we were to sign it, and to implement those domestic obligations prior to signing the actual international treaty. We could then go to the world with a clear conscience and say, before signing the international treaty, `We have already abided by our international obligations by having legislated domestically.' That is the exact reverse of what those on the other side did. They would sign treaties so that they could somehow use their powers to effect changes in the law. There have been occasions on which the signing of international treaties was done without any thought whatsoever as to the domestic obligations.

That is how the former Labor government got itself into so much trouble. The Labor government used to prance around talking about its international obligations until the High Court told the Labor government, `You have international obligations. Your laws are not to be upheld and we will impose those international obligations on you.' What did the Labor government do? It ran in to this parliament with a bill to overturn the High Court decision and thereby to overturn its international obligations. In anybody's language that is two‐faced. You either believe and take seriously your international obligations or you do not.

I believe that this government, as opposed to the former government, has taken a fresh look at this issue and is going to act responsibly in this area. As a result, I have great delight in supporting the government response and welcoming the new approach to international treaty making.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on the ministerial response to the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee report, Trick or treaty? Commonwealth power to make and implement treaties .

SPEECH.PARA: It was not long ago—perhaps two years, or slightly more—that the issue of considering treaties in this parliament was regarded as perhaps not being within the normal standards. I remember that, when we raised these issues and drew attention to some of the anomalies which were starting to come through as a result of the government's treaty‐making activities, we did not elicit a great response at the start.

What is encouraging about this whole process and about this report is not only the government's very positive response but also the responsive chord that it has clearly struck on all sides of the chamber. If we discount the contribution of Senator Chris Schacht and listen to the comments of Senator Cooney and others, there is no doubt that there was a very positive response to the government's statement today.

Certainly there has been a variety of views, including whether we should have gone a bit further. There was a debate when that issue was raised by the Democrats and the Greens. This is a prime example, certainly in my experience—six years in this parliament—of the way an issue can be raised and picked up by a variety of senators. It then attracts public attention; a serious committee looks at what can be done; recommendations are made; and the government acts in a positive manner in responding to the report.

When I look back, there are a number of things which have generated widespread community concern about the treaty‐making activities of the previous government. The first one, which was given some attention by the committee, was the decision to allow domestic disputes to go to UN human rights committees without any public debate at all. Some people—for instance Justice Michael Kirby—have drawn attention to this matter and have noted that there was not much public debate at that time. Australians suddenly found that, as a result of a particular case which went to the UN human rights committees, an important process which could have constitutional implications for this country had been put into effect without any public debate about it.

Another case which caused great concern was the ratification of ILO convention 158. This was an extraordinary occasion where, almost hours before the writs for the 1993 election were issued, this treaty was signed and ratified. It was really only after the election that people discovered what the government had done. My understanding was that there was no press statement at that time. That particular convention has been the subject of widespread public debate. Some elements of the industrial relations legislation of the previous government were based on it. But, as I said, it was signed without any community debate at all and there was no announcement by the government. That sort of approach, which the Hawke and Keating Labor governments had, did cause concern.

No‐one would argue that many of the treaties we sign are not extremely important. And there is no argument that, in the world we have today, there will be more and more treaties which will have to be signed, both on a unilateral basis and a multilateral basis. But it is important that there be a proper process by which this is carried out because of the implications such treaties can have for the domestic affairs of this country.

What the government has done today is to ensure that through the parliament the nation and its people are more effectively involved. The democratic deficit, which Sir Ninian Stephen drew attention to in an excellent speech about 12 months ago, is starting to be effectively addressed. In my view, we have taken a very important step forward in treaty‐making processes through this announcement today.

PARA.BREAK: I can remember having a debate with the former Senator Gareth Evans on this issue. We were discussing the treaty‐making activities of the previous government and I asked him, `Is there no way our people should be involved?' He said, and I believe I am quoting him correctly: `No way, Jose.' The former government really did feel that any parliamentary involvement in the treaty‐making process—and one way we have put forward here is essentially more effective parlia mentary scrutiny—would somehow threaten the treaty‐making regime which it had adopted and it was prepared to ignore contrary voices.

SPEECH.PARA: I certainly welcome the fact that as this debate has occurred over the last two or three years virtually all sections of the political spectrum have become involved. The Democrats have been very actively involved and Senator Bourne has spoken quite regularly on the subject in this chamber. As was pointed out in the debate today, the bill that she put forward went further than the ministerial statement which has now been presented. Senator Chamarette used the word `historic' in her response. She did not feel that it was appropriate that the parliament move to have the capacity to actually veto a treaty, but my understanding was that she welcomed the greater scrutiny and the greater chance for more effective public involvement.

I think this has been a very important process. It has been very encouraging to see that an issue such as this can be put firmly on the national agenda, and that political parties which differ on many things—and this is an issue on which many do differ—can sit down, take evidence, do a serious report and make some important proposals which are very rapidly responded to by the government. Given my own interest in this area, I would certainly like to extend congratulations to the committee members, through their chairman, Senator Ellison, and to the secretary, Anne Twomey, who did an excellent job in the preparation of this report.

I was interested to read a press cutting—I think it was from the London Times—that was sent to me recently. This committee report was in fact referred to in the mother of parliaments in London. It is interesting that there was a debate—in the House of Lords, I think—which was based very much on the sorts of assumptions that underlie the report that we have here. That debate turned to the fact that it was very important that parliaments become more effectively involved in the treaty‐making process. That was in the UK, and I think it shows how even the effect of a good committee report can extend far wider than one would sometimes imagine.

BREAK.PARA: As I have said, I welcome the report which has been brought down. I certainly find most encouraging the very positive responses which have come from all sides of the chamber. I think that the committee and the government can consider that their work has been very well done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane, Sen Winston

TALK.START.PARA: —I also have some comments to make about the document before us—Trick or treaty? Commonwealth power to make and implement treaties —and about the government response that we have received from the appropriate minister, Mr Downer.

SPEECH.PARA: I do so against a background of interest in the subject. I think one of the first questions I asked in this place when I became a member some six years ago was a question at estimates related to treaties. I know my colleague Senator Kemp has taken a keen interest in that matter. I was always concerned about the way treaties were used to interfere—as I call it—with the making of domestic law, when there was no right, without the proper parliamentary processes, to use treaties in such a way.

I particularly want to concentrate on ILO convention 158, because that convention was the one brought in at one minute to midnight before the calling of the last election, and that was the convention used by Mr Brereton of the Labor Party to hang his industrial relations reform legislation on. We all know of the problems that arose from the use of that convention in terms of that legislation, particularly with regard to unfair dismissal laws, and of the pain that it caused to so many businesses and employees. I believe it cost many people the opportunity of gaining a job, because it overrode what was really the province of the states. As that convention had never been before either of the houses of parliament or had a proper opportunity to be scrutinised by the states, it was an inappropriate use of power by the Commonwealth.

PARA.BREAK: In terms of the government's response, that particular action will never be able to occur again, because it will have to go through the proper processes of this parliament—and so it should. In terms of what was in that act, if it had been presented here and debated prop erly by the various parties in this place, and thus people had had the proper opportunity to analyse the powers that existed in it in terms of relationships between the states and the Commonwealth, I question whether that treaty would ever have got up or got past the scrutiny of this place.

SPEECH.PARA: This response, as I have already emphasised, will prevent that from ever happening again. For that reason, I feel very comfortable with that aspect of it. When we make domestic law, it affects the Commonwealth, the states and the community, and it should be made within the province of the Australian nation. You should not be able to hang it, in the way that this was done, on conventions which are made by people outside of this country, people who have no feeling or understanding of how we operate as a Commonwealth country. The importance of this decision will manifest itself and we will see better legislation in coming years as a result of it. As a Western Australian, I must say that it has long been a contentious issue at our state conferences, and the various forums of the lay party, that decisions are made and hooked to these conventions.

I want to acknowledge the work that was done in terms of convincing people of the necessity to reform this particular aspect of the operations of treaties and get them before the federal parliament. Bill Hassell, a president of the party not so long ago, a member of the Western Australian state parliament and a leader of the Liberal Party in Western Australia, did make this an issue many years ago, when it was not so popular, and he pursued it. I think Bill would rest very happy today to know that we have this report before us.

I join my colleagues and people from the other side in congratulating the members of the committee—Senator Chris Ellison, Senator Cooney, Senator Abetz, Senator McKiernan, Senator Neal, Senator O'Chee, Senator Spindler and Senator Vanstone, and the participating members: senators Chamarette, Margetts, Kemp and Short—for bringing this report before us. It demonstrates that when members of the Senate put their minds to addressing a particular issue, and put party politics aside momentarily, they can come up with a document that is representative of the views of the states, the Australian people and the parliament. I take this opportunity to congratulate the committee, and in doing so I include staff members who worked on particular aspects, for bringing this report before us.

This is a very good day for the Australian parliament. As I have heard other speakers say, I think that the quick response to this, now that we are in government, demonstrates that as a government we intend to respond to things and be a government of action. Having made those comments, I reiterate that I am delighted that this report is before us today. I re‐emphasise my congratulations to those people who worked on it and to the minister for getting it into this place so quickly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few comments with regard to the statement delivered by Senator Hill today. I want to commend in the first instance the new Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) on his outstanding response to the report by the Senate committee: its speed, its haste, its comprehensiveness. I think my South Australian colleague Mr Downer will prove to be one of Australia's great foreign ministers and this is an excellent start to the performance of his great duties. The committee itself deserves Australia's congratulations. Senator Ellison, Senator Abetz and others have done a terrific job and have given great credence to the Senate committee process. They have demonstrated how valuable Senate committees can be.

PARA.BREAK: It was very disheartening and disappointing to read what former Senator Gareth Evans said in the House of Representatives the other day in relation to Mick Young when he condemned the Senate in the vein of the former Prime Minister, Paul Keating. While he did not use the word `swill', he certainly described the Senate as unrepresentative and he used other derogatory terms. I think it is very disappointing that someone who has served in this chamber for so long should go to the House and condemn his former cham ber when the Senate has just demonstrated its great value through this committee process by delivering this report which has now been acted upon and which is, as has been pointed out, a unanimous Senate report.

SPEECH.PARA: It was very encouraging to hear Labor senators applaud the government's response. Of course, it is interesting to us that Labor remains divided on this issue, with Senator Schacht taking a different line. It is a reflection upon the former government that we have come to this. It was the former government that brought the treaty‐making process into disrepute. This was never an issue in Australian politics prior to the advent of the Hawke‐Keating government. The external affairs power of the constitution was treated as an external affairs power. Many of us have watched the ALP over many years and we were not surprised to see that its centralist pretensions were put into effect through the back door of the constitution in a way which really did begin to subvert the constitution.

The Labor Party really has a central core philosophy that is centralist, that is not supportive of a federal structure of government, that does not like this Senate, that does not like the existence of states and does not like the fact that we have a constitution which prescribes the powers of the central government, and the remaining powers lie with the states. That is not a model they support and they have always attempted to centralise authority in Canberra. The external affairs power suddenly became a magic door that opened for them to pursue that path in a very dangerous and subversive way through the course of the 13 years during which, unfortunately, they remained in office.

We propose to bring that to an end and we have done so with a very comprehensive response. All treaties will now be tabled in the parliament at least 15 days before they are ratified. We will genuinely seek consultation with the people and with the community. It will not be the false consultative model adopted by Labor where a few peak interest groups were brought into the inner sanctum and given special privileges. We will be a genuinely consultative government. Our approach to treaties is demonstrated by this statement today.

BREAK.PARA: We do have a genuine respect for the parliament, unlike Labor in its previous guise. We will be tabling these things in the parliament with, I note, a national interest analysis that will accompany the tabling—a very comprehensive assessment of the domestic impact of these treaties that are proposed for ratification. I think that will be a tremendous advance in involving the parliament in the process of executive government. The creation of a joint standing committee on treaties is a terrific advance and, of course, as a federalist party, a major advance in forming a treaties council as an adjunct to the Council of Australian Governments, so that states and territories who are affected by international treaties can be involved in the analysis of their effects and the question of their ratification. And there is to be, of course, the treaties database administered by the Department of Foreign Affairs. These are all tremendous advances which we welcome and which the government must be commended for.

The question of parliamentary veto of treaties, I suppose, is one that will always be there. We are not supporting that proposition. I think we go a very long way towards opening up the process and towards involving parliament in it. We will not have the farce where dozens of treaties are dumped in the Senate allowing only a few minutes for feeble comments to be made on them, with no time at all for any proper debate.

So I do not think parliamentary veto is an option. The parliament has the option of vetoing any laws made with respect to any treaties that are entered into. Nevertheless, this is a very comprehensive statement, and a welcome end to the 13 years of development of the subversion of the constitution by abuse of the external affairs power which has now been brought to an end.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill, in his capacity as Minister representing the Prime Minister. Under the Labor government the accord had successfully constrained excessive wage increases, as evidenced by the underlying inflation rate of 3.3 per cent. Now that the accord has been discarded, what are the government's targets for wages outcomes this year?

—I think the accord was an unmitigated disaster. Labor's accord had a special relationship with the trade union movement and what it gave ordinary Australians was mass unemployment and falling living standards.
—What are the targets?

—This is your record. Let's put it this way; the accord was the cornerstone of your economic program, was it not? And the result of your economic program was 750,000 Australians out of work and many Australians in work with less income. That was the result of the accord. There has to be a better way than the accord and the better way is in fact to free up the economy and the labour market, implement the industrial relations reforms that we are advocating, correct some of the economic deficiencies, attack the underlying deficits, help make business more competitive and that will result in a better outcome.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I did ask Senator Hill what the government's targets were for wages outcomes this year. As a supplementary question, given your answer could you confirm that you have no targets, no benchmarks against which the Australian people can evaluate the efficacy of your wages policy? And will you accept that that must necessarily create huge uncertainty in the financial markets and in the wider community?
—The trouble is that what Senator Faulkner does not understand is that he is still using the language of the past. He is still referring to the policies—
—We are asking for an answer.
—Why don't you listen to the answer?
—You haven't got an answer.
—Order! The minister has a right to be heard, whether you like the answer or not.

—You just slip back into the rhetoric of the past—a rhetoric and a policy application which has failed. If you free up the industrial relations situation in this country, if you correct the underlying deficit, if you institute the microeconomic reforms that we are advocating, you will end up with better outcomes on interest rates and inflation. You will enable government to keep taxation down and you will therefore produce growth in employment and higher living standards.

—My question is directed to Senator Alston as the Minister representing the Prime Minister in public service matters. I ask: to what extent does the current downsizing of the public service reflect Labor Party policies and plans? And is there any possibility at all that the copious flood of tears we are seeing from the Labor Party may not be genuine?
—Downsizing! They are being sacked.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a very real possibility. And Senator Collins—who would take a lot of distinguishing from a crocodile at various times—ought to know that that is exactly what is going on here. The fact is that, if you listen to some of the ALP and public service union spokespeople—or some of them at least—you would think that what is in contemplation is a massive downsizing all as a result of policies that we have simply decided to implement unilaterally without any particular need to do it.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that we went into the last election with you lot promising faithfully on a stack of bibles that there would be a budget surplus. You would think that nothing had changed since then, but the fact is that Treasury has made it abundantly clear that some tough action needs to be taken. It is very clear that you were not prepared to take it. Unfortunately we have now been given that responsibility.

If you look at what will be put in place since the last election, we have a threefold approach. We gave a commitment prior to the election to a two per cent reduction in running costs. That is currently being implemented. In meeting our commitments we also spelt out some particular agencies where we thought there was scope for additional cuts and that approach is also being implemented.

Over and above all that is the need to address your $8 billion Beazley black hole. The fact is that you just cannot conjure those figures out of nowhere. I know you would like to pretend that it is business as usual, but it simply is not. Over a period of 10 years from 1986 to 1996 what you did without telling anyone was reduce the size of the public service from 181,000 to 146,000. In other words, 35,000 people were surreptitiously given the boot, some of them by involuntary redundancies.

Indeed, in the last financial year you had a further 19.2 per cent reduction; something like 14,000 people were taken off the list. We are sensitive to the needs of those people. We are not proposing to simply slash and burn for the sake of it. It will be a managed reduction. It will be negotiated pursuant to the Australian Public Service award. We are not setting targets and hopefully we will be able to achieve the great bulk of that on a voluntary basis.

The fact is that you are the ones who imposed on the Australian community the necessity for those sorts of reductions to be pursued. Therefore it is absolute hypocrisy—as Senator MacGibbon's question made plain—to suggest that somehow this is all our fault. It is almost entirely your fault, simply because of the combination—under the guise of a one per cent efficiency dividend—of your getting rid of all those thousands of public sector employees.

That process you put in place is what is currently under discussion. So, when you read about job reductions in certain departments, bear in mind that some of those relate to precisely the process that you had already put in train. The rest of them will relate to the $8 billion hole, thank you very much. So the fact is, when it comes to reductions in the public sector, we know where the blame lies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

That was because the economic policies—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question.
