—My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. I ask: is the $8 billion black hole the only unwelcome inheritance from the former Labor government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Calvert for a very perspicacious question. I would like to be able to answer his question `yes' but, regrettably, bad though that would be—that $8 billion black hole is a black hole that is a legacy of disgrace that Labor has left to the Australian nation, not just to the new government—the government has acquired another series of disastrous inheritances from Labor. On numerous fronts—on virtually every front—the Labor government failed and deceived the Australian people.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us look at a few of the legacies they left. Let us have a look at the state of our external accounts. —They left us with a legacy of almost the highest real interest rates in the industrialised world—at great cost to home buyers, to every Australian, particularly Australian families. ANSWER.PARA: Perhaps the greatest legacy we inherited from Labor was a distrust of government. Every major promise that you made to the Australian people was broken in a way that deceived them and reduced their trust and faith in government and reduced their living standards.

Are you ruling out categorically that there will be no change to your policies—your $8 billion overall plan—even if Treasury revises this downwards?

—What we have in place, we believe, is the correct answer to Australia's economic problem—a problem that we inherited from Labor. It is part of Labor's 13 years of failing. We did not ask for an $8 billion hole—Mr Beazley's $8 billion hole in the budget forecast. In fact, he assured us during the election that the surpluses would continue. We did not ask for that. No incoming government would want to be welcomed by an $8 billion hole in the forecast. But, having got to government, we are determined to address it and to address it with correct economic policy, and that is exactly what we are doing.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Minister, during the last election campaign you promised to cut a total of $3.5 million a year from the budget of the Family Court. That figure includes the two per cent service wide efficiency dividend and the Family Court's share of the AG's running cost reductions. At the time you claimed that these cuts would `ensure a more efficient service for litigants and the legal profession'. Does the government still stand by your statement in light of the minutes circulated by the Chief Executive Officer of the Family Court on 23 April this year, which advised that the loss of funding would result in a dramatic cut to services, including: the reduction of judicial circuits by some 30 per cent, the reduction in the number of conciliation conferences by 50 per cent, and the cancella tion of the delay reduction programs at the Parramatta and Melbourne registries? How do you even try to justify these cuts to the many families in crisis, particularly those in rural and regional areas, that will be affected by your cuts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President—

ANSWER.PARA: An incident having occurred in the gallery—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Please remove those people from the gallery.

—Thank you, Mr President, and I appreciate your taking the opportunity to keep order in this place, and I will take the opportunity to remind members opposite of what the now defeated Prime Minister, who was so proud of his policies that he slunk quietly out the back door, said to people like that last time he got the opportunity. Do you know what he said to them? He said, `Ah, go and get a job.' So you ought to reflect on that and just ask yourselves—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I suggest you might be better to get on with the answer.

—Yes, I will, Mr President, but I do think that members opposite should ask themselves whether that kind of attitude that permeated through to the whole community had anything to do with their comprehensive loss and with them being the party that Australia has comprehensively rejected.

ANSWER.PARA: Turning to your question, Senator, I have not seen the memo that the chief executive officer, or whomever it is that you mentioned, has released. I will take the opportunity to get a look at the memo. I will ask the Attorney-General what he wants to tell you in relation to the allegations in that memo and, when the Attorney-General has an answer, I will give it back to you.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is amazing. I table the memo—
—Order! Just a take a seat for a while and we will wait for some quiet.

—Everyone has seen the memo, and I will table it. In the light of the other cuts announced, such as the closure of the Bendigo and Mackay sub-registries and the reduction of Family Court judges in Tasmania from two to one following the retirement of one of those judges later this year, will the minister explain to the communities of Bendigo, Mackay and Tasmania as a whole how these cuts will make the Family Court more `efficient', given that that was her statement? Also, what do you say to those family law court staff who will lose their jobs because of your policies?
—Order! Before you start, Senator Vanstone, are you wishing to table that document, Senator Bolkus?
—You need to seek leave.
—I was about to make that point, Senator Hill. You need to seek leave to table that document, Senator Bolkus.
—I am just trying to help Senator Vanstone, Mr President.
—You need to seek leave.
—I seek leave to table the document.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Sooner or later, Senator Bolkus, you are going to cotton on to the opportunities, and lack thereof, of being in opposition, and you will not bother to ask—
—You will have to do a bit better than you are doing now.

—I hope in your case it is later, but it might be sooner. I intend to ensure that you have plenty of time to learn this lesson and plenty of time, once you have learnt it, to keep exercising the skills you acquire as being a shadow minister and in opposition. One of the skills you will learn is not to bother asking a supplementary question if it is quite clear that you are not going to get any further information. Even someone with your—
—Mr President, on a point of order: that is not a standing order that she is invoking. If in fact I was actually in genuine need of information I would not ask her in the first place.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Mr President, I raise a further point of order. When we were on the other side, Mr President, you constantly reminded us not to involve ourselves in frivolous points of order. Today we have had numerous frivolous points of order. You told us not to engage in that and I would suggest that you encourage them not to engage in frivolous points of order.
—I have just said there is no point of order.

—In light of the senator's indication that, if he wanted a sensible answer he would not bother to ask me, it might not yet have occurred to the senator that he no longer has a department to administer. One of his roles—to put out your hand and take your pay cheque—is to try to do a job seriously. You should not waste the Senate's time if you don't really want a sensible answer. (Time expired)

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We will wait again for some quiet.

—Thank you, Mr President, I will wait as long as you require. Will the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Robert Hill, please inform the Senate about the good news concerning the positive business and consumer reaction to the election of the Howard government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I have even got some notes. What I did notice this morning was that the opposition, the Labor Party, has in fact slumped in the polls since it lost. It sounds as if it is not even doing the job of opposition well. Anyway, it will improve. It will have plenty of time to practice.

ANSWER.PARA: Certainly there is good news around since the election of the Howard government. Optimism is increasing. It is pleasing to read reports from the Australian Institute of Company Directors and KPMG this morning talking about an expected improvement in the economy over the next six months. Senator Kernot will be pleased to hear that. This is just one of a number of encouraging signs of consumer and business confidence since the election.

I remind you of the rise of four per cent in consumer confidence in March, according to Morgan research and the Westpac Melbourne Institute monthly survey of consumer confidence, which reached its highest point for about two years. The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry March quarterly survey shows a surge of confidence with a 20 per cent net balance of firms predicting an improvement in business conditions under a Howard government. The Australian Bureau of Statistics survey of business expectations also predicted a rise in profit expectations which was good. The ACCI March survey of investor confidence showed that almost half of businesses expect conditions to improve.

Why they expect that is that the Howard government has had the courage to attack the real deficiencies of the former government—Labor's economic program. In particular, it has had the courage to attack the forecast budget deficit of $8 billion, that that was hidden from us.

TALK.START.PARA: —They expected that in January, mate. If the economy is strong, that comes back to us.

—It is interesting Senator Cook is interjecting because I remind him of what he said in September 1995, `Our budget will continue to move into greater surplus.' A greater surplus to $8 billion down. Well done, Senator Cook. There is confidence that business is being restored because they know that the Howard government is now addressing the issue, and it is addressing it for the first time by being prepared to cut public expenditure. It is doing that. It is bringing in industrial relations reform to encourage both employers and employees to work together for mutually beneficial outcomes.
—Rubbish, rubbish!

—It is not rubbish at all. Why do they feel more hopeful under us? It is because you failed them and we have a program that can restore confidence in the economy and we can do something to start eating into your worst legacy—mass unem ployment, which, Senator Burns, you should be ashamed of.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Minister, given that your government has put up in lights its intention to amend the Native Title Act, particularly in respect of extinguishing native title on pastoral leases, will you, as Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Affairs, give this Senate an undertaking today that the previous government's commitment to fund $1.4 billion into the land acquisition fund for the acquisition of land for Aboriginal people—and that fund, as you know, commenced in June last year—will be maintained under your government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —That's a nice try.
—We are proud of our record.
—No, it was a good try. Give him a go. Don't interject on him.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I know that Senator Herron accepts the fact that the whole question of native title or Mabo, as it has come to be known in terms of a simple word that has now become synonymous with it, is very, very important to Aboriginal people. I am interested in your reluctance to commit yourself to that previous commitment when you are so busy creating publicity about actually extinguishing rights that Aboriginal people might have. Is the view that you put in debate last year—that is, when you identified yourself with the average Australian—that the average Australian believed that Mabo stood for `money available, barristers only', still your view, minister, or do you now concede that that was a gross over-simplification of what Mabo stands for?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have been misquoted. I said that was a quote at the time. I did not say that I believed that. I said that was what the quote was, Senator Collins. You look back at the Hansard —and I am happy to produce the Hansard for you. Having said that, you have also misrepresented the government. We have not said that we are doing that. You well know that Senator Minchin on my right is consulting with the community, with the indigenous community, with the pastoralists, with the mining community—everybody who has an interest in the Mabo legislation—to make it more workable. You will recall, senator, that at the time I said in relation to it that if there were no amendments to that legislation it would be years before it became workable. Here we are two years later and what decisions have been reached?
—You are not extinguishing native title on pastoral leases?

—I said there were consultations in relation to it. That is still on the table, as you know. Senator Minchin is going around seeking consultations with everybody. There will be a working paper produced. (Time expired)

—My question is to Senator Newman, Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Minister, you have been a strong advocate for the representation of women in parliament over your time in parliament and before you got into parliament. In the light of the 2 March election results, what is your view about the current level of female representation in the federal parliament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, Senator Patterson herself has long had a longstanding interest and involvement in matters relating to the status of women, and so I thank her very much for her question. We on this side of the chamber are very proud to have seen the influx of so many women into the federal parliament.
—How many?

—Let me tell you, Senator Vanstone. The results of the election prove that Labor's quota, which has never looked secure, is now entirely remote. I will come to the figures later. The sad thing is how unwilling some members opposite are to acknowledge how important it is to Australia that so many women have come into the federal parliament. I think that when you have a spokesman for the Labor Party saying, `Oh, but they're all going to lose. They're not going to be here very long,' it shows a grudging and envious spirit, if you like, to something which they aspired to—certainly the women in the Labor Party aspired to—but have not been able to achieve.

ANSWER.PARA: The sad thing is that the Labor Party does not look like ever achieving their goal. They have one more federal election before the year 2002 in which they have to get 35 per cent of winnable seats. At the last election they had 12 seats where people were retiring which they could have filled with women. Two seats had women retiring and they did not fill one of them with a woman. How can they possibly smirk over on that side of the chamber, Mr President? But on this side the Liberal Womens' Forum under Dame Margaret Guilfoyle helped women to learn techniques and to gain confidence in applying for preselection and then election by the public. It was a proven method that worked: giving assistance to those who are interested in standing for parliament. That is going to give you long‐term—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—What about Blaxland?

—No, we are not going to get a woman in Blaxland—we know that already. The factions have already got that delineated. Mary Easson looks as if she is going completely. From 1 July we will have 23 women in the Senate out of 76 senators. That means we are up to 30.2 per cent in this chamber. All senators should be pleased that we in the Senate have got that.

BREAK.PARA: The number of women in the House of Representatives is now 23 out of a total of 148. That is 15.5 per cent. This means that, as from 1 July, the total number of women in the federal parliament will be 46 out of a total of 224 seats. That is 20.5 per cent. We are proud of this, because we brought those women into the parliament. We added to the women who are already here. We are developing the critical mass that is so important.

Any criticism from the other side is mean‐spirited and envious. If you are fair dinkum you would be doing something practical about getting women in and not going on with this nonsense about quotas which only rebounds on the people who are chosen through the quotas. It is tokenistic. The Labor Party goes through these mechanistic and rhetorical measures but they do not achieve results.
Remember former Senator Peter Walsh who used to say you could tell the difference between Liberal and Labor women—one lot got chosen on merit!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, Senator Short. Yesterday I asked Senator Short a question about the government's intention to slash $985 million out of the IT budget. Senator Short dismissed my concerns as `absolutely speculative'. My question to Senator Short today is: isn't it true that, on 15 February, Mr Costello announced a cut of $985 million to the government's IT budget as a `savings measure' to fund opposition promises made before the election? Does the government intend to keep this promise or, in view of your answer, Senator Short, are all your election commitments to be regarded as `absolutely speculative'?

—My answer is precisely what it was yesterday, and that is that the government will be announcing its decisions in relation to expenditure and revenue items in the budget on 20 August—the day the budget is introduced. Until that time the Labor Party opposite can whistle in the wind in terms of seeking information on particular items. They are all budget matters which will be announced in the budget.
—I seek leave to table a press release by the shadow Treasurer, Mr Peter Costello, on 15 February 1996 entitled `Meeting our commitments', in particular page 3 of that press release.
—Senator Short is confusing election commitments with a budget process, so—
—What is he doing?
—Are you asking a supplementary question?
—Yes. He is confusing election commitments with budget process, so I will give him another chance. Does the government stand by the commitment of Mr Costello on 15 February or not?

—The government stands entirely on its commitment to take measures which will repair the economic vandalism to the finances of this nation that were undertaken by your government in the most deceitful way. These actions led to there being a black hole of $8,000 million in the budget figures. Right until election day the then government refused to come clean about this $8,000 million black hole and open the books to the Australian people. The Leader of the Opposition, the then Minister for Finance, is absolutely and inexcusably responsible for this black hole.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Minister, yesterday in question time you intimated that Australia has the highest local telephone call rates in the world. Are you aware that the March survey by cost analysts NUS International showed that Australian local call prices are lower than comparable countries such as Belgium and the Netherlands? Are you also aware that the Bureau of Industry Economics has said that Australia's household phone rental rates are comparatively low and, in particular, are about half of New Zealand's, where home phone rentals have risen by 30 per cent since privatisation? Finally, what lessons do you draw from the first eight years of privatisation in Britain, where local call rates rose by 27 per cent and domestic installation costs rose by a massive 61 per cent, with only government regulation preventing further rises?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact is that New Zealand has free local residential calls.
—They always have.
—Indeed. That is why—
—That has nothing to do with it.

—If the parrot brigade will listen to the answer, I will explain it. The reason they have very high access charges is to compensate for the fact that they have free local residential calls. You cannot compare the access charges of a country that has no local residential calls with a country that has both. Therefore, if you look at Australia's access charges under NUS, I think you will find that we are about the fifth highest out of the 12‐day survey. I have not seen the latest one, but it is consistent with the one before that. NUS has done consistent surveys on local call charges in recent years which have shown that Australia—I think they reduced the rate of 25c to 23.8c to average it out—effectively has the highest local call charges in the world.

ANSWER.PARA: It is rather sad that you want to quibble about whether or not the rate is 25c or 24c or whether it is the highest or maybe only the second highest. The fact is that it is far too high and there are ways in which you can get these things down very substantially. If you look at the New Zealand experience, for example, you will find that 10 years ago their level of total factor productivity was well below that of Telstra's. Over the last decade they have doubled the rate of growth and they are now performing much better than us. That just happens to coincide with the privatisation process which commenced in 1988 and, of course, the opening up to very dramatic competition, even without a regulator. Their regulatory costs are much lower than ours and their levels of efficiency are much higher than ours.

PARA.BREAK: We have all learnt from the British experience; we borrowed Austel. One of the reasons why we introduced consumer guarantee prop osals in our election commitments was that we were concerned to ensure that those benefits flowed on—that you did not simply find even worse quality of service as a result of any major changes that you might make. We are actually going to require penalties to be paid if installation and maintenance calls are not made on time. I do not regard it as satisfactory for Telstra to agree to come to your premises. You take the day off waiting for them and then they say, `Sorry, we couldn't make it.' We are actually putting in place a very rigid and effective customer regime.

ANSWER.PARA: Do you know what I find deeply disturbing about this whole debate? When the Democrats were asked, `What further customer protections would you like in relation to the privatisation of Telstra?', they said, `We're not really interested in that at all; we are simply opposed. In other words, we have a blind ideological commitment based on 1960s notions of natural monopolies. We are not concerned about how you could deliver the goods for consumers.' Go off and study the rest of the world. You will find that they are all going down that privatisation track for the one very good reason that it has enormous consumer benefits. You would say that the rest of the world is out of step. You would say that they all have $8 billion holes and that is why they are doing it. They are all doing it because they know that you can achieve dramatic efficiencies. The only way you will get costs down and quality of service up is to make the sorts of cuts that Telstra itself recognises needs to be made.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many will they sack?
—They talk to their annual report about a 30 per cent unit cost reduction over the next two years. Do you support that? As a failed Telecom technician, do you support that? (Time expired)

—I wish to ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Firstly, I wish to say that I find what the minister has just said quite offensive. After saying that—and I do find it offensive—given the evidence from overseas, which the minister must have read because I have, that it is regulation rather than competition that delivers reduced local call prices and dramatic efficiencies, will the minister be issuing instructions to Telstra to deliver lower prices to domestic consumers while he has the opportunity to do so?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —The first statement is categorically wrong. New Zealand does not have a regulator. You ought to know that. They rely on the commerce act, which is the trade practices equivalent. They rely entirely on negotiations in the market place. As a result, they have achieved enormous efficiencies and very significant reductions in local call charges.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have forgotten the second part of your question; you may wish to kindly remind me.
—Lower prices while you have time.

—Oh, yes, while we still have time. You do not have much longer to wait before Optus comes into the market with local call charges. I think you will find that they will be offering significant discounts. Once they do that, Telstra will no longer be able to charge monopoly rates.
—That will reduce the price of Telstra.

—Indeed, that might be your mind‐set, but that is not our priority. We want to see efficiencies in the system; we do not want to maximise revenue first. We have a very different approach. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. Has the minister for transport called in members of the board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority to resign? If so, what reasons does the minister give for such a course of action?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President. As I understand it, no, they have not been called in. It is a four‐member board, as you would be aware, Senator Forshaw. The Minister for Transport and Regional Develop ment, Mr Sharp, phoned each member of the board personally—
—Called them up?

—Called them up, yes, or dressed them down; I don't know. All I am saying is that I understand that he did not call them into his office. He simply rang up and reminded them of our pre‐election commitments and asked them to honour that. He did not do that because of the fact that the chairman of the commission might have been the federal Labor candidate for Lowe once; he did it because we take the view that it is very important—

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Robert Ray interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you paid for these days? Sitting back up there pontificating? You might be able to beat Bolkus's TA if you really try. The fact is that, unlike you lot—

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Bob Collins interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You ought to be ashamed of yourself—all those specious reasons you trotted out for the east‐west runway not being able to open up. The fact is that we think it is very important to have people with aviation experience on the CASA. We do not have that at the present time. We therefore took the view that it was very important to be able to have that expertise.

ANSWER.PARA: That is why Mr Sharp very publicly but very politely made it plain that we did not have confidence in a board that was not constituted in the best possible way. We took that view prior to the election. We did not simply sneak up on them afterwards, having said all nice things to them beforehand. We made it plain that we put safety first.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could you take the same attitude to the High Court?
—Actually, there is a constitution that stops that, Nick, so it's a bit harder.
—Have you thought about it?
—Changing the constitution? If you want to support us on constitutional change give us a yell.
—I ask the minister a supplementary question: is it the intention of the government to appoint Mr Dick Smith to the board of the authority?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no knowledge of whom Mr Sharp might have in mind but, undoubtedly, he would be wanting to appoint people with aviation experience. If we are going to be confronted with the current impasse, Mr Sharp has already obtained the Prime Minister's agreement to priority for the introduction of legislation to amend the Civil Aviation Act 1988 to allow us to fulfil our election commitment.

ANSWER.PARA: I can assure you that at the end of the day, if we are in a position to make those necessary and important changes, the people we will put on board will not be the usual party hacks, old mates or branch networkers that you might like to appoint to government authorities. The people we will appoint to a board that is charged with the very important responsibility of oversighting civil aviation will be people with the requisite experience. It is a pity you did not recognise that long ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President.
—I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .
—I have called Senator Knowles.

—Mr President, my question is addressed to Senator Short, who is the Minister representing the Treasurer. One of our government election promises was a family tax incentive. Minister, could you explain to the Senate how this initiative will give recognition to the families so badly ignored by Labor, particularly those with very young children and single parents.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Knowles for that question because it demonstrates the vast gulf that exists between Labor and the Howard government in their attitudes towards families. Under the Labor government Australian families were absolutely ravaged so far as their living standards were concerned. In contrast, the new government has the well being of Australian families at the very highest point of its priorities.

ANSWER.PARA: As I said, under Labor the wellbeing of Australian families was ravaged. Real wages fell. Those on the lowest incomes saw their earnings fall the most. Middle Australia found it harder to make ends meet and to save for the future.

The current account deficit and the foreign debt forced up interest rates to amongst the highest in the world, which hurt every Australian family. Average monthly mortgage repayments rose by nearly 50 per cent during Labor's term in government and many Australians have seen the value of their most prized possession, the family home, fall.

During Labor's 13 years there was a dramatic increase in taxes payable and that impacted heavily on every family. We all know the infamous promises of tax cuts with which the then government lied its way back into office in 1993, only to break those promises and deceive every Australian family after the election.

Mr President, the coalition believes that families are the very best social welfare system that has ever been devised. One of the greatest challenges of modern family life is to balance effectively work commitments and goals against family responsibilities and aspirations. Any credible family policy must be directed at helping families to achieve that balance.

The coalition's $1 billion family tax package does just that. It demonstrates our commitment to Australian families, particularly low and middle income families. It will give families greater incentive and more choice about how they balance their work and their family responsibilities.

The family package is a two‐pronged initiative and it will deliver assistance to families with children, commencing on 1 January 1997. It will benefit all types of Australian families—working couples with children, single income families and single parent families. It also recognises the extra cost of very young children.

There will be two forms of assistance available to eligible families on the basis of income testing, with one being based on the number of children in the family. As to the matter Senator Knowles particularly asked about, there will be an additional level of assistance available to single income families with a child under the age of five. The policy package is designed to restore the wellbeing of every Australian family.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—The answer to your question yesterday is no. Have you forgotten the question you asked yesterday?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

QUESTION.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Short), to a question without notice asked by Senator Sherry today, relating to the economy.

Senator Short showed that he was totally unprepared not only for my question but for the range of economic questions put to him today by the opposition. Since he could not give me an answer to my question, for his edification I have obtained the information from the library. Australia's tax revenue as a percentage of GDP in 1993 was 28.7 per cent—second lowest to Turkey. If we look through a list of the revenue statistics for 24 OECD countries, we see that Australia has the second lowest tax revenue as a percentage of gross domestic product. Let us look at outlays, which the new government is busily slashing in its slash and burn approach to the budget. Australia's outlays as a percentage of GDP is 37.3 per cent—the second lowest only to the United States of America. Yet we have accusations from the new government that taxation was too high under the former Labor government and that expenditure was too high under the former Labor government. Nothing can be further from the truth.

I apologise for not having given a copy of these tables to Senator Short. I seek leave to incorporate a copy of OECD Revenue Statistics and of the OECD Economic Outlook for December 1995 which shows the percentage of nominal gross domestic product total outlays.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —We had some more good economic news today that Senator Short did not refer to. It is always the bad news that he refers to. He never attributes any good news to the former Labor government. It was interesting to note today that the seasonally adjusted current account deficit and the trend estimate was down 3 per cent. It is the lowest figure since March 1994. But there was no mention of this by Senator Short. There was no attributing that to the record and the performance of the former Labor government.

ANSWER.PARA: All you do is pick up bad news to suit your circumstances—to slash and burn, to reintroduce Fightback. That is all you do—pick up bad news in order to destroy the programs on education and health and to destroy the jobs of public servants in this country.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHORT
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me pick up the final point that Senator Sherry was making. He was saying that today's balance of payments result of $1.5 billion was a good result. Anyone on either side of the chamber who thinks that a monthly balance of payments deficit of $1.5 billion is a good result has no right to represent any economic portfolio in this parliament. It is still a disastrously high result. It is good that the deficit is falling; we welcome that. I readily acknowledge that. But to be complacent about the balance of payments and the external accounts of this country when we happen to have a balance of payments figure which, annualised, still gives a balance of payments deficit of $18 billion absolutely defies comprehension.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me make a few points about the figures that Senator Sherry was talking about. It is very difficult, as I am sure Senator Sherry acknowledges, to make comparisons of the tax regimes of different countries. There are the questions of what is included and what is excluded and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree.

—I am glad to see you acknowledging that. My first point is that it is very difficult to make accurate international comparisons. My second point is that I did not deny today that, within the span of OECD countries, Australia is down towards the lower end of taxation. I have never denied that. This government has never denied that. But that is a difficult comparison to make accurately. It also totally ignores the tax regimes of many of our main competitor countries—the developing nations of Asia and South East Asia. It is those countries that are the biggest competitive threat and that also have a competitive advantage. So you cannot ignore the wider than OECD tax regime comparisons. The point that I was making to Senator Sherry today was that, under the former government, taxes and expenditure rose inexorably and there was little or no attempt to keep them under control.
—That is not true.

—You say that it is not correct. In the last year of the Fraser government, income tax as a proportion of GDP was 16.3 per cent. In the year that we are in now, 1995‐96, it is anticipated on the budget figures that, as a percentage of GDP, income tax will be 17.6 per cent.
—He is anticipating the figure. Make up a number.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —Make up a number, you say. That is what you spent your whole life doing. That is income tax. So far as sales tax is concerned, it has gone from 2.0 to 2.9 per cent. Indeed, today, as a result of 13 years of Labor, the proportion of income and sales tax to GDP is higher than it was even at the height of the Whitlam years, those years which wreaked such economic havoc in Australia that we are, in some respects, still living with today.

ANSWER.PARA: We will be living with the legacy of the vandalism of your 13 years in government for many years to come. That is the point I was making today. Your party has always been a high‐taxing, high‐spending government which has reduced the opportunity, incentive and choice of average individuals and families to do the things that they are best able to do. You believe that a big state and a big government overrides the interests of individuals. That is shown in tax and expenditure statistics. That is the point I was making, and I reaffirm it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I put the question:

ANSWER.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President!
—I think it is our turn for the call, isn't it?
—Senator Sherry moved that the Senate take note of an answer. Senator Short has spoken. I would then call somebody from the government benches.

—The motion is to take note of another answer. The motion to take note of the first answer came from the opposition side. As I understand the procedure, the next motion should be the right of the government side.
—That has not been the practice.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

QUESTION.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Short), to a question without notice asked by Senator Cook today, relating to the effect of proposed budget cuts on information technology.

In question time today I asked Senator Short a very direct and succinct question about where does the government stand on its election promises. What I was met with was, in the first place, a reply that he stands by the answer he gave yesterday. Yesterday he did not give an answer, so I guess he stands by nothing at all. But today we never got an answer either. What we got was a confusion—and it may well be that the minister is in fact confused on this point—about an election undertaking and the budget process. I am not asking about the budget process; I am asking about the election undertaking. The election undertaking was quite clear and specific.

In question time today I referred to this press release by Peter Costello, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and then shadow Treasurer, which he put down on 15 February 1996. It was headed, `Meeting our commitments'. Specifically, I table page three of that which is headed, `reduce information technology expenditure'. Then there is a list of financial implications showing a cut in the IT budget by the government of, in 1996‐97, $350 million; in 1997‐98, $335 million and in 1998‐99, $300 million, a total over the three‐year period of $985 million.

That was a commitment given by the opposition prior to the election in an effort to demonstrate to the Australian people that they could fund their election promises. Yesterday I asked a specific question: what studies did the opposition at the time undertake to see, if you slash information technology by that amount, what efficiencies that you could have achieved do you forgo, what services that you could have delivered to the Australian community do you forgo, or did you simply think of a figure and cut it?

These sorts of decisions are not simply decisions of funding. These are decisions in which cost benefit analysis must be undertaken if you are serious about managing government responsibility. There ought to be, therefore, a consideration of what limitation on efficiency and services there will be by reducing the IT budget in this way.

PARA.BREAK: The opposition's position is clear. We do not want these cuts to occur. We do not think they should occur. I also wanted to know from the government whether or not they had conferred with the Australian information technology industry. It is a major supplier of services to the government. A cut of this nature will devastate it. It is a highly competi tive industry worldwide. Australia has a very competitive position in that industry. In part its position of competitiveness is achieved because it is able to win government contracts in this country. If you deny it that opportunity its economies of scale suffer and its ability to win markets in the world is reduced accordingly.

QUESTION.PARA: This is not just `a savings measure'. This is a measure which reduces services that the government can provide, efficiencies that the government can achieve. By this cut you do cut off your nose to spite your face. It is not a saving. Reducing these expenditures is indeed a cost. More than that, they create the prospect of job loss in information technology industries. If Australia is not world competitive in that field, given that we are in an information age and an information revolution, then we will be importing foreign made computers and foreign made information technology, which will blow the current account deficit right off the face of the earth. This is a serious matter.

All I want to know is: does the government intend to honour the commitment it gave before the election to make these cuts? I would like to hear a big no, but, since yesterday my inquiry was described as entirely speculative, I simply ask. This is not a speculative matter. You have said on the record that the black letter of what you have proposed is that you will do this. Are you going to do it or are you not? Do we have to simply wait for four months because you confuse an election undertaking with the budget process? Do we have to wait four months to find out? What does the Australian information technology industry do in the meantime? Does it hold back investment or does it proceed with it? Does it continue to prepare applications for government tender or does it not? Do you put the whole industry in stall, ultimately leading to free‐fall and a lack of competitiveness? What do you do?

The fact that there is a deafening refusal to answer that question is a major condemnation of the government and a position in which the government is clearly offside with a leading sector of the Australian business community, and a leading area of Australian industry which is the hope of this country. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Senator MICHAEL BAUME

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

QUESTION.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), to a question without notice asked by the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Kernot) today, relating to the economy.

Senator Kernot did an extraordinary thing here today. She produced a document and then misquoted it in a way deliberately aimed, it seemed to me—I could be open to correction—to mislead the chamber. Senator Kernot said that the Treasury's latest economic document indicated that the budget black hole of $8 billion was overstated and would be reduced. That was the clear implication of what she said.

TALK.START.PARA: —Had `cast doubt.' That is what I said.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Senator MICHAEL BAUME

TALK.START.PARA: —`Cast doubt,' she said. This is the sort of doubt that, when you read the document, is no doubt whatsoever. I will read from the document for Senator Kernot's benefit and the benefit of the chamber. The document says of the slowdown:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . the indications are that it is temporary . . .
This is at page 1. I thought you might have been able at least to get through page 1. The report says:
. . . the indications are that it—
that is, the slowdown in growth—
is temporary and growth should strengthen during the course of the calendar year.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what I said. I quoted that in my question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Senator MICHAEL BAUME

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you just be quiet and listen. It goes on to say:

ANSWER.PARA: Divergent movements appear to have continued in the first quarter of 1996 . . . As the impact of the contractionary influences from the stock and dwelling cycle wanes, stronger growth in activity should resume over 1996‐97 . . .
It then goes on to say this, which Senator Kernot magically missed:

BREAK.PARA: This profile, incorporating a period of temporary weakness, was implied in the economic forecasts released by the Treasurer on 12 March 1996 as background to a statement of the Government's fiscal policy intentions. It is also consistent with expectations recorded in recent business surveys.

In other words, this booklet that just came out clearly shows that these factors were taken into account. Senator Kernot tried to misrepresent that to this chamber. I think that is just disgraceful, but no doubt it meets Senator Kernot's particular political requirements.

The fact is that, as this document reveals, on 12 March 1996 the Treasurer released a revised estimate of the 1995‐96 Commonwealth budget position, revised projections of the budget position over the medium term and the government's intended strategy for reducing the budget deficit. The revised budget figures contained in the table include the impact of policies announced by the previous government but not the underlying budget balances for the out years. The document states:

. . . the underlying budget balances for the outyears similarly reflects weaker economic parameters and in addition the impact of projected public debt interest payments of the upward revisions to the Budget deficits over the forecast period.
The document then goes on to say, on page 7:
The Treasurer announced the objective of returning the Budget to an underlying balance in 1997‐98 . . .
In this very document it says:
. . . this will involve measures to reduce the Budget deficit by $4 billion in 1996‐97 and a further $4 billion in 1997‐98.

This is not revised. There is no resiling from the $8 billion. Not on your nelly. This document confirms what was said to the Treasurer and the revised budget deficit expectation—the $8 billion dollar blow‐out. It confirms it. It does not in any way diminish it.

PARA.BREAK: Senator Kernot should be ashamed of herself. Another matter that is of significance in that document which should be brought to the attention of the Senate is that on a national accounts basis growth in unit labour costs increased significantly over the second half of 1995. This reflected on the one hand an increase in average earnings stemming from a pick up of wage pressures in 1995 com bined with increases in various other things—superannuation entitlements, and so on.

BREAK.PARA: So they are warning, if you like, that there is an underlying CPI inflation problem and that the longer term outlook for inflation will be heavily dependent on movements in labour costs and the stance of monetary policy. Thank heavens we have a government now that will respond properly to those challenges and those risks. I hope we do not have to put up with the sort of misleading nonsense we have just heard from Senator Kernot.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —A couple of things need to be made clear. We are asking questions about economic forecasting. We are asking questions about how you can say in January that by the end of the year, especially by August, you will definitely have an $8 billion black hole. You cannot. That is the point which I think needs to be made.

ANSWER.PARA: The key question is: are the forecasts right? The second question we have been asking in question time is: is the $8 billion spending cut the appropriate response? That is all we are asking. If I can find the appropriate page in today's Treasury Economic Round‐up, I would like to point out that Treasury admits its GDP growth forecasts have been out by an average of 1.25 per cent over the last two decades. Do you know what that translates to? In economic terms that is a $6 billion margin of error.

TALK.START.PARA: —What if it goes the other way?

—That is right. All I asked Senator Hill was whether the government was prepared to adjust their $8 billion figure in the light of revised forecasts if those forecasts were revised downwards. That is the issue because a lot of people are having their lives, their livelihoods particularly, terminated based on this entirely imprecise science of forecasting when Treasury itself has said, `Yes, we have to admit this. Actually, we've got quite a good record but we have been out by 1.25 per cent over the past two decades.' All I am saying is that surely the government can give us a reassurance that if the forecasting is revised downwards it will act humanely.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHORT
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Is Senator Kernot seriously suggesting that every time there is a report that economic growth might change from the present official level of forecasts you should revise all your other economic statistics, including your budget parameters?
—That's exactly what you've done.
—That's what you keep saying.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —That is absolutely wrong, Senator Wheelwright and Senator Murphy. We have said that, based on the latest official forecasts, there is a black hole of $8 billion in the budget bottom line. If you do not believe that there is an $8 billion hole in the budget, you are saying that you do not believe the official forecasts that are on the public record and reinforced, as Senator Baume says, in the Treasury's bulletin of yesterday. Nothing that the bulletin article said yesterday in any way contradicts the official forecasts that are there.

ANSWER.PARA: Yesterday's document does not provide an official revision of the forecasts. It does not say that at all. It simply reaffirms the underlying basis of the existing forecasts, and it is the existing forecasts on which the $8 billion black hole is based. There is no prevarication about this in any way at all. The $8 billion bottom line figure follows automatically on the government's official figures, which are based on those from Treasury. We are saying that until such time as forecasts change, and of course forecasts can change in the future, the only way in which any government can operate is on the basis of the existing forecasts. That is the only way in which government can operate responsibly.

What Senator Kernot was putting to the Senate today, with great respect to you, Senator Kernot, was highly misleading because she gave the impression that somehow or other the Treasury was now saying something different from what it said in the release of the official forecasts, on which the government's $8 billion deficit has been based. That is quite simply wrong, with respect. I think you have misread and misunderstood the Treasury bulletin document.
Senator Patterson interjecting—

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I am being very generous. It is early in the life of the new parliament, so I am giving Senator Kernot the benefit of the doubt on this second day. If she does the same thing next week or in a few weeks time, we will be a little less generous. The fact is that what she put to the Senate today was quite wrong. There is an $8 billion budget deficit. It is a deficit of deceit by the previous government. It is a deficit that it knew about before the election. The key role was very much played by the now Leader of the Opposition, the then Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley), in deliberately covering up the true state of the previous government's finances. (Time expired)

ANSWER.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—As the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Short) has thought that there is time for warnings, I want to put on the record at this early stage of the parliament that, as I understood it, the Liberal Party's traditional position about taking note of answers had been that it was a time for opposition senators. They made that point very strongly to us.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think we should have any hard and fast rules for the minister to use up 10 minutes of the 30 minutes allocated for taking notice when he is going to speak to the MPI that comes on later today. It is perhaps excessive. We might have an informal consideration on how it is going to operate.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are asking for a better performance from us than what yourselves gave; is that what you are asking?
—Yes.
—Okay, we will do our best.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Sherry proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The government's deliberate attempt to create undue and needless anxiety in the Australian community in its ideological pursuit of $8 billion in spending cuts.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The new government has come into office professing honesty and integrity. But one of its first actions has been to make incorrect assertions about an $8 billion budget deficit. In fact, it does not just make an assertion, it boasts about an $8 billion so-called black hole. It is using this as an excuse to slash and burn not just public service jobs but a variety of public programs, like education and health. We are going to find out the true extent of that slash and burn, as ministers keep reiterating, in August when the budget is delivered.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of aspects of the approach of the government that I want to deal with today, as do my colleagues Senator Cook and Senator Wheelwright. I want to place on record and reiterate Labor's economic record, since it is being subjected to some considerable rewriting of history—a rewriting of history that the new government was very fond of accusing the former Prime Minister of doing.

I also want to examine very briefly the record of the Prime Minister (John Howard). If we have a black hole, you have a black void. Go and ask an astronomer what the difference is between the two. Your contribution to a black hole under John Howard as Treasurer, up until 1983, was massive compared to any alleged black hole we had.
In terms of our general economic performance, I would like to quote from a speech, which appears in the Reserve Bank bulletin, given by the head of the Reserve Bank, Mr Fraser. It says:
By the standards of other developed countries we have not done badly. The economy has expanded by more than a third over the past decade and a proper interpretation of the data—
I emphasise `a proper interpretation of the data'—

—as well as casual observation—suggests that the vast majority of Australians are better off today than ever before. To be distracted by concerns that other countries (including some of our Asian neighbours)—
as Senator Short alleged earlier—
have caught up or surpassed us is to confuse the issues at stake.

I would also like to refer to the latest economic indicators in the Economist . Interestingly, of the dozen countries surveyed, Australia—surprise, surprise—has been at the top of the economic growth league over the last year. Australia is at the top of the economic growth league when compared to other comparable OECD western countries. That is a very impressive record. I will seek leave to incorporate that when I conclude my speech.

We have generally had good economic performance at a time, I might say, of severe drought and at a time when prices for our raw materials, particularly minerals, were very low in the world marketplace. We have had a good growth economy, particularly compared to the rest of the world. Even at the bottom of the business cycle, which is where we are at the present time, we have had economic growth running at just over three per cent. We have created on average 220,000 new jobs each year. That is a significant record.

Also connected with this has been an essential restructuring of the economy focused on export growth. An ANZ bulletin—which I was attempting to find; I do not have it in front of me at the moment—highlights the important transition of the Australian economy and the increase in export growth, particularly to Asia, over the last 10 years.

Inflation has been a very major constraint on the growth of the Australian economy, particularly in the last Liberal government. But under the Labor government, over the last 13 years, we have been able to reduce inflation to a target band of two per cent to three per cent, and perhaps lower. Looking at the figures that were released about 10 days ago of 0.4 per cent for the quarter, we may be able to maintain inflation in a lower band than that.

A lot has been said about the current account, and certainly it could be better. We could have a more comfortably low current account. It is currently approximately 4½ per cent of gross domestic product, but there has been a major improvement in recent times. It was approaching six per cent last year. The sorts of figures that were released today, which Senator Short and I referred to earlier, show a continuing downward trend.

A key to this, of course, is the issue of national savings. I highlight the introduction of the superannuation levy when we were in government. It has been adopted as a bipartisan policy. I will acknowledge that of the new government. They did not give us any credit for it. They opposed it bitterly when we introduced it. That will further enhance national saving, particularly when we get to the contribution of 15 per cent of total overall wages by the year 2001.

Whilst on the issue of wages, we had an accord, which the new government has torn up. The new government has said, `We don't need any agreement on wages. Let the market decide.' That is an enormous gamble that the new Prime Minister and his Treasurer, Peter Costello, are taking. If it fails and inflation goes up, interest rates will go up. The new government is gambling that inflation will not rise and is taking a gamble on every Australian family's mortgage. I will make some brief comment about John Howard's—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Howard to you.

—Prime Minister Howard's `black hole' remark. As I said, if we have got a black hole, you have a black void. The difference is that a black hole has some substance; a black void has nothing in it at all. When Mr Howard was last Treasurer, the projected deficit in 1983-84 was $9.6 billion, or about 4.9 per cent of our gross domestic product. What would that be in today's dollar terms? It is $24.5 billion. That is what John Howard left us from his time as Treasurer in 1983-84. The black void from John Howard, as I refer to it, was five times worse than the alleged void that we left.

BREAK.PARA: This issue of the $8 billion, this so-called hole, is merely an attempt to shift the blame onto Labor for what the new government is engaged in, to blame us for the massive reduction in programs, services and employment by a reduction of public service jobs. The shortfall is not $8 billion. It is much closer to $4.9 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are proud of that, are you?

—We are not proud of it. In large part the figure is due to many of the promises made by the coalition at the last election. My colleague Senator Wheelwright will talk about projections and forecasts in some detail.

BREAK.PARA: In addition to the coalition's promises, the other reason for this budget blow‐out has been the performance of the government, then in opposition, in this Senate. I think we have to refresh the memory of the now government about their performance in this Senate. In 1995-96, they knocked $265 million off our measures when we were in government. In 1996-97, the now government knocked over $2.5 billion of the then Labor government's budget, including airport sales, leasing proposals of $2 billion and building material proposals of $O.3 billion. When we went to the election there was a further $185 million worth of various measures held up in this Senate. When you take those sorts of billions of dollars into account, you see that the alleged $8 billion hole has been largely of the now government's own making.

I referred earlier to the new government's promises at the election, which are included within this $8 billion hole. One of the promises the new government made was to cut IT expenditure by $985 million over three years. We will be fascinated to see whether they can carry out a cut of $985 million in IT expenditure, particularly when there are going to be so many public servants retrenched or made redundant through the government's slash and burn policies.

We will be particularly interested in the other promise written into this so‐called $8 billion; that is, the savings of about $500 million through reductions in fraud and by the tightening of the activity tests. There were a range of other issues estimated by Finance prior to the election—I am sure Senator Short has seen the figures—which expose shortfalls in the new government's election commitments. They are some of the reasons we are faced with this so-called $8 billion hole.

Really, what is it all about? It is not about good economic management. It is about a new government implementing its philosophical approach, which was very well outlined in Fightback over three years ago. It is Fightback. That is what it is. Fightback wasn't dead and buried. You decided to be clever and smart. You went to the last election with Fightback in the bottom draw.

What I find fascinating about reading Fightback today is that many of the things you are doing now, particularly in cutting the Public Service, are in fact more severe than what is outlined in Fightback. So Fightback wasn't dead and buried. It was just put in the bottom draw and you took a politically smart position, as it turned out, to hide what you were going to do. That is the reality of both the cuts to the public service and the proposed cuts to government programs. That is why you are engaged in perhaps one of the biggest lies this country has ever seen. Repeat it over enough and often enough: $8 billion. That is why you have engaged—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHORT
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me at the outset correct one total inaccuracy.
—Only one?

—It is a big one. I want to nail Senator Sherry on this one. He claimed that, of the $8 billion Beazley black hole, a significant portion of it—I am not sure what he said; I think he said almost half of it—was due to the policy commitments of the coalition government. Let me draw his attention to the latest Treasury bulletin, Economic Roundup . On page 5 it says:

SPEECH.PARA: The revised budget figures—
those are the ones showing the $8 billion black hole—
contained in the table below include the impact of policies announced by the previous government, but not the election commitments of the coalition government.
I hope that Senator Sherry will take the first available opportunity to correct the totally false statement that he made during his introduction to this debate.

If Senator Sherry believes that returning the budget to balance is an ideological obsession, then it is no wonder that Labor left Australia's finances in ruins and why the Australian people so comprehensively rejected Labor on 2 March. His assertion is in the same league as his incredible inference today that, somehow or other, a monthly balance of payments deficit of $1.5 billion, an annual deficit rate of $18 billion, is somehow good news. If that is good news, I would hate to hear what Senator Sherry regards as bad news for the Australian economy and for the Australian people.

Senator Sherry claims that we are in ideological pursuit of $8 billion spending cuts, but then he says that there is not really an $8 billion black hole left by Mr Beazley and the outgoing government. No-one else in Australia believes you, Senator Sherry. Every commentator, from the government's own official forecasts down, accepts the unequivocal fact that there is an $8 billion hole in the budget—a hole that the Labor government said, right until election day, did not exist.

Indeed, on the contrary, your then Minister for Finance, now Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) was saying, `Everything is sweet, we are actually in surplus. The forward estimates show that we are going increasingly into surplus.' In fact, the forward estimates which the outgoing government knew existed were absolutely and totally the other way. They showed that the true situation was that the budget was going increasingly into deficit throughout the period of the forward estimates. There is absolutely no doubt that there is an $8 billion black hole. If there is anxiety in the community—and that is what is stated in the wording of Senator Sherry's matter of public importance today—it stems totally from Labor's ineptitude in having an irresponsible budget policy for many, many years.

The Labor Party cannot hide its head in the sand any longer, nor can Australians, as Labor would have them pretend to be able to do. We do have to address, seriously, honestly and openly, the problems that we have inherited as a result of the mismanagement of Labor's rule. The difficult position that the new government is in financially, in terms of the budget, is a direct result of the opposition leader's deceit as finance minister. That said, the coalition government has made it clear that we will keep faith with our commitment to provide assistance to those most in need, despite the enormity of the fiscal problem facing us.

The uncaring and irresponsible attitude to fiscal policy by Labor is the one thing that has created the problem that we now face. Labor got itself out of touch. It was unwilling or unable to face the challenges to get Australia on track. It seemed to live in cloud‐cuckoo‐land. Senator Cook, who I see is speaking later in this debate, was a leading architect of that through his ministerial portfolio. There were many others as well. Senator Sherry's claim in his MPI earlier today that a balanced budget is a mere ideological pursuit highlights the absolutely irresponsible cloud‐cuckoo‐land attitude of the Labor Party towards fiscal management and fiscal responsibility.

It is this Labor mind-set that has led to five consecutive underlying budget deficits, despite the fact that the economy has been in a growth phase for the last four years. If you are going to run huge underlying budget deficits at a time when you have a period of economic growth, then the inevitable consequence of that is that you are going to produce over the life of the economic cycle an absolutely huge, even greater, underlying deficit. Of course, that causes huge problems for interest rates, for inflation, for competition, for our ability to provide for families in need, and for the opportunity for Australians to grow their living standards. It is this attitude—

TALK.START.PARA: —Inflation is low at the moment, thanks to us.

—Inflation is, I think, at a five-year high. It is exceeding the on average target that the previous government, your party, set as its benchmark. It is this attitude of Labor's that has led to a 400 per cent increase in Commonwealth debt. As a proportion of GDP, Commonwealth debt has gone up fourfold, I think, over the last five years or thereabouts.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sherry, how many more budget deficits do you actually want? Why didn't Senator Sherry say today whether he believes an $8 billion budget deficit is acceptable? Would he seek to reduce that deficit? If not, then let him say so and let him be judged accordingly for the fiscal irresponsibility and stupidity that that implies. If, on the other hand, he does share the coalition's view that the Beazley $8 billion black hole is disastrous, unacceptable, and in desperate and urgent need of correction, then he should say so. He should also tell the Australian community how he would achieve it.

So, far from anxiety induced by the new government, the policy agenda of the new government means that all Australians can look forward to a brighter and more prosperous future. That, I think, is the reason why the latest opinion polls show that the government is in stronger standing in the community than it was even at the time of the election. We are absolutely committed to stopping Labor's legacy of budget irresponsibility. We will make the necessary decisions to restore an underlying budget surplus. If Labor and the Democrats had any sense of fiscal responsibility, they would be sharing the wish to work with the government and the Australian people to correct the situation which is quite obviously untenable and in the worst interests of the nation. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know about you, Madam Deputy President, but I think most Australians are getting a bit sick of this ritual—the hand on the heart before the election, `I make the following promises.' After election day—
—You can talk!
—I am going to honour my promise; I am going to vote against the sale of Telstra. That is the promise I made to the Australian electorate. I am only halfway through—

BREAK.PARA: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I seem to be really getting you excited today, senators. I am only halfway through the ritual. I am only up to election day. Then we get to, `I'm terribly sorry. The cupboard is bare. I really mean to do the best I can, but I can't honour my promises and, unfortunately, I have to cut much more than 2,500 jobs from the public sector.' Nick Greiner did it; Jeff Kennett did it; Dean Brown did it; Richard Court did it; and Bob Carr did it. Now even Deputy Premier Joan Sheldon is trying to do it in Queensland, despite the fact that the Queensland government has a debt-free status.

BREAK.PARA: But we have to ask the question: what sort of condition is the federal budget really in? Where did this $8 billion so-called black hole come from? It was almost entirely due to Treasury downgrading its economic forecast on growth to 3.25 per cent on 12 March. The debate really is not about whether Labor is more duplicitous than the coalition for the Democrats. For us, it is a matter of now looking at the impact of relying on an imprecise science of forecasting and the effect it will have on people's lives. We have to ask ourselves: firstly, are the forecasts right and, secondly, is the $8 billion spending cut the right response?
As I said a little earlier, those who treat Treasury forecasts as holy writ etched in stone really need to look at other parts of the Treasury Economic Roundup today—

TALK.START.PARA: —What would you do?

—I will get up to that in a minute. Treasury admits in Economic Roundup that its GDP forecasts have been out by an average of 1.25 per cent over the past two decades. As I said earlier, 1.25 per cent translates into a $6 billion margin of error. Treasury says that by world standards that is not too bad. That is a real comfort—`by world standards that is not too bad'. But it is not a comfort to the thousands of public servants shortly to be out of work on the basis of a figure that is likely to be revised.

BREAK.PARA: You asked me this: what should we rely on? Since the release of the updated Treasury forecasts on 12 March, there have been a string of economic indicators suggesting that Treasury was unduly pessimistic. Treasury's Economic Roundup today says that the indications are that the growth slowdown is temporary and that growth should strengthen during the course of the calendar year. There are plenty of other indicators: today's balance of payments figures; the December national accounts, and we need to remember that those came out after the 12 March release; the various business investment surveys; credit growth figures—all of which have led the Reserve Bank and others to suggest stronger growth later this year.

As well as black holes, I would suggest there is a black cloud over the growth figure. It is not because of former finance minister Kim Beazley's actions, but this could well be due to the actions of Treasurer Costello himself. For his determination to slash $8 billion out of the budget, there is the increased likelihood that that action will cut the growth rate by, according to the ANZ and Westpac forecasters, between one half and one per cent of GDP. Of course, that adds to unemployment.

Instead of low growth requiring budget cuts—and that is the situation we are told we have—we could end up with a case of budget cuts made by the coalition causing low growth. In my view that is a self‐defeating policy adjustment. That leads us to fiscal policy. Irrespective of how much of the projected deficit is caused by forecast changes, how much deficit reduction is really needed? Recently the Governor of the Reserve Bank, Bernie Fraser, described as basically a failure the fact that after 17 quarters of growth the budget is not in surplus, and it is true.

PARA.BREAK: The previous Labor government did drop the ball on deficit reduction and one really important contributing factor in this was the 1993 One Nation tax cuts that were always unaffordable, unfunded and fiscally irresponsible. In 1994 they followed that by setting up $10 billion in the Working Nation employment programs, which were funded not through revenue and expenditure offsets, but from the growth dividend. In 1993 the Demo crats opposed those tax cuts as unaffordable and they were very badly targeted.

BREAK.PARA: Senator McGauran interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We did. We also called for the 1994 Working Nation to be fully funded. We accept that, because of these key failings by Labor—and Senator Short asked me what I thought and what I would do—some element of fiscal repair is necessary, but how much remains a matter of careful judgment. The key factor must be the impact on unemployment. We need to remember that unemployment is rising. It is up from 8.1 per cent to 8.4 per cent in four months and there has been another projection by Westpac that it will reach 8.7 per cent next year.

BREAK.PARA: We have to ask what is the most appropriate way to deliver fiscal tightening, taking into account expert advice from people like Vince Fitzgerald. It is his advice that it has been the rundown of the revenue base, rather than excessive spending, which is the main problem.

The government has ruled out looking at the revenue side and in our view that leaves them dealing with fiscal policy with one hand tied behind their backs. However, we will support the coalition government's efforts to identify and eliminate inefficiency. We will support their efforts on the abolition of redundant programs and better targeting of assistance to those in need. But we just cannot lend our support to cutbacks which lead to the reduction of access to standards of essential government services or any of these reductions which leave low income earners worse off.

PARA.BREAK: Earlier today in question time I simply asked Senator Hill: if the $8 billion figure was revised downwards, would the government adjust its policies more humanely. All I got after that was some kind of abuse for misquoting the Treasury Economic Roundup. Senator Hill did not answer my question and my position was then misrepresented. However, I will not worry about that. The question we have to ask is: when will the government accept that the $8 billion is not cast in stone and that the reliance on that figure is causing incredible anxiety and distress which is wide spread across the community? If the cuts are not necessary and if the forecasting is revised downwards, will you desist from the slash and burn policy?

TALK.START.PARA: —What if they are revised upwards, Cheryl—$14 billion?

—We take that into account, too. All I am saying is that it is not etched in stone, but your policy response seems to be that it is. I believe we need to watch the economy very closely over the next few months to work out what the most appropriate deficit target is and the most socially and economically responsible way of meeting that target.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Sherry, in this matter of public importance. At a press conference prior to the election, the then Leader of the Opposition, now Prime Minister, Mr John Howard, was asked a simple and straight question by a journalist. That question was, `If there is a budget deficit, will the government still deliver on its election promises?' The answer by Mr Howard was also simple, straightforward and to the point. He said, `Yes, yes, yes, yes, yes. The trouble is that it now appears that that answer has become, `No, no, no, no, no.' Because now we have a massive campaign by the government to position public expectations by producing a so‐called black hole out of a black hat which justifies them walking away from their election promises. That is what appears to be the case.

SPEECH.PARA: During the election campaign, honest John Howard, who is now the Prime Minister of this country, stood by hand on heart and made honesty in government an election issue and he will be called to book by the Australian people at the next available opportunity. They want the person who claimed that he is the honest man of Australian politics to live by his word. They took him at face value; they expect him now to deliver.

Upon being elected to government, predictably—as we have seen with state Liberal governments around Australia after they are elected—they came in and said, `Oh, my God! There is a problem now with the budget and therefore we can't go ahead and do the things that we promised to do.' What they have said is—and it is their term for it—that there is a black hole.
