Senator Kernot described it as a black cloud. I would say that they are black of heart and really never did have any intention of delivering those election promises. They tried to gull the Australian community into believing that this was a government that would not rock the boat; it would adopt Labor policies, govern inclusively and that it would in fact do the things that Labor was doing. It would adopt Medicare, keep the employment programs in place and do all those things on health and education that we were doing.

Senator Sherry has described this so‐called black hole as a furphy, and it is. But it is a furphy which the government knows to be a furphy, yet they continue to knowingly repeat that furphy. This is almost entirely due to the Treasury revising its forecasts and downgrading the budget parameters. It is not a fact that it exists. It is a forecast opinion and one where the Treasury has changed the parameters post the election to come to this conclusion.

As Ross Gittins said in the Sydney Morning Herald, forecasts are not facts—and nor are they. The government is running around saying that this forecast opinion will change as budget parameters change, and they are changing even now because the inflation rate is lower than anticipated by the markets and by the Treasurer (Mr Costello)—and thanks to a Labor government, it is, according to the inflation rate that came out last week.

This is a callous trick. We have a situation in which forecasters, reputable agencies, are saying that, if the budget outlays are cut by the figure the government is talking about, economic growth in Australia will be stunted by—according to the figure Senator Kernot gave today—between a half and one per cent. I concur that this is a reasonable forecast in the circumstances.

That means increasing unemployment, that means that Australia under‐performs in the world, and that means the government cannot deliver on any of its promises. It is a callous trick, too, to have industry lobbyists go and talk to ministers in this government and have ministers defend themselves, limply and lamely, by saying, `I agree with you, the lobbyist, that if we were to abolish these programs then that would be bad policy. Unfortunately, we might have to look at doing that because we have this so‐called black hole'. That is the ready excuse to do what was always intended, to do what was at the back of the Liberal mind before the election.

We will, of course, shine the light of truth on this. Indeed, the black hole is not there; it is a furphy. This is an exercise in naked ideology—not naked ideology, as Senator Short tried to pretend in this debate, to the extent that we are somehow opposed to a balanced budget. We were the governments that had balanced budgets.

The Liberal Party is not a party with any record of balancing budgets in this economy. Its ideology is all about small government, of government withdrawing from education, of government withdrawing from health, of government withdrawing from welfare, of government withdrawing from programs to support industry and business, and of government withdrawing across the board from other areas, including the dismissal of public servants. So here we have an ideology whereby you blame the victims, you penalise them by removing services from them, and you ensure therefore that you can deliver.

I recall that before the election the coalition promised there would be no tax rises, that there would be no new taxes, that there would be no compulsory redundancies and that there would be no cuts to welfare. They made spending promises which mount up to in excess of $3 billion per annum by the year 1998‐99. They are all promises that have to be met on top of this so‐called funding cut.

We in the opposition will be holding the government to a position, if they run away from any of their election promises, of having to face the Australian electors. No wonder yesterday in the House of Representatives the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, when asked by Kim Beazley, the Leader of the Opposition, to produce the Treasury estimates of what the cost of the coalition election promises is, refused to do so. Someone who, before the election, campaigned in a mealy‐mouthed way, calling for the books of Treasury to be opened, has refused the opening of the Treasury books when it comes to revealing Treasury estimates on his own costs.

The overall budget shortfall, as distinct from the underlying deficit, I might say, is currently estimated for 1996‐97 not at $8 billion, as we have been hearing from the government, but at something more like $4.9 billion. It has to be remembered that a significant part of that shortfall was in fact due to the coalition itself when last year it blocked some $2.5 billion worth of budget measures. So they are, to the extent that there is a deficit, the architects of it.

The cuts in the industries area are particularly savage. They have gulled Australian industry leaders into believing they stand for small business, but they are cutting out of industry expenditure targeted programs to help small business, medium‐sized business and large business everywhere in Australia. Let us hear about the industry position on the diesel fuel rebate. What are industry leaders saying to this government about the tariff concession order? What will small business say about the loss of access to the NIES scheme, R&D concessions and export schemes that help them penetrate foreign markets?

The forecast for this budget in the second half of this year is good. That forecast was put down in January, before the election. The business confidence survey showed that that was high. That was true before the election. The economy in the second half of this year will be good, and that will be an achievement of the outgoing Labor government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran, Sen Julian

TALK.START.PARA: —Having been where the Labor Party is now, in opposition, I know only too well that a government directly after an election always enjoys a honeymoon period. Given the MPI today and the opposition's denial mode it is in at the moment, I can see this government will have a very extended honeymoon.

SPEECH.PARA: That is borne out very much by today's news polls in the Australian, which show a very strong lead, if not stronger than the result of the 2 March election, and that business confidence has shot up since our election which will naturally lead to improved investment and therefore greater hope for improved jobs. It is quite obvious our tough decisions that are before us are expected by the electorate. They are not having a downward effect, a downward impact, upon the electorate, rather that is why the electorate put us into government.

I would like to particularly relate my comments, given the short time in this MPI, to the previous speakers. Just prior to me Senator Cook spoke of the very simple question that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) was asked during the election campaign: would he deliver on all his promises? The answer to that is yes. We are going to deliver on all our promises, on all our policies. We know the task before us is very tough but, rest assured, we are going to deliver upon the promises we gave to the Australian people during the election campaign.

The area of most concern out in the Australian community is social welfare, and more than ever we are committed to delivering to that area. The Prime Minister said on radio only a few days ago that we are not going to slash and burn—reduce pensions or pull back on our commitments to homeless youth. Already we have acted upon our commitments to homeless youth by setting up a task force in that area.

I refer the Senate to a speech John Howard made in regard to social welfare which clearly sets out our directions and commitments in this very sensitive area and the honest approach toward delivering our policies that we will undertake. Senator Cook, that is the simple answer to that simple question. But when you were asked for a simple answer to a very simple question regarding the budget surplus, what you said in this chamber on 20 September 1995 when you knew quite well the estimates were moving against you at that time, was this:
I say to Senator Short that the honesty is all on this side of the chamber—
that is when you were in government—
not on that side of the chamber.
But I tell you one thing for sure: our budget will be balanced and in surplus. Our budget will continue to move into greater surplus.
That is the honesty you gave to a very simple question from Senator Short.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite right.

—You have been in denial mode since then. You even knew in September 1995 that the estimates had clearly blown out. We know you knew that, Senator Cook, because in September 1995 the Joint Economic Forecasting Group warned the government that the budget blow-out would occur in 1996‐97, let alone Treasury's own estimates, which you said have been revised since the election. That $8 billion hole was an estimate compiled prior to the election because it was available to the incoming Treasurer (Mr Costello) on 3 March. The day after the election he received a blue folder with the Treasury estimates—a day, quite ironically, known as Clean Up Australia Day. The outgoing government knew full well the task before the incoming government.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to assure Senator Sherry and Senator Kernot that this government will deliver on its promises regardless of the herculean task before many of our ministers of finding savings. That is the job we must do. The Victorian government, the Jeff Kennett government, proved that when tough decisions are made and budgets are brought into surplus the public will go along with that. That is what they want the government to do. Do not fall for the trap of denial like John Brumby does or, come the next election, you will end up just like John Brumby.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wheelwright, Sen Thomas

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the matter of public importance proposed by Senator Sherry. Let me say in relation to this debate that this spurious $8 billion figure, which has been so greeted with enthusiasm by senators opposite and indeed all members of the coalition parties, is in no way reliable enough to be used as the basis for spending plans over the next financial year or the year thereafter.

SPEECH.PARA: It comes as no surprise after the election to see senators opposite and other members of the coalition whooping with joy that they have the prospect of cutting government spending by $8 billion. But there is all the world of difference between a full budgetary round of forecasts, which was done last November and has not been done since, and a quickie estimate that is given to an incoming government—outside the processes of the Joint Economic Forecasting Group. There is all the world of difference and that is something which senators opposite will not recognise.

I think this is the sort of problem which Senator Kernot was wrestling with. I am glad to be in a position to explain the situation to her. You have to realise that senators opposite and members of the coalition are very keen on market estimates. These quickie estimates of what the budget position is are the sorts of things the coalition is very keen on, certainly it was before the last election campaign.

In fact, if you look at what happened in the last election campaign, the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Fischer, accidentally blurted one out on the Sunday program, which was quite off strategy. It was very embarrassing, but it indicates, as he said then, that that was the thing upon which they were basing their fiscal strategy.

The fact is that it is entirely unreliable. These market estimates, these quickie estimates—which this government received from Treasury and which they so rely upon—are very unreliable indeed. Let me tell you about them. I can tell you about them because I used to do them. I was a market economist and I was in the position of making these estimates.
Senator Kemp interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are they different, Senator Kemp? Let me tell you. In a financial market you have to make minute‐to‐minute decisions about whether you are going to buy financial securities. You have to make estimates on the best available information. The point is that, if you are wrong—if you have bought the wrong bond or you have bought the wrong equity—you can sell them again. That is a fundamentally different process for making plans which are going to have their full effect throughout the entire year on government expenditure and government savings. This is the sort of distinction which this government has not made; this is the sort of distinction which puts the lie to this $8 billion number. It is not reliable.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me give you an indication of just how unreliable these quickie estimates can be. There is an organisation called Consensus Forecasts. Every month they get all the private market forecasts for the budget deficits, inflation and all the other major economic variables. Listen to how much they varied over the course of the year. Let us take the 1995-96 deficit: in January 1995 they thought there would be a deficit of $7.4 billion; by March they had changed to $4.6 billion; by April they were expecting a deficit of $3.7 billion; by June 1995 they were expecting a surplus of $0.4 billion; by July 1995, these market economists, doing these quickie estimates upon which the government is now relying, were back down to a deficit of $0.9 billion.

And so it went on month by month—0.7, 1.4, 1.3, down to 0.9 again, 1.3, 1.4 by March 1996. If we look at this fiscal year, 1996-97, already, in January, they are expecting $3 billion; in February they are expecting $3.1 billion; in March 1996 they are expecting $3.3 billion. That is the is the sort of variation you get if you rely on these spurious quickie estimates which you are flaunting in front of the public.

I can tell you this, and I am very confident in saying this: we will never see this exercise done again, will we? We will never see these sorts of quickie exercises trotted out again. It was the Labor government, the Labor Party, that had two forecasting rounds in a year instead of one, and it was the Labor Party, not John Howard when he was Treasurer, not Senator Short when he worked for the Treasury, that brought out projections of the forward estimates with the budget. That is about as much as a Treasury can do in any one year. It takes hundreds of economists and it takes a great deal of detailed work to build up a useable forecast upon which you can make estimates of public spending. We will never hear it again. This is the only time you have ever brought this number out and we will never hear it again.

The fact of the matter is that it will not be $8 billion in August, and you know it. It is not a number upon which you would choose to rely. All of this was an attempt to bring in Fightback. All you wanted to see was the number $8 billion, which neatly fits in with the sort of budget cuts that you want to bring, and that is what you have got. We will not see this sort of thing again. If it is such a great idea, do it again. Why don't you bring it in every three months? Do it every week. Let's run a sweep. That is how reliable these figures are. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order: I noticed a moment ago that Senator Bob Woods was interjecting. That in itself is against standing orders, but he was interjecting out of his place in the chamber and that is also against standing orders. Mr Acting Deputy President, I suggest that you tell him that, if he wishes to interject, he should take his place in the chamber.
—I had noticed the transgression. In the interests of the debate proceeding properly, I turned a blind eye to it. I understand that Senator Woods is now aware of his transgression.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —I know I have only a very brief time to speak to this MPI. It is very interesting to hear Senator Wheelwright talking about the things we are very good at. I can tell you, Senator Wheelwright, that in the past few years one of the things that we have become very good at is winning elections. One of the reasons that we were able to win this election so convincingly is that people believed what we were telling them rather than what you were trying to defend.

SPEECH.PARA: I know you have not been in opposition very long, but if this is the best MPI you can come up with in the first week of your period in this chamber in opposition, then we are in for a pretty dull time for the rest of the year—especially when you start talking about creating undue and needless anxiety in the Australian community. In 1990, when we had a million people unemployed, I remember that there was more anxiety created in our community than the average person should ever have to put up with. Why did we have that anxiety? Because of your economic program and because of your former Prime Minister's decision to have `the recession that we had to have'—a recession which we are still getting out of. You ought to be the last ones to talk about creating needless and undue anxiety in the Australian community.

The very fact that you now seem to be going into this state of denial, as was said by my colleague Senator McGauran, is an affront to the people of Australia who have judged you for what you are worth. They judged you on 2 March, and it seems as though you are finding it very difficult to realise that you are now in opposition and that the people have made their judgment. It is you who are responsible for the budgetary position that we find ourselves in—you alone—and you are the ones that must accept the blame.

This is the opposition that would not tell us the true budgetary position before the election—not even the latest available forecasts. The dishonesty that you displayed in that pre-election period was one of the main reasons why you find yourselves where you are today. The people of Australia resoundingly rejected the Australian Labor Party in the biggest electoral defeat since 1951.

After such a massive loss, you would expect that the new opposition would have a good look at themselves, make some significant reforms and change the ideas that they tried to put before the Australian people. What we have seen here today is a re-run of the same old Labor untruths that we were told when we were in opposition and when you were in government, and that same denial mentality still seems to exist.

The people of Australia know that that $8 billion black hole belongs to you. It belongs to your government. All your denials here today will do nothing to change their view. The fact that you are now trying to ignore its very existence will make you a laughing‐stock in the community and you will continue to be judged in the same way that you were judged on 2 March.

BREAK.PARA: The thrust of this MPI was probably raised in a question to Senator Hill from Senator Kernot in question time yesterday. Having heard her today, I think she is probably Senator two‐bob‐each‐way Kernot. Senator Kernot believes that we cannot get it right and you cannot get it right: only the Democrats can get it right. Of course, they will never get the chance to get it right. It is going to be left to us to right the wrongs fronting the Australian economy today.

The thrust of the MPI was probably raised because of that question. Senator Hill suggested that it was an offensive question. The fact that the opposition has put forward an MPI makes it even more offensive because the $8 billion debt that is mentioned in this MPI is the Labor Party's own debt, one which they are totally responsible for. As we say repeatedly, it is the intention of this government to do everything in its power to make sure that it rights the economic wrongs of the previous government.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Order! The time having reached 4.30 p.m., the Senate will now proceed to consideration of general business.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 May 1996, on motion by Senator Ian Macdonald:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes:

PARA.TAB: (i) the strong support for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and all its charter activities shown by all members of the former Senate Select Committee on ABC Management and Operations, chaired in the previous Parliament by Senator Alston, and
(ii) the evidence given by ABC management that funding for the ABC has not been maintained in real terms; and

SPEECH.PARA: (b) reaffirms the committee's conclusions that:

PARA.TAB: (i) the committee supports the maintenance of ABC funding at least at its current level and the continuation of the triennial funding arrangements,
(ii) the continued exemption from the efficiency dividend helps provide greater planning certainty for the ABC's capital works program and is therefore supported by the committee, and

(iii) the committee supports the maintenance of current funding levels in real terms and would support favourable consideration of any application for the provision of additional funds to ensure the viability of new parliamentary and ABC approved charter activities.

SPEECH.PARA: The ABC is one of the strongest and most relevant organisations in Australia today. You need not take my word for that. Earlier this year a Sun‐Herald article showed that about 85 per cent of all Australians believed that the ABC has a more positive effect on Australian life than any of the other categories listed. There were a great many other categories listed. I regret to say that politicians came in third from the bottom of all categories listed. Journalists probably came in lower than that. The ABC as a body came in right at the very top. I am not the only person who thinks that in this chamber. All members of the 1995 Senate Select Committee on ABC Management and Operations agreed with that in our report.

The ABC is one of the strongest and most relevant organisations in Australia today. It is an essential part of Australian life. It consistently and overwhelmingly puts high quality Australian product on our televisions and through our radios. It is our greatest source of high quality innovative product in broadcast media today.

Quite recently a long list from the ABC came around to all senators setting out the awards that it won in 1994 and 1995. I will just read out a couple. They won an Emmy award for outstanding news and documentary achievement. That was for Wolves of the Sea, produced and directed by David Parer and Elizabeth Parer‐Cook. They won Australian Film Institute awards in the television section and an award from the Australian Cinematographers Society. In the industry voted categories of the Logies, Janus came in very high, as did The Damnation of Harvey McHugh, Four Corners and Frontline. For radio they won the Gold Medal at the New York International Radio Festival in 1995. In 1994 they won the Prix Italia award. The 1994 gold Walkley award for radio went to Background Briefing and silver awards also went to Background Briefing. It won an United Nations Association of Australia media peace award. Radio National's South Africa Week won a major award for radio. I was one of the judges on that, but there were a lot of other judges as well, so I am not saying that because it was only me.

Where the ABC leads, Australian and international commercial channels will often follow. Where did we first see Mother and Son? What commercial channel would have touched that before the ABC? None of them. In fact, the ABC was a bit nervous about it at first, but it has become one of our most popular and highest rating television programs and we are selling it overseas. How many American children are now singing `bananas in pyjamas are coming down the stairs'? An awful lot of them! That is a real achievement, particularly with American television.

The ABC provides leading news and current affairs coverage, which cannot be manipulated by any powerful media baron. For instance, Radio National's breakfast program is essential listening for those like myself who want to know what the day's political agenda is likely to be. How many times have we in this place ordered a copy of Lateline or the 7.30 Report from the library because we missed the detail of a story that had significant impact on public and informed opinion?

Apart from the ABC, it is probably only the Sunday program that does that on television and it is really only the ABC that I can think of that has as large an effect on radio. These are essential parts of our daily lives. The ABC is an essential and immensely important part of our daily lives. The ABC is under threat yet again.

BREAK.PARA: I was the Deputy Chair of the 1995 Senate Select Committee on ABC Management and Operations, a committee which examined the operations and management of the ABC in considerable detail. We saw an ABC which is sound and which provides a diverse and vibrant service, but one where commercial influences had just started to compromise the editorial integrity right at the margins. Why was that? The answer is that the ABC was not adequately funded, even for its charter obligations.

Over the last few years the ABC has been given extra charter obligations and then given one‐off grants to fulfil those obligations, after which the service was to be self‐funding. Obviously, on a limited budget that is a very tall order. The ABC has since rectified the problems which we identified except for one essential one. That is a problem which the ABC cannot rectify itself—federal government funding.

Over the years, ABC funding has not been maintained in real terms. Because of that it has been forced past the point of efficiency. It is no use saying that we will trim some more fat off. There is no more fat; muscle has started to be trimmed. If the ABC is forced to cut programs because of a two per cent funding cut—have no doubt about it, if it has to make such a cut after all the cuts it has had to make over the years, which nobody else has had to make, it will be programs or entire networks which will have to go—we will see a few amputations that will undoubtedly make Australia the poorer.

A study was done a while ago by the then director of Radio National which looked at the relative efficiencies of its programs as against comparable overseas broadcasters. The study showed that in comparison with the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation the ABC makes similar programs for about half the cost. In comparison with the BBC's Radio Four it was about one third of the cost. In relation to US public radio it was about one half of the cost. So in relation to comparable corporations around the world, Radio National is an immensely efficient broadcaster. And there is no reason to suppose that the same does not apply to the rest of the ABC.

The coalition's election policy included a few very interesting and very good policies on the ABC. In particular, the coalition said it would maintain existing levels of Commonwealth funding for the ABC and SBS, would ensure that Australia TV had a long‐term future in Asia, and would make sure that there was no advertising or sponsorship on the ABC. I have to agree absolutely with those policies. They are excellent and I was very pleased to see the coalition put them up.

I expect that Senator Alston will promote those policies and that there will be no cuts to ABC funding in the next budget. He has promised in his published policy that there will be no cuts. I expect that the ABC will continue to be exempted from the efficiency dividend because that is what was promised. It is also one of the recommendations made in the Our ABC report of the committee looking into the ABC.

Strong across‐the‐board support for the ABC and all its charter activities was shown by members of the committee. One member, Senator Carr, is sitting over there waiting to speak. There were other then government members, then opposition members, Senator Chamarette and me. While there was a dissenting report, there was no dissent to any of the things mentioned in this motion. Everybody agreed that the real problem was that charter activities had to be funded properly.

The motion to establish the Senate committee inquiry listed funding as one of the main issues to be examined. I thought it was one of the most important things we had to look at in relation to the ABC. The Senate, pretty well unanimously, agreed. It was found that the ABC has been under‐funded.

The evidence given by ABC management that funding has not been maintained in real terms was irrefutable. When you look at bureaucracies around the country where funding has been maintained in real terms you have to accept that if the ABC is to continue to carry out all its charter obligations it needs to be funded at an adequate level. I do not think it is being funded to an adequate level now, let alone if its funding is cut by anywhere near two per cent.

We also have to remember that the ABC is in its third year of triennial funding. It would be too outrageous to contemplate anything happening at such a time but we have to contemplate the likelihood of something happening in the next period of triennial funding. That is something we must watch carefully.

As a member of this Senate, a former member of this committee and the Australian Democrats' communications spokesperson, I reaffirm the committee's conclusion that it unanimously supported: the maintenance of ABC funding, at least at its current level; the continuation of triennial funding arrangements; and the continued exemption from the efficiency dividend, which helps provide greater planning certainty for the ABC's capital works program—I certainly hope that will not be a question that comes up when we learn what is happening to ABC funding.

Maintenance of current funding levels in real terms is very important. That does not allow for a two per cent, one per cent or even half a per cent cut. The committee was also unanimous in support of favourable consideration of any application for the provision of additional funds to ensure the viability of new parliamentary and ABC‐approved charter activities.

At the moment there are only four speakers, including myself, on the list for this debate today. Not one is a member of the government. I hope someone from the government will speak on this matter. Perhaps they just do not have their act together. It is very important that we hear the government's side of this question. I look forward to hearing the opposition's views when we hear from Senator Schacht and Senator Carr and I also look forward to hearing from Senator Chamarette. I hope that the government will think again and find somebody who can speak today on funding for the ABC.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion moved by Senator Bourne, the Australian Democrats' communications spokesperson and a member of the Senate Select Committee on ABC Management and Operations, the report of which, Our ABC , was presented today. That committee was chaired by the now Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston. After reading the report's recommendations, I see that Senator Alston's position is analogous to that in which Jim Hacker found himself in a classic episode of Yes, Minister .
—An ABC program.

—It is a BBC program shown on the ABC. The episode I refer to was one of the most famous and most funny episodes of that program. Unfortunately, what happened in that episode looks like it is going to come true here in relation to the ABC. When Mr Hacker, the new Minister for Administrative Services, had been in opposition he had circulated and organised a gigantic petition to arrange for freedom of information amendments, et cetera, to open up the government to more transparent arrangements. He then became the minister responsible for dealing with his own petition. Sir Humphrey Appleby classically convinced him very rapidly that he should dump his own petition and speak against it, which he did.

SPEECH.PARA: What do we have here? The committee chaired by Senator Alston made all the wonderful motherhood recommendations about funding for the ABC and the independence of the ABC. But what did Senator Alston say yesterday in the Senate? He would not give a commitment to maintain the funding as outlined not only in this report but also in the coalition's policy statement `Better Broadcasting', as announced on 18 January. He would not give a commitment to reaffirm that funding. Further, today he spoke about the need to provide a two per cent efficiency cut across the board, including the ABC, which is completely contrary to the recommendation in this report. That recommendation is that the ABC should be exempt from such an efficiency dividend, that it should be guaranteed funding, that it should be guaranteed the triennium funding. Here we have Senator Alston aping Jim Hacker in his first two months as a minister in the new government.

In opposition, Senator Alston chaired this committee for two years; he stood up in this parliament demanding extra funds for the ABC. When I asked him a question yesterday he fell at the first fence. He would not reissue that commitment. Now he speaks glowingly about the need to apply the two per cent efficiency dividend across the board—to the ABC, to Telstra and to others. He says that they are inefficient. He does not say that in the committee report. The recommendations which he signed off on are quite to the contrary. He says that the ABC deserves certainty in funding. The opposition certainly supports that view.

We established in government over the last 13 years the policy of triennium funding for organisations like the ABC. We established it for organisations like the CSIRO, the SBS and other major institutions that provide a broad service to the Australian community. We did that to ensure that those organisations had guarantees over three years, so that they could better plan the management and provision of their services to the Australian public.

At the first chance when those opposite get into government it appears that the triennium funding arrangements will be undermined due to an efficiency dividend arbitrarily put on the ABC. The ABC will be told, `You cut where you like but there is going to be a two per cent cut in the efficiency dividend.' That is what we know at the moment. We do not know whether anything further is coming. We do not know whether the ABC is being picked off somewhere else for bigger cuts. We know the triennium funding has another year to run from this coming budget. But by the time of the next budget, when the ABC is due to negotiate a new triennium of funding, it will be doing so in the full glare of a government trying to achieve $8 billion worth of cuts. The ABC cannot be confident in my view that it will not have its base funding slashed to provide the cuts to achieve this figure of $8 billion, this holy grail figure that it has become.

Today I pay tribute to Senator Kernot who pointed out, with the release of the Treasury figures today, that it is now revising changing the growth figures in GDP. We all know that if there is about a one per cent change in GDP in the Australian economy, it could mean an increase in revenue of well over $1 billion to $1½ billion dollars. Other savings will come: extra growth means increased employment, therefore there will be less demand for unemployment benefits.

The figure $8 billion that the Treasurer, Mr Costello, and the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, and all the other ministers are treating as some holy grail figure is an excuse to achieve a political and ideological objective of the government. It is an excuse to reduce those organisations that they think do not follow the coalition's ideological line.

From time to time we all hear the conservatives whingeing that some of the programs aired on the ABC put a different social, political and economic viewpoint. The coalition whinges about anything it does not like. I have to say that the Labor Party and even the Democrats sometimes probably do not like everything screened on the ABC. But that is the idea of a national broadcaster—to portray the full range of views. Senator Alston has fallen at the first opportunity. He has become Jim Hacker by rejecting his own report of a committee which he was so keen to chair.

Not only is Senator Alston creating great uncertainty about funding, but in remarks made a week or so ago he said that the ABC could perhaps look at raising extra funds through sponsorship or some limited advertising. When he was the shadow minister for communications, I never heard a more dedicated opponent than him of advertising or sponsorship in relation to the ABC. But with the first pressure from the economic dries like Mr Costello and Mr Howard, he caves in. He says, `Maybe it's a way to get extra money for the ABC. Maybe it's not too bad to have a bit of sponsorship, a bit of advertising.' I think he said that it has not done much damage to the SBS, that they seem to have handled it. He misunderstands the complete difference between the national broadcaster, the ABC, and its charter—a charter which this committee report is about upholding, expanding and improving—and the SBS and what it has to do under its charter.

PARA.BREAK: Nevertheless, Senator Alston has let it out that he can think of ways in which the sponsorship or the advertising can be put quietly into the ABC. He might even do it more brutally in other ways by saying, `Lis ten, we're taking $10 million, $20 million or $50 million a year out of your triennium funding under the efficiency divided scam, but you can make it up by sponsorship. You can make it up by limited advertising. That is the way you will make up the shortfall.' Therefore, we would have the most significant change in the style and operation of the ABC since it was formed in the 1930s.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a great threat to the ABC by the new government, and it is why I think it is very appropriate that this motion is being debated in the first week of the new parliament with a new government. The opposition is certainly very keen to be associated with the motion as moved by Senator Bourne and I must say that, as the new shadow spokesperson for communications, I am very keen to be associated with the motion and to be debating these issues.

I can tell Senator Alston and the government that on these issues of funding for the ABC—not that I am not critical at times of its performance—there has to be a review of management from time to time to make sure the best efficiencies are there, but it cannot be used as an excuse for ideological reasons to try to inhibit the programming of the ABC. I often think that is the motivation of some of the forces in the coalition.

We will always defend editorial independence and the way to guarantee that editorial independence is to guarantee stability in funding. That is why when we were in government we introduced triennium funding because the funding cannot be got at budget by budget. But under the excuse of an efficiency dividend it will be got at in this budget, and in the following year when the triennium is up for negotiation it will be got at again.

The opposition will campaign to stop this apparently ideologically driven government from trying to reduce the performance of the ABC. I am sure that we will be joined by the Democrats, by various organisations and, above all, by the millions of Australians who rely on the ABC for the diversity of its programs: news and information, entertainment, current events, sport—all of it. I am sure they will be with the opposition and other parties in the Senate. I therefore commend Senator Bourne's motion to the Senate and look forward to its being carried.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Bourne's motion which is in the Notice Paper today. I welcome the opportunity to say a few things about the ABC, an ABC which I personally value very highly. As a result of the Senate inquiry which I participated in, I am able to say I know a great deal more about the ABC than I did before the commencement of this inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: What I would particularly like to emphasise to the Senate is the fact that the Senate Select Committee on ABC Management and Operations—which was established under the most dubious of circumstances, with a whole series of quite vicious allegations made within the terms of reference itself—was not able to come up with the goods to demonstrate that the ABC was in any way weak or not fulfilling its functions as an effective public broadcaster in this country.

This parliament is not yet a week old and the deafening hollowness of the coalition's election commitments are resounding throughout its walls. Despite the coalition's promise to maintain existing funding to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, as announced in their policy brought down on 18 February 1996, the ABC has been informed by the government that it will be subject to a funding cut of at least two per cent. That information was reported in the Australian Financial Review of 23 April. It was also indicated that much larger cuts had not been ruled out. A cut of two per cent would approximate $10 million.

Adding to this funding assault, the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) has refused to rule out the possibility of advertising or sponsorship on the ABC to cover funding shortfalls. What should the electorate make of this apparent new turn in policy that this government and this minister have presided over? At the very least we can say that there has been a maximum degree of evasiveness. It would seem to me that there has been quite a fundamental shift and breach of promise in regard to what was put before the Australian people and before this parliament in respect of the operations of the Senate select committee into the ABC.
On 30 March 1995 in this chamber, Senator Alston said:

The coalition has a very strong commitment to the ABC as one of Australia's vital national cultural institutions . . . and it is vitally important that the ABC remains as an independent quality alternative to the commercial radio and television networks in the decade ahead. Australia certainly needs a fearlessly fair, impartial and independent ABC.

Senator Alston then referred to the forces of darkness. One could not agree more. The question is: what are the forces of darkness that we are talking about? I contend that the forces of darkness reside on the other side of this chamber.

The Darth Vaders of Tory philistinism, of course, have captured the Treasury bench. They have enriched the public debate for many years with their diatribes of hostility to the ABC. How many times have we been told that the ABC has a left‐wing bias, that it is run by the Labor Party, and that it is full of all sorts of people with doubtful sexual preferences? How many times have we been told that the ABC is somehow or other not up to it? That was the whole basis, was it not, of this Senate inquiry? Remember the terms of reference, or have you forgotten so soon?

There were utterly scandalous terms of reference which stated that the ABC is marked by `failure', by `controversy' and by `conflict', that it was `dysfunctional', had `some deep‐seated problems that had caused universal concern'. That is why the members of the now government, when in opposition, behaved outrageously in flouting the standing orders. That is why the chairman of that committee sought, without the authority of the committee, a whole series of matters from the ABC which were right outside the terms of reference. He careered around like a lose cannon, acting without the committee's authority.

As I saw it, that Senate inquiry was the inquisitional equivalent of the gutter crawl. They were trying to solicit a submission from anyone who had an axe to grind against the ABC, anybody who had a prejudice to peddle about the ABC. That is why there was a whole series of time wasting activities and why there was concentration on peripheral matters such as the dismissal of Pamela Bornhorst, whose affair was probably more fitting to the letter pages of TV Week than in a Senate inquiry.

It does not end there. Yesterday, again, the government indicated that it saw a need for `a major shake up in the ABC', that `the ABC was running a deficit' and `its character was nebulous'. It made it clear to us all yesterday that the ABC was going to be subject to major change. It was stated yesterday in the Senate that `the ABC itself is in need of a significant shake‐up'. That is completely in contrast with what we were told through the Senate committee.

I repeat that the Senate committee was set up in the most dubious of circumstances, yet its findings were not able to demonstrate that the claims made in the terms of reference were valid in any way. It was demonstrated, though, that the case was the complete opposite, that the ABC was operating in a much stronger way, was serving more people than it ever had and its performance and public satisfaction levels were much higher than they ever had been.

As far as we are concerned, and as far as the Labor senators who were involved in that committee were concerned, our faith in the ABC was demonstrated by our commitment to give the ABC triennial funding, which has been in place since 1988. The commitment was demonstrated in real terms—and this is where I perhaps disagree with the sentiments expressed in the proposition before us today—by an increase in funding since 1988‐89. That was done by earmarking $1.5 billion for ABC activities over the three‐year period to June 1997 and providing additional funds where required for special initiatives such as the Australian Television International and, of course, pay TV.

The proposition before us today indicates that the ABC management and the ABC union felt that there had been a cut in funding. That was not borne out by the figures. Senator Bourne would recall the findings of the report itself. On page 155, it states:

Both the ABC and the CPSU argued that the ABC's funding base was permanently reduced in 1988/89 when the ABC did not receive supplementation for the full movement in the non‐farm GDP deflator. Both organisations estimate that the ABC has lost $35m from its funding base.

However, the Government's efficiency dividend has not been applied to the ABC since the first triennium of funding (1988/89—1990/91). The exemption from the efficiency dividend represents a significant saving to the organisation and is supported by the Committee. Overall, the ABC has fared as well as any public sector organisation in its budget funding in recent years.

I put it to the Senate that there has been a quite deliberate campaign of denigration against the ABC for some years by conservative forces in this country. There have been the tactics of slander, abuse and trivialisation, characterised in particular by the lead‐up to the establishment of this particular Senate inquiry. As far as I could tell, there seemed to be quite a determined effort to undermine the confidence in the ABC board by constant reference to the members' past and present political affiliations. Part of the inquiry's findings went to the issue of board membership.

It would be very interesting to see what the government's position is on another matter—that is, the board being appointed after thorough parliamentary scrutiny of nominees' credentials. Let us hear more about that. When this government comes to appointing new members to that board, I wonder how much notice it will take of the commitments it made in this report through the chairman, Senator Alston, agreeing to that proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —ALP membership will not be essential.

—How many members of the Liberal Party are on the current board? You keep saying this, but how many? You might ask yourselves whether or not it is possible for Labor to appoint members who are in fact active and involved in the Liberal Party. That did occur. I wonder how often it will occur with you.

SPEECH.PARA: The real issue here is what is at stake. It strikes me that it is the Fightback agenda being implemented by stealth. You will recall that under Fightback the proposal was for a slashing of some $50 million from the corporation's budget. It seems that that is where we are going with this matter as well, despite the commitments that have been made to the public and this Senate through this inquiry.

There is abundantly clear evidence of the hypocrisy of this government on this matter. It is quite clear that it is an ideologically driven agenda of the current government for the corporation to be wound back. You have to ask yourself why that is the case. One of the reasons is not the failure of the ABC but its success. Because it is so widely accepted by Australians and because it so effectively competes with commercial interests, it has to be wound back, doesn't it? That is very much at the heart of the problem here. We cannot have an independent news organisation, can we, that puts a different view? That is bad news, according to the ideological precepts of those opposite.

We are really talking about the Fightback agenda being introduced by stealth. We are looking at the commercialisation at any cost through this new government regime. What a terrible cost that would be. The ABC is, in my judgment, more than a mere broadcaster; it has a very important role to play in both the national political debate and the development of a national culture in this country. The ABC is a very important institution in the protection of Australia's culture, and a very important protection in Australian society in that regard. That is why the debate about advertising on the ABC is much more than just a question of economics.

There are two pillars of independence for the corporation, that is, its separation from political and commercial influences. Such independence could well be compromised were the ABC to become even partly dependent on income from advertisers and sponsors. Wasn't that the point that you constantly made throughout the inquiry? You said that any off‐budget revenue raises the issue of seepage and the question of the independence of the ABC. What now do we see so quickly after there is a change of government?

BREAK.PARA: Extensive surveys of public opinion on the ABC in the late 1980s indicated that the overwhelming majority of Australians want the ABC to be commercial free and that they are prepared to keep paying their 8c a day for the privilege. Eighty‐one per cent of respondents opposed advertising on the ABC.

As the former head of the corporation recently stated, `The dirty work of the commercialisation of the ABC will be left to a cash‐strapped board.' David Hill made that comment in the Sydney Morning Herald of 23 April 1996. ABC chairmen and media commentators have warned of the inevitable dilution of the corporation's unique products which will result from commercial pressures. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) has described the prospect of advertising on the ABC as a major tragedy, a sentiment with which I fully agree.

Even Australia's commercial television networks have opposed the introduction of advertising. You could ask yourself why. It does indicate that there is, I think, broad opposition to the introduction of advertising on the ABC. They have warned that there will be a dramatic drop in the overall quality of Australian television programming, and they cite the SBS television model as being ineffective. Of course there is commercial interest in that, but there is also, I think, sound reason in terms of the product that would result, that is, with drama and all the other entertainment services provided by the ABC, not just the news itself.

Should an Australian cultural icon be defiled because the government has set itself an unrealistic and irresponsible target of budget cuts totalling some $8 billion over two years? The diversity of Australia's broadcasting system has worked well for the nation with its strong and complementary commercial and public arms. The Labor government's stable funding regime and policy environment provided the ABC with the necessary certainty to maintain and develop the service, experiment with new formats and pioneer new techniques. It should not be undermined by a major shake‐up, as this minister has promised.

If I recall correctly, H.G. Wells described advertising as `legalised lying', a process the government should not be seen in the same light as. It is time for the minister to squash the rumours and to spell out exactly what the government is intending to do on this issue. You cannot rely on half‐truths and evasive answers. These in themselves destabilise and demoralise the corporation, and are of great concern to the electorate at large.

The public broadcaster has served the public well for some 60 years. The ABC is much stronger as a result of Labor in government. In terms of the resources that have been delivered and the policy regime in which it operated, it has been able to extend its services to quite extraordinary levels. The ABC has increased its radio audience by some 62 per cent and its television audience by 26 per cent since the late 1980s, and it has done so, in my judgment, largely as a result of quality programming and more Australian content than ever.

The ABC cannot afford to be undermined by the sorts of ideological obsessions that we are witnessing here and that we have witnessed for some time from the Liberal Party. We all understand that the ABC is a great Australian institution. I have no doubt it will survive. The issue is, however, at what cost it will survive. The ABC has survived war, depression and, of course, the worst excesses of tory philistinism. I believe it will also survive Richard Alston.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarrette, Sen Christabel

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of Senator Bourne's motion relating to the ABC. I recall giving a `hear, hear!' to the motion yesterday when she gave notice of it in the chamber. I am extremely disappointed at the failure of the government to be here to present a position and to listen to the views that are being expressed and to the questions that are implied from the views that are being expressed. It is not an auspicious start in this new government's first week of program.

SPEECH.PARA: It is actually the comments of the new government that have generated concern regarding the future of the ABC. Yet it is not here to clarify and elaborate on the position it intends to take, or to even present an interim position. There is no justification for its failure to be present and to express a view at this time. I want to express serious condemnation of the failure of the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) and his party to even have the minister and his views represented.

We have heard much about the Senate inquiry into the ABC. It has been referred to in various ways. As I was an instigator of that inquiry, and as one who certainly supported it and participated in the committee, I would like to recount some incidents in the life of that committee which I believe can support Senator Bourne's motion and the need for this chamber to consider very seriously aspects of the ABC's operation.

I instigated that inquiry as a wholehearted supporter of the ABC in its role as Australia's independent national public broadcaster. I presented the Senate inquiry as a positive step to clear the air on a series of issues relating to the management and operation of the ABC. I did not believe that support of the ABC should involve any glossing over of problems that were clearly apparent in the operation of the ABC at that time. I will refer to some of those concerns which I believe had been in some cases dealt with, in some cases exacerbated, and in some cases are still in suspension because of this new government's failure to declare its full position on the matters.

Basically, I felt that the ABC needed a visible mechanism to get over the problems and criticisms that had occurred and that the purpose of the inquiry was not to emphasise any one of the particular issues of concern but to allow a number of people to air their views and to be part of the problem solving process. In my view, this would ensure that nothing would hold back the ABC from continuing its vital role in the community into the next century. They were the words that I used at the time of supporting the inquiry.

I think there were dire predictions, even at that time, held by the former government regarding my motives and the motives of the opposition in supporting the motion for a committee into the ABC. I think aspersions were also cast on the Australian Democrats for being prepared to look at the terms of reference and to also support them, after they had included some aspects that met their concerns, which were that it should not be a destructive inquiry but a constructive one to uphold the importance of our national broadcaster.

I can recall a conversation at the time of those allegations. I am sure that Senator Bourne remembers it as well. Senator Alston, Senator Bourne and I were engaged in a three-way discussion in another part of the chamber. I asked Senator Alston to repeat the comments that he had made to me in response to my concerns that, in the lead-up to the previous federal election, it had been quite clearly stated by the former leader of the Liberal Party, John Hewson, that de‐funding, or reducing the funding, or not continuing in the same volume the funding of the ABC, would be considered.

Senator Alston quite specifically repudiated that previous stance of the coalition. He said that there was no question of lowering the level of funding, that it had put those troublesome policies behind it, that it wanted to have nothing to do with them, and that he would guarantee to Senator Bourne and me personally that the only interest the then government had was in a constructive support, a continuing support, of the ABC. I am sure Senator Bourne can bear out that conversation that occurred between the three of us, and the motivation that led us to double check before we agreed altogether on passing that motion in the Senate: it was in the interests of furthering the operations of the ABC and not doing anything to curtail it.

In relation to some of the concerns that were addressed, I believe that the then government and the ALP senators who were on the committee took a less than helpful role in what they no doubt considered was a defence of the ABC. `Defence' is probably the right term because they became so defensive and abusive that their main concern seemed to be to defend the ABC by undermining the inquiry.

In retrospect, and even at that time, I think that their role could have been far more powerful. They could have ensured that the committee's report was unanimous and that it tied the coalition well and truly to the kinds of supports for the ABC that we would not even need to be debating today if they had added their presence in a constructive way to the committee public hearings. Instead, they simply argued with the chairman and made aspersions on the motivations, and not only on members of the committee but also on people who gave evidence.

I believe that the previous comments of Senator Carr need to be balanced by a statement from me. As a member of that committee, I think there were opportunities for the two senators, Senator Forshaw and Senator Carr, to have been very constructive in working with Senator Bourne and me to make the recommendations of the committee even stronger than they eventually turned out to be.

The concerns that were raised—some have been addressed; some have been proven true—and that I want to mention here are concerns about the role of ATV, ATV International, the proposed abolition of ABC regional television news, program sponsorship rules, continuing levels of resignations and departures of ABC staff, appointments to the board, relationships between the board and management and the increase in commercial activities.

In particular, we were concerned about the centralisation of operations towards Sydney, the proposal to amalgamate Radio Australia and ATV and the increasing commercialisation of the broadcaster. Western Australia is only too aware that some of these moves have unfortunately already taken place. I believe that regional Australia has been severely penalised by the kinds of budget constraints and centralisation that have operated in the ABC and which need to be counteracted by a strong stand from government and from all parties that says, `The ABC should have the funding. It should not penalise regional and decentralised public broadcasting—radio or television—to the detriment of the people of Australia.'

While the committee hearings made it perfectly clear that there was a danger of that if there was not an increase in and an increased security of the funding of the ABC, we have been able to see that that centralisation, that holding down and lessening of the broadening aspect of this ABC, has occurred. Central to the kinds of changes that have occurred is concern regarding funding. During the committee's deliberations, we discovered that the ABC had operated extremely well, considering the low base of funding from which it was operating.

When we received a comparison of the ABC's funding with that of other national broadcasters around the world, we were appalled to see that, just for example, the ABC's total television budget is greater than the budgets of the national broadcasters of only New Zealand and the United States. If we want to emulate the United States and let our national broadcaster drop to that degree in terms of its commercial competition and sway, we have to think very seriously about the implications of that. I think we should seriously question it if we feel we are only the same size as New Zealand and we can afford to have a budget that is just barely bigger than that of New Zealand when we are such a vast continent. People are spread out right throughout the states and we cannot afford the kind of centralisation that may well be possible in New Zealand.

The ABC's budget ranks behind those of the national broadcasters of Japan, Italy, Germany, the UK, France and Canada. It is really a disgrace and I think this government needs to be looking at that—looking at its international reputation and the kind of image it is going to present by the priority it gives to its national broadcaster.

I think I said in a previous speech that one of the intelligence test items is: what is the importance of a free press? I leave that as an open question to test the intelligence of my listeners here. I will just say that the importance of a free press must not be overlooked by this new government and must not be overlooked in relation to the issues we are discussing right now. It has very serious ramifications.

As part of the committee report, all parties supported the triennial funding initiative. We have supported it because it provides the ABC with the ability to plan over a longer period while at the same time allows it to retain any profits arising from its commercial activities. Senator Bourne and I had concern about the commercial involvement, so that was not a uniform committee position. However, we were totally united in relation to the maintenance of the present level of funding as a minimum and additional revenue that should be provided by the government, rather than forcing it into commercial activities or into downscaling the very worthwhile activities it has been conducting for so long.

The case for additional funding was put very clearly in the report on page 97. While it did state that the ABC's annual report of 1993-94 advised that current funding levels would enable it to maintain current activities, one of the major concerns was that other activities wouldn't be able to be engaged in. Some of the activities that had actually been raised, for example ATV, which was experiencing revenue shortfalls, and also other aspects of ABC services, would eventually be a drain on the limited appropriation funds allocated to the ABC. The report quotes the Friends of the ABC as saying:
The root of the ABC's current problems is undoubtedly a general shortage of funds and management's entrepreneurial attempts to address this problem.
The report continued:
The Friends claimed that the shortage of funds has been exacerbated by the expansion of the ABC into such areas as ATV and 24 hour radio news on the parliamentary channel.

I believe that the statements in Senator Bourne's motion are worthy of total support. We really need to put on the record where the coalition stood in relation to these matters. Certainly, the maintenance of ABC funding, at least at its current level, and the continuation of the triennial funding arrangements was a unanimous recommendation. The coalition supported the continued exemption from the efficiency dividend because it helped provide greater planning certainty for the ABC's capital works program. The committee also supported the maintenance of current funding levels in real terms and would support favourable consideration of any application for the provision of additional funds to ensure the viability of new parliamentary and ABC approved charter activities.

I think nothing could be more clear than the committee's findings and I think there can be nothing more clear, by the absence of a representative of the government speaking on this matter, than that the government is in danger of grave hypocrisy or of really letting down its responsibilities in relation to this very important portfolio area.

I conclude by saying that we cannot stress enough how important it is to maintain the role and functions of the ABC—and not just in the way that we have taken for granted for so long, because we are about to see an enormous technological leap in this country. We do not need a public broadcaster that slips further and further behind the kind of competition that will come from other innovations and which people should be seriously concerned about, because of the impact that will have on Australian content and on the general objectivity of media coverage. When we established the committee, I knew that the ABC was not immune to justifiable criticisms. I believe that its funding should be not only supported but increased. I support, in the strongest possible terms, the motion that is before the chamber at the present moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I was a member of the select committee which considered the issues which have been debated this afternoon. I must firstly respond to the comments directed by Senator Chamarette at me and Senator Carr. The accusation was that we really were not interested in the issue and sought to somehow derail the committee. I refute that completely. I think I am pretty safe in saying that I was probably one of the few members of the committee that attended every single session of the hearings. Not only that, I also took a keen interest, as did Senator Carr, in the issues before the committee and we sought to obtain as much evidence as we could from the witnesses regarding the matters.

SPEECH.PARA: But, of course, we do not resile from the fact that, from the very outset of that committee, it was fatally flawed because we had a series of conclusions that were looking for an argument to be sustained. Whilst I would acknowledge that there were at the time some general issues of concern regarding funding for the ABC, there were also some specific matters that were in the public arena, such as the alleged increase in use of sponsorship through what are known as `infotainment programs' to supplement ABC funding. There was also the specific matter that Senator Chamarette took an interest in, namely the dismissal of an ABC reporter named Pamela Bornhorst. Despite all of those rather important and serious matters, what we ended up with was a committee, chaired by Senator Alston, which sought—in our view—to attack the ABC wherever it could for political purposes.

We had this inquiry which went into the membership of the board and allegations of stacking. We had allegations directed at staff of the ABC. In some cases quite serious and malicious allegations were allowed to be made against staff of the ABC who were then placed in a difficult position of having to defend themselves. When you went through the specific terms of reference of that inquiry, it became very clear that each of the allegations and issues raised were either erroneous or were matters which were being adequately handled within the structure of the ABC, particularly through the Palmer report.

The reason why the government senators at the time came down with a dissenting report was that we believed that the ABC was under surreptitious attack here by the then opposition. I do not level that charge at Senators Bourne or Chamarette, because I believe they have—and had at that time and through that inquiry—a genuine desire to examine some issues of concern to them and to do so in the course of defending and promoting the interests of the ABC as a public broadcaster. I have had the opportunity to talk particularly with Senator Bourne on a number of occasions and I think we both agree that we are great fans of the ABC, as many of us are. I refute those comments of Senator Chamarette with respect to our activities on the committee.

I also want to touch very quickly on a couple of matters that arose out of the committee and that have been covered here this afternoon by the various speakers. I note that the now government—those who when opposite were so intent upon chasing down every burrow any rabbit they could find to get stuck into the ABC only a year or so ago in the inquiry—have not even bothered to participate in this debate. Senator Alston has said that they believe that the ABC is a great public institution. On many occasions, Senator Alston, then as opposition spokesman, asked questions in the chamber and made speeches attacking the government—attacks which were unwarranted. He was always holding up this mantle that he stood for an independent ABC and one that needed to be adequately funded and open to public scrutiny.

Today we have one of the first debates in this chamber since the election, and where are the government? They have gone home. They are not here. The minister is not here to even participate in the debate.

The precedent was set during the election campaign. What happened during the election campaign? There was going to be a debate between the Prime Minister of the day, Paul Keating, and the then Leader of the Opposition, John Howard—just as there had been a debate in the previous election in 1993 and in preceding elections. But what was the view of the opposition leader? The view was, `We can't have the debate on the ABC.' John Howard would not accept Kerry O'Brien as the moderator of that debate. He attacked the integrity of one of Australia's leading and fairest and unbiased political commentators—Kerry O'Brien. He was not going to actually come out and say it publicly. No. What did he do? He said, `I refuse to have the debate on the ABC with Kerry O'Brien.'

It was a matter of fundamental importance in terms of the independence and the integrity of the ABC that, as our only true national public broadcaster, it should have the opportunity to carry that debate, to do so in a totally commercial‐free environment and to be able to choose the compere or the moderator of the debate. But the now Prime Minister said, `I'm not going to turn up.'

Of course, the precedent was set then. You would not participate in the debate on the ABC. Now that we are debating the ABC and the critical question of funding for the ABC, you will not participate in this debate either. You have gone quiet. You have done a Jeff Kennett. When it comes to the ABC, it is the only way you can ever shut Jeff Kennett up, because he will not talk to them. This is the attitude. This is this great support that you have, and your leader has, for the independence and the integrity and the maintenance of an unbiased and fair public broadcaster like the ABC. You will not even come along into the chamber and debate the very important issues. Of course, it is an important issue—a very critical issue in terms of the future of public broadcasting in this country.

As Senator Carr so rightly pointed out, the real agenda was in Fightback. That was to rip $50 million out of the budget of the ABC. The ABC is probably one of only two remaining national public broadcasters in the world that relies essentially on public funds through the budgetary process and does not rely upon direct commercial revenue through television commercials, radio commercials and so on.

There are other public broadcasters throughout the world that have a mix of funding. There are broadcasters like the BBC that rely on a licence fee system, where the level of funding can go up just by putting the licence fee up. Of course, the ABC has always been subject to budgetary allocation. The introduction of the triennial funding arrangements by the Labor government brought a lot of stability to that funding process and enabled that broadcaster, the Broadcasting Corporation, to be able to plan well in advance for its needs. What we have now is a direct threat to the continuation of public funding at current levels for the ABC. As Senator Carr so rightly points out, the agenda is ultimately to slash public funding for the ABC and, no doubt, probably open it up to another form of privatisation.

We stand committed to maintaining that total support. I will be very interested, as I am sure we all will be, when the minister in this place, Senator Alston, finally finds the time to come along and participate in the debate, to see how he addresses this issue without hypocrisy. He is now on the record, as he said in the past, saying that he would maintain the level of funding. Clearly, within a matter of a few weeks, that promise has been broken like so many others. So we are very supportive of the continuation of public funding for the ABC, and I endorse wholeheartedly the remarks of earlier speakers, particularly those of Senator Carr.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bourne will now close the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—Go, Vicki, go!
—Hear, hear!

—I thank honourable senators for their support. Let me make the point that editorial independence can only be guaranteed by adequate independent funding. The courage to produce a significant amount of innovative, high quality programming, as the ABC constantly does, can only be guaranteed by adequate independent funding.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me make just one more point about the efficiency of the ABC. Another comparison between Radio National and the BBC's Radio 4 showed that similar programming from the two networks was provided with a global budget for Radio National that was about one-third of what was provided for BBC's Radio 4. The ABC is as efficient as it is going to become. Chopping budgets by one or two per cent every year does not necessarily lead to greater efficiency. In fact, lower funding will very quickly lead to lower efficiency. When does the appallingly named efficiency dividend—`efficiency dividend', who made that up?—become nominally inefficient? When does it become the inefficiency dividend? How close to zero does the budget have to be before we start questioning the basis of this ridiculous concept?

Any government which reduces independent funding for an independent broadcaster is in fact at the same time increasing the power of a few media barons, and that is particularly so in Australia. The absolute stupidity and short-sightedness of doing such a thing is that any government which increases the power of any media baron increases that power over itself. That is a very dangerous procedure indeed. Australia needs every single program on every single network which is currently produced by the ABC.

BREAK.PARA: Let me finish by going through the coalition's election promises in relation to the ABC. It will maintain existing levels of Commonwealth funding and triennial funding for the ABC and the SBS. It will support the ongoing extension of Triple J into regional Australia. It will ensure Australia Television, ATV, has a long-term future in the Asia‐Pacific region. It will fund the ABC and the SBS directly for their transmission costs. It will provide $6 million for the captioning of ABC and SBS television news services. It will implement a coherent media policy which puts the national interest first. I am really pleased to hear that one.

The coalition will maintain the current prohibition on advertising and sponsorship on ABC television and radio. ABC Radio, which includes Metropolitan Radio, Regional Radio, Radio National, ABC Classic‐FM, Triple J and NewsRadio, is one of Australia's most influential and listened to radio networks. I absolutely agree. The policy reads:

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Coalition is committed to maintaining the ABC's comprehensive radio network.

BREAK.PARA: That is in bold. I am very pleased to see that. It goes on:
For many people in rural and remote areas, ABC Radio is their most important link with the outside world.
How true. Again, in bold:

PARA.EMPHASIS: We will encourage and support the ongoing expansion of ABC Radio, including the extension of the highly successful Triple J network into regional Australia.

BREAK.PARA: What can I say? I absolutely agree—very, very good policy. The coalition has promised to put these policies before parliament where appropriate and attempt to get them through. I can guarantee that the Democrats will support them and it seems to me that we can count on the support of the opposition and Senator Chamarette. So we are looking forward in the very near future to seeing more funding for the ABC, not less.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't hold your breath.
—I won't hold my breath.

BREAK.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Herron) agreed to:
That general business be not further proceeded with this day.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Report No. 20 of 1995-96—Performance audit—Diesel fuel rebate scheme—Australian Customs Service.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane, Sen Winston

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I would like to make some comments about this audit report as far as the scheme itself is concerned. I am sure everybody in this chamber would be well and truly aware of my interest in this particular area of policy. In doing so I note that the auditor has identified a number of aspects of the scheme that were of concern. This has been a consistent aspect of audit reports into the diesel fuel rebate scheme for a number of years. It is worth noting that Customs have responded in what I believe is a very positive way to dealing with those particular aspects that have been identified by the auditor.
