I particularly want to draw to the attention of the Senate the response by the Australian Customs Service on the handout brochure that goes with the report. Customs has identified and is implementing a more cost‐effective means of data capture which recognises the diversity in business sophistication among claimants under the scheme. The brochure goes on to list a half a dozen points. There is no need for me to read those out because they are there in writing.

I do want to raise one particular aspect which would improve the scheme enormously. Back in 1981 or 1982, because of certain misuses of the scheme, it became a rebate scheme rather than being an exemption scheme. I think it is time to have another look at that particular aspect of the scheme. I believe it should be done this way. It could be done in conjunction with a sales tax exemption. A sales tax exemption certificate operates in those industries where the diesel fuel rebate scheme applies.

It is about removing taxes from the inputs into export industries. Under the sales tax exemption scheme you have a registered number and only authorised individuals can operate from that number. Customs should be looking at introducing a similar type of scheme. In fact, you could have a sales tax exemption certificate that applied to both sales tax and the diesel fuel rebate scheme.

I believe it could be done under a Medicare type card with a number on it which has to be stamped on each invoice. That in itself would be an enormous improvement in the scheme in terms of efficiency and would significantly reduce the compliance costs for both the users of the scheme and the department, because there are enormous resources tied up in manpower and facilities in administering the scheme.

Nonetheless, it is be acknowledged that Customs have addressed a number of aspects that are raised here. I also want to point out why people from my state take such an interest in this scheme. I refer particularly to page 7. It is well known that Western Australia provides some 25 per cent of the export income of this nation. It has also been estimated that by the year 2010—or between 2010 and 2015—mainly out of the Pilbara region of Western Australia, and other areas in the goldfields as well, particularly the electorates of Kalgoorlie and to a lesser extent O'Connor, that percentage of Australia's total export earnings will rise to about 40 per cent.

Western Australia receives about 38 per cent of the total value of rebates, yet has only 10 per cent of the claimants. That is a reflection of two things: the total export operations in mining and agriculture in Western Australia and the distances involved in transportation. I want to make it clear that, when I mention transport, I am not talking about transport on public roads. It is paid on public roads. I am talking about transport on private roads out in the bush. I believe that it is important that we continue to highlight those aspects of the scheme. It would be detrimental to those industries if their costs increased, particularly the infrastructure costs involved in the expansion of some operations.

I particularly want to mention the operations of Marandoo and Tom Price and what are commonly known as transport networks. A private railway line has been built between the two operations. By linking Marandoo and Tom Price, it increases the life of that particular operation by some 40 years. It is anticipated that if Tom Price is not expanded by the increase in the high‐grade ore from Marandoo, it will cease to be an export operation by the year 2009. The extension of the railway system to Marandoo will increase its life to about 40 years, between the years 2040 and 2050. So we need to take a long‐term view of the diesel fuel rebate when we are considering the structural requirements for the development and continued expansion of mining in Western Australia. I wanted to draw the Senate's attention to that aspect.

Another aspect which is of interest—no doubt Customs is looking at it—is the discrepancies in the average cost of processing a claim. This is dealt with on page 34 of the report. I suggest that we should develop a type of card system which could operate in conjunction with the sales tax exemption. It would significantly lower the administration cost of the diesel fuel rebate scheme. For some reason or other—I have not been able to identify it at this stage—the cost of processing in the Northern Territory is significantly higher than it is in the other states. New South Wales has the lowest processing cost. There is probably a very good reason for that, and no doubt we can pursue that in the estimates committee hearings.

Having made those comments regarding the diesel fuel rebate scheme, I reiterate that the responses by Customs to this and other audit reports have been very positive and constructive. I look forward to seeing in the audit report next year how these recommendations have been implemented.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The audit report on the diesel fuel rebate scheme allows us to address some important issues today. I want to point out to the Senate the absolute and fundamental importance of this scheme to the mining industry.
—Point that out to John Anderson.

—I see the former minister sees where I am coming from. There is some speculation in the press that there may be some attack on this diesel fuel rebate. It is, as I said, fundamentally important to Australia's fishing, farming and mining industries. They are the big earners, the big job providers in Australia. The scheme has been effective since 1957, providing some relief from the excise on diesel fuel.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also absolutely important to the international competitiveness of our export earning industries. It is calculated that its removal would result in an increase in direct farm costs of $90 a week on average, and more for heavy users of diesel fuel, such as grain growers. I think there was a letter from the mining industry, which came only yesterday, or maybe today, which says that the loss of the diesel fuel rebate to the mining industry would increase the cost of coal by, I think, $1 per tonne.

The trebling of the diesel fuel rebate over the past decade has been a result of the automatic increase of the fuel excise going from 10.437c a litre in 1986 to 34.183c a litre in today's dollars. Most of that money was initially spent on the development of roads. During the last 13 years the money was syphoned off into general revenue, but that is a matter for another debate.

In its 1993 budget the previous government attempted to impose an administration charge of one per cent. We on this side of parliament knew that that would have been the thin edge of the wedge driven in. It would have been one per cent this year and it would have been cranked up to a greater amount once it was established. I am very pleased that the then opposition, the government at the moment, led a charge—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not at the moment; for a long time to come.

—At the moment and for a long time to come. They led the charge on that. With the support of the Democrats, that was defeated in the parliament. When this matter of the diesel fuel rebate was debated just before the last parliament rose, a number of things happened with the support of the Democrats that they can take no credit for.
—That's a contradiction.

—On the one hand they giveth and on the other hand they taketh away. The Democrats supported the government, which resulted in a loss of the diesel rebate to some aspects of the mining industry and the primary industry. When they removed the diesel rebate from the extraction of limestone, which was used to help defeat the acidity in the soil, that amounted to a loss of about $600,000 to farmers. The cane trains that bring the sugar cane into the mills also lost their maintenance rebate for diesel fuel.

SPEECH.PARA: I have taken this matter up with the minister and Senator Crane has taken up some aspects of this legislation with respect to his home state with the minister. We hope that when an amending bill comes through the subjects that we raised with the minister in relation to the building of roads on properties, the reinstatement of the diesel fuel rebate on cane trains and the maintenance of the lines will meet with the minister's approval and he will re-establish the diesel fuel rebate on those issues.

The Auditor-General's report allows me to address those issues on the diesel fuel rebate and gives us an opportunity to say how important it is to farmers, miners and the fishing and forestry industries. The farmers have not had a great deal of joy, particularly the wheat farmers in the eastern states. They have faced five years of drought. Any loss of diesel fuel rebate would be very significant to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful for the opportunity to stand here and support most of the comments made by the Leader of the National Party in the Senate (Senator Boswell) and also to join my Liberal Party colleague from Western Australia, Senator Crane, who has put forward some suggestions for revamping the diesel fuel rebate scheme. The Auditor-General's report which is before the chamber gives us the opportunity to say a few words about the scheme. It also gives us Western Australian senators the opportunity to stand in solidarity on behalf of the constituents in Western Australia that we are elected to represent in this parliament of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Leader of the National Party, Senator Boswell, said, the diesel fuel rebate scheme is under some attack at the moment. In fact, the eyes of the razor gang are very firmly focused upon this scheme. If they are successful it will cost the miners from Western Australia that we represent in this place dearly. It is not only the farmers in the great state of Western Australia that we speak about; it will cost the farmers throughout the nation. In the words of Senator Boswell, it will cost them some $90 per week.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?
—It will cost them $90 per week if the scheme is done away with or is gutted in the way that has been suggested in some of the media outlets.
—You didn't buy a farm, did you, Jim?

—That is a good interjection. I have nothing personally to gain from supporting the retention of the diesel fuel rebate scheme. The only gain that I get from defending such a scheme in the parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia is the fact that I would be truly representing the views and wishes of the constituents in Western Australia who elected me to represent their views in this place. I am very pleased to stand here and represent those views. It is easy to do that from opposition, as we are finding out in this place. I thought being in opposition was going to be a very lonely task, but I am finding that it is not quite so lonely at all. There are some government backbenchers who from time to time will be prepared to stand up and speak out against the actions of the government.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen a very brave act here this afternoon. I note and commend Senator Crane for doing what he has done previously. We have already seen the very brave act here this afternoon by the Leader of the National Party in the Senate, Senator Boswell, who effectively got up and spoke against his ministerial colleague, Mr Anderson, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, who is a member of the razor gang—

TALK.START.PARA: —Courageous.
—He is very courageous actually.
—I raise a point of order. I claim to have been misrepresented.
—Senator Boswell, I accept what you are saying but it is normal to raise that at the end of the speech.
—But it is an important matter.
—I am sure it is—
—I don't think it can go unchallenged.
—No, but it is normal procedure to do it at the end.

—If I have misrepresented Senator Boswell and an apology is necessary, I am prepared to give it. But, as I heard him, and I listened very carefully to what he had to say, I thought he was defending the diesel fuel rebate scheme. If he was, I was getting up here to support him in defence of that scheme because it is under attack from the razor gang—the Expenditure Review Committee of the cabinet—which includes his colleague, Mr Anderson, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. If I have misrepresented you, Senator Boswell, I will repent—no question about it—but I believe I heard you properly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Madam Acting Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented. The previous speaker, Senator McKiernan, said that I was defending the diesel fuel rebate scheme, and he was perfectly right in saying that. I made no attempt to disguise that fact, nor did Senator Crane. But Senator McKiernan expanded on that and said that I was running a different line from that of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, John Anderson.

SPEECH.PARA: At no time has John Anderson come out and said that there should be a downsizing of the diesel fuel rebate. On the contrary, the minister said that he would fight to retain the diesel fuel rebate. You cannot extend that argument because there is speculation in the press that it is supported by John Anderson. It is not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! You are starting to debate the issue. Could you please continue only in relation to where you claim to have been misrepresented.
—I think the previous speaker was being devious. He was trying to drive a wedge where there is no gap. He has said that he will apologise. I accept his apology.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles, Sen Susan

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot allow the opportunity to pass to make some comment on the diesel fuel rebate scheme in its entirety and also on Senator McKiernan's newfound interest in some sections of his constituency in our state of Western Australia. Senator McKiernan and I have been here about 11½ years now and I do not think I have heard him talk on anything to do with this scheme before or heard him raise any concern he might share with people on this side about such a scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is very significant that he will now support us and the farming, mining and fishing communities of Western Australia. I hope that extends across the board to all the initiatives we will take in government to ensure that those people in the mining, fishing and farming industries in Western Australia get a far better deal than was extended to them under the previous 13 years of Labor administration.

It has been of some concern that those communities in rural Western Australia have been very hard hit over the previous 13 years. The Liberal and National government must now ensure that they get a far better deal. It is for that reason that my colleagues and I insist upon the maintenance of the diesel fuel rebate scheme because it is an essential part of their wellbeing into the next century.

I, too, guarantee that I will fight to the death to ensure that people have access to the scheme they have enjoyed in the past. It is one small way in which their contribution to valuable export dollars can be measured. I will make sure that I continue to support the scheme.

I can see Senator McKiernan about to leap to his feet. I sincerely hope that I have not misrepresented him in any way. I have not intended to misrepresent him. I am just delighted to know that we will now have some support from the opposition benches for giving people in the mining, farming and fishing communities of Western Australia a better deal.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 May, on motion by Senator Herron:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I have looked through this report on the tobacco industry and the costs of tobacco related illnesses; it is another outstanding report from the Senate. As I look around the Senate chamber, I see that everybody here has participated over the years in a great number of reports on various issues that have come before this chamber. That work has been done in the discharge of our functions as parliamentarians and in the interests of the Australian people. The chairman of the community affairs committee was Senator John Herron, who has now gone on to become a minister of the Crown, and I congratulate him on that.

SPEECH.PARA: This committee held public hearings at Canberra, Melbourne, again at Canberra, Sydney and Cairns on various dates. I understand that the facilities of Hansard would have been made available to the committee at those hearings. This parliament and the various committees of this parliament need resources to enable them to carry out their proper functions under the constitution in respect of their duties to the people of Australia.

It would be a disaster if this—I use this word advisedly—august parliament were treated as if it were another department of state, a department run by the government. It is in that respect that I rise to express my concern about an insert in the Daily Hansard of 1 May 1996 which came to my room this morning. That insert reads:
In the light of anticipated funding reductions, the distribution of the printed Daily Hansard is under review, with the expectation that there will be significant reductions in print runs.
When a final decision is made, users will be advised. Both the Daily Hansard and the Weekly Hansard are available on the Internet. The home page address for Hansard is:

The address is given. Senator Crane, whom I respect, laughs about this. This is not a laughing matter. It is a matter of what resources are made available to parliament. Parliament is superior to and stands above the ministry and it should not be subject to cuts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator MacGibbon, I am surprised that you should be making a joke of this. You have been one of the great parliamentarians over the years. You have not been a person who has sought ministerial office. You are a person who I have always thought has a great respect for parliament. To see you making fun of an issue of what resources are available to the most important institution in this nation is a matter of some sadness. Under the constitution, parliament is the supreme body. I feel a speech coming on in respect of this when I get up on the address‐in‐reply to the Governor-General's speech.

—I wish to raise a point of order. What Senator Cooney is addressing is undoubtedly of interest to this chamber. It is a matter of moment and a matter that ought be considered in due course, but aren't we discussing a Community Affairs References Committee report dealing with the tobacco industry and the costs of tobacco-related illnesses? Whilst we might have some concern about the ailments of the government, I am not really sure that Senator Cooney can draw the link that this is somehow related to tobacco illnesses.

—On the point of order, it is quite clear that what I am talking about has everything to do with this report, and, indeed, with every report. This very report, as with all other reports, is made possible only by people, as I have already indicated, travelling around the country calling a number of witnesses—and I will go through those—and having the resources to bring forward certain propositions that are of vital importance to this country. I would have thought that how that is done—the wherewithal by which this report is made available—is central to the issue that we have to address today.
—There is no point of order. Please continue, Senator Cooney.

—What I say is this. There are three arms of government. One of those arms is the executive, and it does not matter whether it is an executive from the party that is now on this side of the chamber or an executive, as it in fact is, from the parties on the other side. The executive is one arm, and one arm of government alone. If it is in a position to exercise, in effect, restraint upon the parliament and upon the judiciary so as to make their work less efficient—less efficient is the degree to which I put it—than it otherwise would be, then we as parliamentarians fail.

BREAK.PARA: Through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, Senator Abetz has got up, and properly so, to defend, as he sees it, his government. I am not having a go—if I can put it that way—in specific terms about his government or specifically about his government. What I am having a go about is this: that parliament, which is supposed to be the supreme body and from which the executive is selected, should not play to the tune set by government. If there are resources to be reduced, then they should be reduced by the parliament. If the parliament agrees, pursuant to a proposition brought before it, that it should take part in general funding cuts, so be it. It should not be subject to a proposition put forward in an inset or in a Hansard that says, `Well, look, there are anticipated funding reductions and the resources available to you are going to be less.' That is not how we as parliamentarians should go forward.

According to the governments's proposition, there is a need for funding cuts. That is a political issue. That is a matter we are going to discuss in the chamber. It is very legitimate—more than legitimate—for those opposite, who now have a mandate to govern, to put forward propositions that will result in funding cuts if accepted by this chamber. It is not proper, it is not in accordance with constitutional history and it is not in accordance with parliamentary history in this country or in England—from which we, in large part, take our precedents—that parliament should be subject to the dictates of a lesser body.

When the present government was in opposition, it called for, as it was entitled to do, documents from the executive. There was great dispute about that. Parliament was exercising its power over the executive—making the executive responsible to the legislature, to the parliament. It is proper that we as parliamentarians continue what was suggested by those applications and which came as a result of a long and glorious history of parliamentary rule. It is only proper that, if there is to be this reduction in the funds made available to this parliament to carry out its functions, we as a parliament should have a say in it.
I will finish on a lighter note. When I was talking about this with Marcia O'Hara, who guides me in these things, she said that Hansard is now only available—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon, Sen David

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented. I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Senator Cooney implied that there had been a lapse from my traditional respect for the institution of parliament. I can assure him that that is not so. I was very pleased at the general tenor of his address, but it did strike me as somewhat surprising that he commented that the executive was answerable to the parliament. That is a belief I have always inflexibly held. I passed an observation, and he probably did not hear me clearly. All I said was, `I can't remember when I have heard that coming from you when you were in government.'

—by leave—I accept what Senator MacGibbon says about his respect for parliament. In answer to that, Senator MacGibbon, you might look at one of the reports that we introduced to this chamber on the cost of justice. You will see that, as chairman of the committee involved, I said very much that sort of thing in print. I will get you a copy and get it sent to you.
—by leave—I will graciously, fully and unreservedly apologise to you, Senator Cooney.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles, Sen Susan

TALK.START.PARA: —I have almost hyperventilated with the exercise that I got jumping for the call. Madam Acting Deputy President, seeing that you have allowed the latitude you have on the consideration of the tobacco industry and the cost of related illness report of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, I just cannot allow some of Senator Cooney's comments to go without a response.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it fascinating, Senator Cooney, that your comments are from a person who belongs to a party which has been in government for 13 years and which has sought in every way, shape and form to grind down the facilities of this parliament lock, stock and barrel. Also, you come from a party which until recently saw fit to have the Daily Hansards printed on archive paper that lasts 100 years when the Daily Hansards are pelted out the door the moment the Weekly Hansards are printed. Also, you come from a party that should be sufficiently informed about technology to know that the Hansards are on the database, which is a far better and more economical use. You also come from a party that has trumpeted long and loud about conservation issues and preserving the forests. You cannot have it both ways.

We need to get a reasonable response across the board about the requirement of facilities by senators, members and people who use the Hansard as to what is the most practical position to take on the Hansards and the distribution of the daily, weekly and electronic Hansards because, quite frankly, I do not know too many people who go to bed every night and read their daily copy of the Hansard cover to cover. I have to say that I do not read mine every night.

I will now get back to the issue before the Senate—that is, the tobacco industry and the cost of tobacco related illness report handed down by the Senate Community Affairs References Committee just before Christmas. I, as I say, was a member of that committee and I agree wholeheartedly with the majority of the recommendations put down by the majority of the committee. I agree that smoking is addictive. I agree that everything that is humanly possible should be done not only to get people to stop smoking but also to stop them from smoking in the first instance.

However, Senator Minchin, who spoke on this report yesterday, and I did see fit to put in a minority report on some of the issues that were canvassed by the committee which we felt had a very serious and potentially deleterious impact on small business. We proposed something much stronger in our general recommendations about making the sale of cigarettes to minors illegal. I think that shows our bona fides in terms of the attitude that we took to the question of smoking in general and the desire that we had to see fewer and fewer people in the community smoking.

BREAK.PARA: We thought that, while this product is legal, snatching it out of the stores—as is literally proposed by the majority report—was not only unfair but would certainly impact very seriously on the viability of many businesses. The report details the number of businesses that would be affected by such a move. It also highlights the types of businesses that would be affected. The minority report was very seriously considered by Senator Minchin and me in those terms to make sure that the business community was not going to be seriously and detrimentally affected overnight.

The part that I wish to raise tonight is the role one of the cigarette companies played in the misinformation and the distribution of that misinformation. Senator West actually referred to it briefly last night as well in her comments about this report. Given the fact that the report had made a number of recommendations that I felt had great significance for the health of the Australian population, I was very disturbed that Philip Morris in particular decided to not only distort the report but also not even mention the dissenting report.

I have not been keen to agitate this sensitive issue, particularly in a public sense. I in no way wish my dissenting report to be interpreted as an endorsement of smoking, under-age smoking or in fact any type of smoking in general by any age. Rather, I am keen to see that whatever regulations are put into place are fair and reasonable.

Philip Morris actually sent a so-called information sheet to retailers around Australia, including retailers in Western Australia. I call it a misinformation sheet because it told business owners that the Senate's plan to ban the sale of cigarettes in their stores would dramatically impact upon their business. They inferred that this was legislation. In fact, the inference went one step further: they inferred that it was law. It went on to say that such a ban would threaten the income and livelihood of their business and that of their employees. It urged them to write to a named member of parliament raising a number of points, which they provided on a separate page, and to let Philip Morris know what action they had taken.

In the letters sent to Western Australian retailers my name and contact details were provided, albeit the provision of the details was partially incorrect as well. But in doing this it remains my view that it was implied that I had supported the committee's recommendations that businesses be seriously affected and that I should be lobbied to reverse that point of view. Of course, the company argued the contrary. In fact, I found it rather amusing in some sense, had it not been so wrong, that in the end they tried to imply that they had done this for my benefit, that I was somehow going to be made the hero of small business when the correction was made. Nothing could be further from the truth. They were not trying to do it for my benefit; they were trying to do it for theirs.

I think it is very sad, given the fact that we had heard the arguments of Philip Morris and a lot of the other cigarette companies throughout the year in the preparation of this report, that they then sought to go and distort the report and not even talk about the dissenting report at all in such a public fashion. No mention of that dissenting report was made in any letter in the first state, and it was not until I performed and questioned very seriously their motive and the way in which they had done this that they then offered to give me a list of the people to whom they had sent the original misinformation sheet. But then they retracted on that guarantee and said that they would in the end put out a sheet on my behalf.

My office was flooded with calls, faxes and letters from retailers who were angry at me for making recommendations on cigarette sales which stood to harm their businesses and at my party for doing so. But in reality nothing could be further from the truth. In the course of my negotiations with Philip Morris about sending the second letter, a representative of the company had the gall to tell me that the letter to retailers would work in my favour by providing me with a perfect opportunity to communicate with small business owners. That is absolute rot. They did not write such a letter to open up the paths of communication between retailers and members of parliament; they wrote it, plain as day, to further their own interests.

It is the responsibility of any business to ensure that the proceedings of this parliament are reported accurately—if that is what a business wishes to do. But to report them inaccurately, as Philip Morris did, is very sad. It is very sad given the fact that in relation to the business aspect and the impact on businesses, I was right behind them. I am not right behind them in terms of encouraging people to smoke. It is very sad that this event took place. I certainly hope that Philip Morris and other companies will be more careful in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague, Sen Baden

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has been very interested to see such an important report brought before it. Today and yesterday we heard speeches from the Chairman of the Community Affairs References Committee, Senator Herron, and from other colleagues of mine—from Senator Minchin, Senator Knowles, and Senator Cooney, and from Senator West, who spoke yesterday. I am sure that we will give every consideration to the arguments set out in the majority report and in the minority report.

SPEECH.PARA: For the record, I am entirely convinced by the position that Senator Herron has put to the committee in the majority report: tobacco is addictive; tobacco is poisonous to the human system; and it is our responsibility to curb every possible use of tobacco, consistent with the human rights and freedoms of citizens to choose. The day is fast coming when tobacco will be described accurately as a poison and when it will no longer be fully available for sale in the community in the way that it is now.

The other matter that leads me to rise concerns the general remarks in this debate from Senator Cooney, my good friend. I quarrel not with Senator Cooney's point that parliament should have appropriate and ample resources to do its work—of course, I support that; and from the clarification of Senator MacGibbon's remarks, I can see that he stands by that as well, as do we all—but I quarrel with my good friend Senator Cooney fearing an outcome. He is anticipating what might be in the budget.

I do not believe, even with the restricted and measured amount that was announced in the election campaign, that there will be a cut in the expenditure in the upcoming budget which will affect all areas of government and all areas of the parliament. But let me assert to Senator Cooney, and indeed to all senators, that, if there are any measures put in the budget that relate to parliamentary appropriation which are judged by a majority in this Senate to be seriously affecting the ability of the parliament to do its work, then the parliament must say so. Then, through the estimates process and legislation committees, it must examine the detail of the provision with regard to the Senate, Hansard, the library, the Joint House Department and, if necessary, the House of Representatives to ensure that the parliament does have the resources to fulfil its responsibilities—as we do in so many ways—not least in the committee system, which was the focus of Senator Cooney's remarks.

My colleagues and I said this when Senator Walsh was Minister for Finance and when at one stage there was a tussle about whether there was adequate provision for the parliament. The appropriate way for that to take place is for the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill), after proper consultations with colleagues, and for the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Mr Faulkner) and other representative senators to have meetings with the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) to ensure that there are appropriate moneys. If there are not appropriate moneys, they should make the appropriate resolutions when the budget is before us.

My quarrel with Senator Cooney is that he has set up a scarecrow. I understand solidly his principle that the parliament must have its resources. The parliament has control of the budget, even if it is initiated, as with all money bills, in the House of Representatives. We all—opposition and government members and minority party senators alike—must stand when the time appropriately comes. We must not stand in any anxious anticipation of the budget. But, when the time appropriately comes, we must stand to ensure that the parliament is able to fulfil its duties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chair, on a point of order: I rise to indicate that perhaps it would be appropriate to stick a bit closer to the reports. We have all allowed a great deal of latitude, but I think a number of senators wish to speak to particular reports. The debate we are having could be said to have strayed a bit from the actual report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane, Sen Winston

TALK.START.PARA: —My contribution will be very short. I fully endorse the report, and I wish to take up the matter of the two points of order that have been raised. I happened to make a comment across the chamber to which Senator Cooney replied, `This is no laughing matter, Senator Crane.' I was not laughing at this report. I did make an interjection when Senator Cooney, I believe quite incorrectly, introduced the matter of Hansard reports and the likelihood of us not having them. I said, `Do you smoke them, Barney?' He turned that around to say that I was laughing at this particular report.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make it quite clear to this chamber that I was not laughing at this particular report. Had Senator Cooney stuck to the subject matter, as has been raised by Senator Abetz and now Senator Evans, he would not have done that. If we are going to get through these reports, it is important that we stick to the subject matter. I reiterate: I was not laughing at this particular report. I was having a little bit of fun with regard to the misuse, I believe, of this particular report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank you for your contribution. In relation to the points of order, I think the debate did range too widely for the nature of the report under consideration. I accept that a great deal of latitude was given on this occasion, but I agree that we must stick to the detail of the report in question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I can promise that I will stick to the subject matter and content of this report because it was a very important committee inquiry into what became known as Eastlink. On 30 March last year, the Senate referred to the Senate Economics References Committee for inquiry and report the matter of the proposed interconnection of New South Wales and Queensland electricity grids with a high voltage powerline.

The matter arose following public questioning of the viability of the link and other matters, the imposition of its construction on private lands and the possible health risks emanating from high voltage powerlines. Because the committee's report was completed after the Senate rose at the end of last year, it was presented to the President of the Senate out of session on 18 December 1995.

Although the Eastlink inquiry stemmed from a proposal which forms part of a much broader plan, that of interconnecting the electricity utilities of the eastern states to increase national competitiveness and efficiency, the committee's work for the most part particularly related to the concerns of those people living along the proposed Eastlink route; that is, the regions flowing along a line from Gatton, near Toowoomba, in Queensland to Armidale in northern New South Wales. The link was to have been a 330 kilovolt double circuit steel trowel transmission line, having a length of about 380 kilometres to 400 kilometres, capable of carrying 500 megawatts in either direction.

During the course of this inquiry, the committee received 274 submissions, 1,266 form letters and surveys, and petitions carrying some 2,658 signatures. Public hearings were held in Toowoomba and Armidale and detailed inspections were conducted along parts of the route.

During these hearings and inspections it became clear to the committee that the communities affected by Eastlink were very strongly against the proposal. Demonstrations were held outside public hearing venues and the community of Allora organised a street parade to show the committee just how strongly people felt about Eastlink passing through the Allora region. I well remember that street demonstration because it was early in the course of our inquiry. I do remember that when the committee first went to Queensland to hear evidence we were welcomed by the then Queensland Minister for Mines and Energy, suggesting that we were conducting a kangaroo court, that because I as a South Australian was chairing it perhaps I didn't have any knowledge of what was going on in Queensland anyway.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is he still the minister?

—He is not minister. He is a colleague of Senator Burns, but I would say that, judging by the paper comments the next morning, not a close colleague of Senator Burns. It is the first time I have ever been on a Senate inquiry where senators have actually been welcomed with the enthusiasm they were on this inquiry. I think that is a sign that the people in the general community welcomed the opportunity and the activity of Senate committees.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the photos in the report distinctly shows a photograph of a truck going down the street. All it has on it is a banner saying, `We thank the senators just for coming'. I think that highlighted the effectiveness of Senate committees and the work they do. It gave people who felt they had been deprived of any opportunity, any public hearing or any consultation to have a chance to talk to the Senate and to publicly state what their feelings really were.

To me, one of the highlights of this particular inquiry was the fact that people who felt they had been deprived of any opportunity to state their case now felt that there was a venue and an opportunity, through the Senate committee system, for them to do so. I think it is a case of taking the parliament to the people when normally we expect the people to come to the parliament. So I think that was most important.

The committee's inquiry covered a lot of aspects, particularly the potential health effects of EMFs. I think that far outweighed any of the other considerations we were lobbied on or given evidence on, excepting perhaps some of the environmental concerns. The committee found that many people held genuine reservations about the impact that a high voltage powerline may have on their health and the health of their families.

In attempting to resolve this issue from a scientific point of view, it became clear that reputable scientists have taken strong stands both in support of and against the proposition that high voltage powerlines may cause health effects in people living near them. In the light of such conflicting evidence, and because it is not possible to scientifically prove a negative, the committee was unable to totally dismiss the possibility that there may be adverse effects. Similarly, we were unable to conclude that a definite link exists between high voltage powerlines and adverse effects on human health and thus that any new policy recommendations need to be made.

However, the one thing that we were able to agree on and conclude was that simply the fear of detrimental health effects—whether real or imaginary—was itself having an impact on the lives of some individuals who were affected by the Eastlink proposal. In acknowledging those concerns the committee took a similar stand to that of the Gibbs report and agreed that, as a minimum policy or until evidence is proved otherwise, the concept of prudent avoidance should continue to be practised by government and power authorities.

In the case of Eastlink, we particularly concluded that prudent avoidance should mean siting the line as far as possible away from houses, outbuildings and other farm facilities. Of course, history has moved on since then and we know that decisions have been taken which are possibly not in the light of the committee's report. But I am quite sure that some of the evidence that we took and the recommendations we made had an influence on a decision that was made by the now Queensland government to revisit the issue of both the power connection and the Eastlink proposal itself.

With regard to the community consultation process used, there was much evidence given to the committee that, while authorities made an effort to consult people directly affected by the proposal, both those individuals and the broader community rejected the consultation process as completely inadequate. People believed that they were never given a chance or choice on Eastlink in the consultation process and that because of that it was intrinsically flawed.

BREAK.PARA: The committee concluded that, while the power authorities put a large effort into public consultation, the methods used were not acceptable to and were not accepted by many of those people affected by the proposed powerline. The committee also concluded that the effect on the community of the public consultation process—as inadequate as it was—was, ironically, `considerable social disquiet and distress'.

Throughout the inquiry the committee was impressed by the knowledge and the enthusiasm the community groups and individuals held for alternative renewable forms of electricity generation. This view paralleled the opinion expressed in the report of this committee's predecessor, the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, when it tabled a report in the Senate in 1992 entitled Gas and electricity: combining efficiency and greenhouse. The report also said that Queensland would be an ideal place for increased research and development of renewable energy options.

I want to pay a special tribute to the secretariat. The economic references committee secretariat has had a number of inquiries over the past 12 months and the dedication of the staff is outstanding. In this particular case there were 274 written submissions, and the work that the secretariat put into the inquiry—particularly the secretary, Rob Diamond, and Dr Pippa Carron—was quite outstanding. I certainly pay tribute to them.

As the former chairman of that committee, I also pay tribute to the members of the committee, particularly my deputy chairman, Senator Bruce Childs. This committee has a history of providing unanimous reports to the Senate. Although this was not a totally unanimous report—we thought we had one until Senator Woodley put in a two‐page minority report at the end—there was general agreement and we worked towards a unanimous report. The functions of the committee in this particular case were designed to represent the views of people in the area and I felt that we had a responsibility to come to as unanimous a report as possible.

I thank the committee members—Senator Burns and Senator Woodley are here—and those people involved in the Eastlink inquiry. I appreciate the way we worked together. I hope that when the new references committee has met and its chairman is elected, the same spirit of cooperation will exist when reporting to the Senate on matters of vital importance which have been referred to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns, Sen Bryant

TALK.START.PARA: —I was most impressed during the committee hearings by the way in which people came along to make a contribution and to express their concerns for the future, not only about themselves in any commercial operation they may have had in terms of rural activity, but also about their children and their children's future.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think there is any doubt that Eastlink will proceed at some stage because there is no nation on this planet that stops any transmission line for electricity at a state or provincial border; it is done within a nation. Economically, I believe the imperatives are there for it to occur at a later stage.

As Senator Ferguson said, once again the Senate committee system gave an opportunity to people to have a platform to voice their concerns about what they saw as a real problem for them and the people in their community.

I have had discussions with eminent people in the electricity industry and with those who oppose transmission lines and have concerns about EMFs. One thing emerges clearly: no‐one can show that they are detrimental and no‐one can show that they are not. The jury is still out on that particular matter. There is one thing it is certain the jury is not out on: the visual pollution is damned horrible. It is a pity some other way could not be found through alternative energy.

People in the community voiced their opposition to Eastlink, but it was also very enlightening and very good to hear them suggesting alternative energy. I was a little surprised, because I have never heard people do so in such a consistent way as those people did who appeared before the committee. I for one support those sorts of propositions.

The consultation question was a real problem. I guess like all quangos the people involved in this particular measure took the Big Brother approach. They really were saying to people, `We'll consult with you,' but all they wanted to do was tell people what they were going to do, how they were going to do it and how it should not worry anyone. To me that is not real consultation. I hope that in the future, if this matter does proceed, there is good consultation. I hope that they do take notice of the suggestions by the committee about siting within particular properties and across that area generally when the link is put in in the years ahead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to welcome the tabling of this report of the Economics References Committee. The Senate may remember that in March last year I actually initiated this inquiry with the support of coalition members.

SPEECH.PARA: I, too, would like to add to what Senator Ferguson said. My congratulations and thanks go to the staff of the committee. They did a marvellous job. Not only were there over 200 submissions but some of those submissions were very substantial indeed.
On behalf of the committee, I would also like to thank the chair, Senator Ferguson. He did an admirable job, a remarkable job. It was very well done.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is an admirable fellow.

—He is. With Senator Ferguson, I would also like to thank the people who made submissions, particularly the people of Allora. It was quite a remarkable experience to have half the town turn out to welcome a Senate committee. I guess that this is one of the great and often undervalued roles of the Senate—that is, to provide an opportunity for people to have their voices heard.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the report was tabled last December, there has been a change of government in Queensland. In this respect, at least I congratulate the new coalition government on their decision to heed the views and advice of many people and of this Senate committee, and to cancel the Eastlink project. I hear what Senator Burns says. In the future there may be a connection of some sort but certainly now is not the time for that connection to be made.

I would like to draw the Senate's attention to a few parts of the report, particularly my additional minority report. It was not a dissenting report in the sense that it disagreed with the report which was made, which I endorsed; rather, it emphasised a number of points which I believe needed more emphasis and underlined a need for much better scrutiny of the real economic, environmental and health costs of Eastlink.
In terms of the minority report, I would just like to put on the record the broader environmental concerns which I believe need to be addressed. The report states:
The Democrats believe the evidence provided to the Inquiry shows
. a continuing lack of support by governments or the electricity industry for encouraging the reduction of electricity consumption throughout the community, and
. an ongoing failure to provide serious support or encouragement to alternative energy options, and—
although, as Senator Burns says, that is what the community is asking for—
. little or no consideration given to the potential impact of Eastlink on greenhouse gas emissions.
Those are the things that I wanted to underline, and that was really the reason for the minority report.

The final paragraph of the report reiterates once again that Queensland would be an ideal place for increased research and development of renewable energy options. It is obvious to me that this potential, underlined by two Senate reports, is not being addressed. That costs us all environmentally, but it means also that Queensland is missing out on considerable economic benefits in being able to establish renewable energy industries, with the likelihood of many jobs being generated in that area.

I believe it is good that Eastlink will now be scrapped, but it is crucial that in the light of that scrapping the Queensland government does not just replace it with other powerlines or, even worse, build more coal fired or hydro‐electric power stations. Unfortunately, it appears that this is still a possibility—that the Queensland government may go down that track.

I believe it is ridiculous that governments consider spending hundreds of millions of taxpayers' dollars on unnecessarily generating and transmitting electricity. It appears very much that this is being driven by electricity companies. We have seen evidence of that in recent weeks in the media in Queensland. We saw a scandalous example of an electricity corporation trying to hoodwink the state government into believing that there was an impending power crisis, with blackouts and brownouts supposedly likely to be widespread this summer.

It has now come to light, in a statement to the Queensland government in recent days, that this scenario is totally false and was based on false information given to the government by one of the power generating authorities. It is clear to me that electricity companies will do all they can to further their own commercial interests, regardless of the overall economic, environmental, social and health costs to the community.
I agree with what Don Maisch said in a right‐of‐reply which he made to the Electricity Supply Association of Australia's criticism of his original report entitled Fields of Conflict. He says this:
It is perhaps understandable why the ESAA—
Electricity Supply Association of Australia—

consistently denies that there is a possible EMF‐health hazard. Their role is not to be a public health "watch dog", but to be an advocate for the power industries interests, and talk of health hazards is, quite frankly, bad for business.
If this whole debate were about the hazards from tobacco smoking, and not about EMF's, could we rely on the tobacco institute to give expert advice on the health risk from smoking?

The ESAA should be concerned about the legal implications of their attempts to suppress the evidence of an EMF health hazard. In both the asbestos and tobacco industry, similar attempts to suppress hazard information eventually resulted in multi million dollar litigation cases. Specifically because their attempts to suppress information indicated the industries knew of the risk, and still knowingly exposed workers and the public to their products.

I just want to say that it is a risky strategy for the ESAA to be involved in. I hope the Queensland government is able to stand up to this sort of strategy used by the ESAA and make decisions for the future benefit of all Queenslanders.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I note that the only good thing the lost but not lamented Frank Walker ever did was ask the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters to inquire into the redistribution process. I think it was timely and necessary that the redistribution mechanisms be reviewed.

Probably the only other good thing that occurred under the Labor administration was that it finally got the right chairman for this committee. Laurie Ferguson was the third Labor chairman of this committee in as many months. No offence to my friend and colleague Senator Foreman, Laurie Ferguson did a tremendous job of chairing the committee at the time of this redistribution. I congratulate him on his appointment to the shadow ministry. Laurie did a great job in ensuring that we approach this job in a bipartisan fashion.

TALK.START.PARA: —He should be a minister.

—Shadow minister will do for the moment. We produced a unanimous report, which I always think is a healthy sign in what is otherwise a very partisan parliament. The committee secretary, Kieran Schneemann, and the secretariat did a first class job in supporting the committee on this occasion. I am delighted that Kieran has moved on to greener pastures by joining the staff of a coalition minister.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, it was a unanimous report. There are 24 individual recommendations which the new government will now need to consider. Because the recommendations are unanimous, certainly I as a coalition member am happy to encourage the government to adopt them. If they are adopted, the redistribution process will be considerably improved.

The major problem with the redistribution process at the moment is the requirement on the redistribution committee to ensure that 3½ years after the redistribution is made no division will deviate by over two per cent from the average divisional enrolment for that state. That was actually a relaxation of the original Labor rule which said that after 3½ years there had to be exact equality, which was an impossible requirement. There was a relaxation brought in to make it two per cent but even that has proved to be extremely difficult.

Labor and Liberal members alike regard that requirement on distribution committees in drawing electoral boundaries as an impossible mathematical requirement which is subjugating all other criteria in relation to community interest, et cetera, to the mathematical requirement, which for those of us who have been actively involved in redistributions is guesswork anyway. It is based on population projections which often prove wildly inaccurate. It is resulting in rural electorates, which have relatively low growth, being placed well above quota and therefore even bigger than they would otherwise be. Our rural members are having an impossible task placed before them as a result of this section.

One of the most important recommendations is that we allow for a variation in the rules relating to the 3½ years and the two per cent. I think the two per cent the committee recommended should be allowed out to 3½ per cent. The National Party submitted that it should be five per cent. I think the government should move to a 3½ per cent tolerance, if not more, in order that we can have a sensible approach to the business of redistributions and take account of other criteria. I also note the recommendation that the period of 3½ years probably should be reduced. It is very difficult to project 3½ years out. That probably should come back to two years.

There is also a very important recommendation, No. 4, in relation to large electorates. I think we all accept now the 10 per cent rule, although it was very contentious back in 1974 when it was introduced. We have recommended that the Minister for Administrative Services consult with the six largest House of Representatives seats to discuss ways in which we can improve the members' capacity to represent their constituents. I think that is a very important recommendation and one I encourage our new Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Jull) to take up. Some of our electorates are impossibly huge, some as large as western Europe, and very difficult for anyone to service.

We also recommended that the criteria in relation to existing boundaries be subservient to the other qualitative criteria—that is, community interests, means of communication and travel, physical features—because the boundaries commissioners find themselves having to constrain themselves to existing boundaries for no reason. There is no reason at all why undue regard should be paid to existing boundaries when drawing seats. Community interest is the most important qualitative criteria and should override existing boundaries. They are among the most significant recommendations which, again, were supported unanimously and which I hope the government will look seriously at.

We discussed the issue of electoral boundaries and political fairness to some degree. That is dealt with in chapter five of this very good report. It is an issue of considerable importance. We have seen in a number of state elections in particular governments of both colours winning office with less than 50 per cent of the two‐party preferred vote, which is not one vote one value at all. It of necessity means that voters for the party that is achieving government with less than 50 per cent has a vote worth more than the party that is gaining the majority of the vote but a minority of the seats.

It is a complete denial of one vote, one value to have such a situation occur. We have had that situation in Queensland and New South Wales recently. It occurred in South Australia in 1989, where the Labor Party, with 48 per cent of the vote, was able to govern. I was privileged to be part of a group of people who brought about a tremendous constitutional change in that state, the only state that provides for politically fair boundaries. We now have in South Australia the fairest boundaries of any state in Australia—or indeed of the nation—in that they provide that the party that wins a majority of the votes shall have a majority of the seats.

I, as an architect of that South Australian scheme, was wanting the committee to look at that issue from a federal point of view. I concede, and I do so in the report, that it is extremely difficult to apply such a mechanism at a federal level. It would have to be done on a state by state basis. You are dealing in some states with relatively few seats. It is very difficult to apply the very good South Australian system at a federal level.

I also concede that, at the moment, there is no obvious call for such a system. We do not have a situation nationally where governments win office with less than 50 per cent of the vote. The only recent experience was in 1990 where the coalition got just over 50 per cent of the vote but did not win. I do not think it was so dramatic a deviation that it would call for a review of this issue at a federal level but I do think it is an issue that the parliament should monitor. It should constantly keep under watch the question of the political fairness of federal boundaries. If we find significant deviations occurring—one way or the other—then the matter should be looked at to see whether something like the South Australian model should be brought in nationally.

In conclusion, I think this is a very good review of the nation's system for drawing electoral boundaries, the system that does determine who wins office. It is the nature of the seats; it is the nature of government. We do have to ensure one vote, one value but we also have to ensure politically fair boundaries. Therefore they need to be monitored. This report will now go to the new government and I hope it will adopt what are unanimous recommendations. I therefore commend the report to the Senate.
