DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles, Sen Susan

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to speak on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission because of my concern for the way in which it appears to lack accountability. It receives about $854 million each financial year, not counting funds for things like the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies or Aboriginal Hostels. The total Commonwealth expenditure on the indigenous population is about $1.3 billion and the latest census data indicates that the population of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people is 265,000 or 1.6 per cent of the total population.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have to say that what I am going to outline tonight I would outline if it came from any possible department that you could wish to think of. And I want to dispute up front any claim of any degree of racism, because I believe very firmly—as my record will show throughout my time in the Senate, in the chamber and in estimates and other committee hearings—that I have had a long interest in and concern about the welfare of Aboriginal communities, and particularly about health, employment prospects and housing. But accountability must be an across‐the‐board phenomenon. It must not be dependent upon race, colour, religion, nationality, gender or anything else. Nor should it be exempted by any of these things.

The Strelley station in the Pilbara, the north‐west region of my home state of Western Australia, and related entities such as the Nomads Charitable and Educational Foundation, have been intermittently under the microscope in the Senate since 1993. I have raised my concerns about it regularly, as have my colleagues Senator Panizza and Senator Tambling. There have been speeches, questions on notice and questions asked at many Senate estimates committee hearings. There has been print media and television coverage. Now an ombudsman investigation is under way because ATSIC is not able to provide any substantiation that it has been accountable on Strelley.

The response to the concerns raised since 1993, when a task force review was conducted, has been piecemeal to say the least. The outcome has been questionable at best. Certainly, it would appear that the former minister, Mr Tickner, had little interest in the allegations raised. Equally, it appears that certain staff in ATSIC Perth have had to go it alone in terms of trying to sort out the mess, by commissioning a special task force review and an independent audit report of its grants to the Strelley and Nomads entities. The most recently released audit report is an inspection of funds granted by ATSIC to Strelley and Nomads. That was conducted by Duesburys Chartered Accountants. The report, I have to say, is damning. I seek leave of the Senate to table both these documents.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report arises from a recommendation made by the Strelley task force review team back in March 1994. It indicates that the former Department of Aboriginal Affairs and its successor, ATSIC, planned a number of reviews of the Strelley organisation over the past 20 years. These did not eventuate until the regional council of ATSIC made a once and for all decision in April 1993 to suspend ongoing funding for 1993‐94 to Strelley and Nomads until a major review was undertaken. CDEP funding was suspended in July of the same year by ATSIC.

SPEECH.PARA: The task force report explains that the reason for this is that the administrator of the companies, Mr Don McLeod, whose office is located in South Guildford some 1,800 kilometres away from the site of Strelley station, constantly denied ATSIC access to the Aboriginal communities there. The report says that Mr McLeod required ATSIC staff or staff from other agencies to seek his permission before they visited the Aboriginal communities. Approval was not usually forthcoming and, when it was, administrative staff from the South Guildford office accompanied the ATSIC staff on their visits. They were not permitted to contact the communities directly to arrange visits. Due to this arrangement and the alleged lack of cooperation by Mr McLeod, the investigation took many years to eventuate. When it did, according to the report, it `was not able to satisfactorily address a number of the terms of reference'.
Additionally, recommendation 10 on page 70 of the report indicates:
ATSIC staff conducted their tasks working under the threat of being arrested and charged if they stepped foot onto any of the Strelley properties . . .

Actually, the concern about Mr McLeod's ability to run the stations in the best interests of Aboriginal people goes as far back as 1977. I seek leave to table a copy of an assessment made by the Chief Pastoral Inspector, dated 12 January 1977, to the chairman of the Pastoral Appraisement Board.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In that assessment the inspector stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from this, it is pointed out that Strelley Pastoral Pty Ltd also "manage" Coongan and Warralong, held by the Aboriginal Land Fund Commission. It should also be noted that this same group, headed by Mr Don McLeod, were in earlier years responsible for the virtual extinction of Riverdale, Meentheena, Yandeeyarra and White Springs as operational station units and it is a foregone conclusion that such will be the fate of Strelley, Coongan, Warralong and any other pastoral properties which come under their control.
The inspector then concluded:

I have no hesitation recommending that the request to transfer Lalla Rookh to Strelley Pastoral Pty Ltd be refused until such time as the company has demonstrated its real intent and ability to efficiently develop, stock and operate stations in a husband-like manner as required under Section 103(3)(4)(c) of the Land Act.

Maybe if that advice and warning had been heeded, we would not be seeing the gross waste that is evident today. Nonetheless, the evidence that has been produced subsequent to that since 1993 has been damning and the former minister should have taken it on board.

PARA.BREAK: The task force report showed that Strelley had been abandoned, but considerable infrastructure remained in place. This included 40 houses, 10 shelters, two single‐men's quarters, an ablution block, a solar pack, two school buildings, a mechanical workshop, a power house building, two generator sheds, two fuel tanks and three water tanks. It is alleged that, despite this state of abandon, ATSIC had poured another $1.6 million into Strelley. This is despite the insistence of a former caretaker, Mr Ric Livingstone, who stated in his February 1993 report to the state government that the money was going to waste or, worse still, that it had been syphoned away from the Aboriginal communities.

SPEECH.PARA: The task force report in 1994 and the subsequent Duesburys report of this year paint a very bleak picture in terms of gross misappropriation of funds and the questionable existence or use of assets. Alarmingly, in my mind many of these assets were in Perth, not in the Pilbara where the communities reside. It stands as obvious that they could have been of no benefit to the Aboriginal communities for where they were intended. These assets included a $33,000 Cessna 150, five motor vehicles to a total value in excess of $70,000, a mobile septic tank valued at about $3,500 and an $11,000 trailer‐mounted solar plant that is in Perth. The finding on the CDEP outcome is that not a single time sheet could be found. There was no proof of the operation of the program.

In the summary of the findings Duesburys indicate that, despite their best efforts, they were unable to prove and identify the existence of assets purchased with grant funding, nor were they able to physically inspect these assets to determine their operational status or their current market values.

Some of the things that need to be highlighted include the failure to provide financial reports to ATSIC within the reporting periods specified, failure to have financial reports certified as having been ordered and failure to have financial reports audited by an appropriate person. The list goes on. Then we have specific examples of apparent impropriety, which include $10,000 paid to Nomads Management Pty Ltd for accounting and auditing, although the relevant invoices for the related party did not detail the nature or the extent of the services provided. We have amounts totalling $55,000 which were paid to Nomads for airfares and charters, but Nomads were unable to provide Duesburys with documentary evidence as to the nature and extent of the services provided by Nomads. Then we have repairs and maintenance of vehicles.

An amount of $6,500 was paid to Watts Western Rubber, Bayswater, Perth, to purchase 58 tyres and 188 tubes. The invoice was made out to Strelley Pastoral Pty Ltd but was charged to Nomads. I might add that the 58 tyres and 188 tubes were for seven vehicles, as were sixty‐five 12‐volt heavy duty batteries to the value of $3,997. The invoice was made out to the Moolyella Society but was charged to Nomads. Once again, the 65 batteries were for seven vehicles. Amounts totalling $12,122 were paid to Nomads Management during 1991-92 for the services of a part-time bookkeeper, but they were not able to ascertain which employee these charges related to.
My time is almost ready to expire. The problem is vast and it needs to be addressed.
The minister is very much aware of it. I think the Senate should show grave concern for the way that this has been administered over the last 13 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight in the Senate chamber I rise to mourn, firstly, but also, more importantly, to pay tribute to a great Australian, a great Western Australian, a great Aboriginal and a great bloke. I am talking about Rob Riley. The sad news came through to this place yesterday that Rob had been found dead in a suburban hotel in Perth. It came as a tremendous shock to me personally. To those around this place who have known Rob and who have known him for a number of years, it was a tremendous shock. I imagine that it must have been a devastating blow to his family. I have not been able to talk with them. It is probably something that they as family members and intimate friends will not be able to recover from for a long period. I think all of Australia is saddened by Rob's passing and all of Australia is deprived of a very important individual in the area of Aboriginal reconciliation and also in the area of the representation of the views and aspirations of the Aboriginal people of this country.

BREAK.PARA: I got to know Rob pretty well when he worked as a senior adviser for the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Gerry Hand, in the late 1980s. I suppose we had a few things in common. He reminded me on one occasion that there was a bit of Irishness in both of us, which lent for a bit of rebellion. He attributed that in part to his name, which was reflective of at least part of his ancestry.

Rob came from a minority and, as a migrant, I was also part of a minority. He also cared very deeply about people. We had another thing in common, which I only very recently found out, and that was that both of us had been apprentice fitters and turners. I stuck with my apprenticeship and he, fortunately or unfortunately—certainly fortunately for his people—went on to do other things.

Firstly, he served in the Beaufort Street Magistrates Court as a clerk with the Crown Law Department in Western Australia. He then joined the army and spent three years there before he returned to Western Australia to study psychology at the WA Institute of Technology, or WAIT, as we called it. From there he went on to work for the Aboriginal Legal Service in Western Australia.

Then he started on a path that was to bring him to national and, some would say, international prominence when in 1981, at the tender age of 26, he won an election to serve on the then National Aboriginal Council. At 27 he was chairman of the WA branch, and at 28 he was the deputy national chairman. In June 1984 he became the youngest national chairman elected by the national conference of the NAC.

He had very strong views, as did the NAC. They were perhaps so strong that in the middle of 1985 the then Hawke government decided to abolish the NAC, which put Rob out of a job. But he was not out of a job for very long. He moved himself up to Darwin in the Northern Territory to work for the Northern Lands Council. It was when he came to work for the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Gerry Hand, that I actually got to know him. From there he continued on his path to national prominence.

Last year he was again very much in the news in Western Australia after a couple of unfortunate incidents where he was caught in charge of a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol. Obviously, for a person of his prominence and in his position it was not something to boast about. But he met that challenge front on, so much so that the West Australian newspaper saw fit to write an editorial about him on Thursday, 3 August 1995. I want to quote part of that editorial because it says an enormous amount about the man:

. . . he has salvaged dignity and pride from his nightmare with his straightforward courage and honesty in accepting responsibility and punishment for his wrongdoing. From the depths of his humiliation he has set an example of strength of character that others can look up to.
His resignation from his job of executive director of the ALS is widely regretted—especially in the Aboriginal community—but it was the only honourable course he could take.
Later in the editorial it says:

Although his offences are serious, they took place at a time of high emotion for Mr Riley. National Aboriginal and Islander Week this year focused on the tragedy of Aboriginal children separated from the families and only days before his offences Mr Riley had publicly told of his own emotionally wrenching experience. To his credit, he made no attempt to use this to avoid the consequences of his actions.

The reason I quote those comments is to draw attention to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission's national inquiry into the separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children. That is a much needed inquiry. I hope—as, I suspect, do those other senators who had cause to make representation to the then government to get this inquiry under way and ensure it had funding—that the inquiry will be a memorial to Rob Riley, a person who has done so much to support the cause of Aboriginals in this country.

I do not want to make this a partisan political issue but, as we have talked about in other debates in this place, attempts have been made by government to cut funding in various program areas under its administration. I suspect that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission will have to endure some funding cuts just as other government bodies and departments will. But I hope that, as a tribute to Rob Riley, this inquiry will be separated from those cuts and that the minister will ensure that it will be fully funded to its proper conclusion. That would be a tribute to this great Western Australian, this great Aboriginal, this great bloke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I address the Senate once again on the issue of what I believe is failed financial supervision in Queensland. Senators might recall that in 1995 I advised the Senate that the Queensland Office of Financial Supervision and the Queensland Treasurer had failed to competently supervise credit unions in that state. Queenslanders, quite properly, are asked to have confidence in the credit union supervisor, but I believe that the Queensland Office of Financial Supervision has failed to act on serious complaints made to it against the Queensland Professional Credit Union Ltd.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to explain tonight the extent of the failure of the Queensland Office of Financial Supervision. A number of my Queensland constituents have tried to extract answers from QOFS but to no avail. They have been told that the matters with respect to the 57th report of the Senate Committee of Privileges are `at an end'. Yet I believe that no proper investigation was undertaken by QOFS. There should have been an investigation into the conversion of long service and holiday pay to employer superannuation. If independent inquiries had been made, the QOFS would no doubt have responded differently to my constituents.

With respect to the Senate Privileges Committee report, the issue is that the Queensland Professional Credit Union took reprisal action against a member when he tried to question management of the QPCU. That person's membership in the credit union was terminated without giving that member his rights according to the credit union's own rules. Three members of the credit union then complained to the QOFS claiming that the credit union had broken its rules and, in turn, was in breach of the financial institution's code.

The QOFS responded to the members' complaint that they had considered the Senate Privileges Committee report and found that no further action was warranted. However, they did not bother to give reasons. Was it perhaps that they did not consider that there may have been a breach? Perhaps they may have thought that there was a breach but that it was not worth pursuing. Or is it that the relationship between the credit union and the industry regulator—the QOFS—is such that it is in the best interests of QOFS not to bite the hand that feeds it? The QOFS is funded by levies from the credit unions and building societies.

Clearly, the Senate Privileges Committee was not satisfied with the board of the credit union when it wrote that `it considers the explanation provided by QPCU was disingenuous'. At the 1995 AGM of the QPCU the managing director, Mr Rutherford, stated that they were delighted with the report of the Senate Privileges Committee. Also, in correspondence received by my constituents, QOFS said, `It has confidence in the current financial position of the society and the quality of its prudential management and corporate governance.' This, I believe, is a matter of kinship. Where are credit union members to go for a remedy for a blatant disregard of proper processes, as in this case? If the regulatory body is not prepared to enforce the code, all we have is window‐dressing as regulation, and this could have dire consequences for the members of all non‐bank financial institutions.

The second issue which has been the subject of member complaint arose out of the 1994 annual report of the QPCU. It was about a conversion of long service leave and unused holiday leave which was transferred to employer superannuation. I have raised this matter previously in the House and with the previous Treasurer and also with the current Treasurer (Mr Costello). They have advised that such a conversion was not possible.

Yet at the 1995 AGM of the Queensland Professional Credit Union Ltd shareholders were assured by Mr Ellwood of KPMG that the ATO, the Australian Taxation Office, had completed its inquiry into the conversion of long service leave to superannuation. This assurance was expressed in such a way as to leave most shareholders with the impression that the ATO was accepting the transfer as a bona fide transaction. In a newsletter from KPMG to clients and in the media, KPMG states:

It should be noted that industrial relations legislation may limit the extent to which some employee entitlements (for example, unused annual leave and long service leave entitlements) may be the subject of such arrangements . . .

This newsletter is referring to arrangements which I have described above. KPMG is telling clients in February 1996 that this type of transfer should not be attempted. But at the credit union's AGM in October 1995 Mr Ellwood appeared to be telling the members of the credit union that it was okay. They cannot have it both ways. There is a basic inconsistency in the advice by KPMG. This raises a serious question: was the credit union meeting in October 1995 misled by KPMG?

This is a matter of public interest. With the current federal government's proposal to allow banks, and presumably credit unions, to partake in a share of the superannuation honey pot, it is imperative that adequate controls are in place to protect the retirement savings of Australian workers. Failure to do so would be inviting disaster. I will ask the Treasurer, in a letter to him, to advise the Senate of the ATO's estimate of the legality, prevalence and revenue loss as a result of transactions such as the one advised by KPMG to the Queensland Professional Credit Union Ltd.

I ask the Treasurer to assure the Senate that the ATO is recovering the outstanding tax in the above transactions and to say what steps it has taken to audit this activity in Australia. I ask the Treasurer to raise these issues at the next meeting of the council of premiers and finance ministers and seek a review of the effectiveness of the Australian financial institutions code and whether the exemptions from the Australian corporations and securities legislation enjoyed by credit unions and building societies should be revoked. It is my view that these organisations have not been subjected to an effective watchdog and would be better supervised at arm's length through the Australian Securities Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to recognise the tremendous work being done in Australia towards the treatment of diabetes, particularly with respect to young children and adolescents. The International Diabetes Federation is an international body which conducts research around the world into the very debilitating disease of diabetes.

SPEECH.PARA: In Australia, there is a consultative section which focuses particularly on childhood and adolescent diabetes. The co‐conveners of that organisation are Mrs Lorna Mellor and Professor Martin Silink. Mrs Mellor is the Vice‐President of the International Diabetes Federation and Professor Silink is a leading expert and specialist in this field.

In May last year I became aware of the need for funding support for the Australian consultative section to enable them to conduct an international conference in Sydney in April of this year. The aim of that conference was a workshop to bring together experts from Asian and Pacific nations to look at research and, in particular, the training needs for health care workers in other less developed countries so that they could go back and assist in the treatment and further research of this disease.

The conference was held in April of this year. It was able to be held because of the support that came particularly from AusAID through its international seminar support program. I particularly want to place on the record thanks to the former minister Gordon Bilney for his assistance in making that support through that program possible.

As I said, the workshop took place in Sydney in early April this year. I am advised that it was a great success. I was privileged to be able to attend the opening ceremony and to meet a large number of distinguished international experts, all giving selflessly of their time towards researching and assisting in trying to find not only a cure but ways of more appropriately dealing with this complaint; a complaint that many people are aware of and that afflicts, in particular, adults—quite often without any prior warning—but also new-born children and young people, who then have to live with that complaint for the rest of their lives.

Last week I had the opportunity to visit the new children's hospital at Westmead and to see the work being performed by Professor Silink and his team first-hand. It is certainly inspirational to see the dedication of Professor Silink and his team—the nurses and all the other staff at the children's hospital—giving hope to and giving of their time and their skill for these young children.

I also wish to place on the record a particular tribute to Mrs Lorna Mellor who has given many years to the International Diabetes Federation in this area. She is a woman who has the ability to get things moving, to get things happening, and to get other people moving. She was very much responsible for getting this conference off the ground and for bringing people from all around the region to Sydney. I understand that that is the first time that that has occurred. I understand that, following the conference, the delegates have returned to their own countries, are putting those training programs in place and are looking to conduct further workshops which will progress the work in this most important area.

In conclusion, I believe that this is one of those areas where government funding support is certainly appropriate and it produces real results. I only hope that, in the current climate that grips the current government, they can recognise that there are many areas where we should not look to reduce the funding but to improve it.

I finally wish to pay tribute to Mr Terry Sheahan who has been the President of Diabetes Australia for a number of years. He was also involved in getting this conference off the ground. Terry retires from his position as President of Diabetes Australia this year, and he has also devoted many years to assisting in this very important work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make this relatively brief because the President has indicated he has a matter he would like to raise. I raise a matter which is quite serious in nature in my home state of New South Wales. On 25 May there will be a by-election for the seat of Clarence. Clarence is a very pleasant area on the north coast of New South Wales. It takes in a number of very pleasant towns such as Lismore, Grafton, Casino and Yamba.

SPEECH.PARA: Up until recently, Harry Woods, whom we all know, the former member for Page, looked after that area as the federal member. In this up‐coming state by‐election Harry Woods will be the candidate for the Labor Party. I have to say, not at any great length, that I wish him a great deal of luck and thank him for continuing to serve the people of that north coast area.

I wish to raise a matter about the National Party candidate in that particular seat, a fellow by the name of Geoff Knight. The things that I wish to say regarding him are not quite as pleasant as those I have said about Harry Woods. Geoffrey Leonard Knight was, until the end of last year—in fact, January—living in the state seat of Coffs Harbour at an address at Bonville.

Some time earlier this year Geoff Knight, realising there was shortly going to be a National Party preselection for the seat of Clarence, took up enrolment at an address known as `Bonnyhills' Orara Way, Glenray. The interesting thing about this particular property is that there is no house there, there is no water and there is no electricity. Geoff Knight was subsequently preselected by the National Party and he is now the candidate for the state seat of Clarence. Understandably, the National Party may not have done anything about this if they had been unaware but the fact is it is now on the public record.

In the Daily Examiner, a local paper, on 23 April 1996 an article ran about the investigation into his having made false statements in relation to his electoral enrolment. That article pointed out that Mr Knight had originally told them he had never lived on that property, that he had used it for an agistment, that he had fenced it and that he believed, in accordance with the provisions for the local government electoral roll, that being a property owner was entitlement enough for enrolment on the federal roll. In fact, he relied on that enrolment to vote in the last federal election.

BREAK.PARA: The article then went on to point out that Geoff had resiled from that position some two weeks later by saying that he had in fact resided in a caravan for a very short period though his wife and child had continued to live at the previous address during the period of this supposed residence on the block. I must urge the National Party, in the light of this being on the public record, to do something in relation to their candidate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I very reluctantly rise on a point of order about people being maligned in the parliament in the adjournment debate. I thought the adjournment debate was non‐controversial and designed so we could actually get along with talking about things that I know you, Mr President, want to talk about later.
—There is no point of order. There is certainly plenty of precedence.

—The district returning officer at Grafton has indicated the matter is under investigation and that if found guilty Mr Knight could incur the penalty of a $10,000 fine or three years in gaol. That is entirely a matter that will be dealt with by the DPP and subsequently the courts. Why I raise this matter is not to intervene in that investigation but to urge the National Party to take the appropriate action and supervise their candidate or, if possible, obtain a further candidate who has not breached the laws of this land.
